PREFACE
         This code of the Village of Germantown Hills, as supplemented,
contains ordinances up to and including ordinance 878, passed January 16, 2025.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular
provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not affect the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
ORDINANCE NO. _862___
 
AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING THE COMPENSATION OF THE VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND
TRUSTEES
 
 
WHEREAS, this Ordinance is enacted in compliance with 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-5, et
seq.,
 
NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Germantown Hills, Illinois, as follows:
 
Section 1. The compensation of the Village President shall be a salary of four
thousand ($4,000.00) each fiscal year.
 
Section 2. The compensation of each Village Trustee shall be one-hundred
twenty-five ($125.00) for each meeting of the Board of Trustees attended, if
public notice of the meeting was given.
 
Section 3. The compensation established by the Ordinance shall apply to the
Village President and Trustees who are elected at the general municipal
elections in 2025 and thereafter, until changed by proper Ordinance passed and
approved according to law.
 
Section 4. The compensation established by this Ordinance shall be in addition
to reimbursement of proper expenses actually incurred during the course of
performing the duties of Village President and Trustees.
 
Section 5. Ordinance No. 624 continues to be in effect for those Trustees who
are not up for re-election at the general municipal election in 2025, but
Ordinance No. 624 will cease to have any effect following the general municipal
election in 2027.
 
Section 6. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its
passage and approval according to law.
 
PASSED by the Board of Trustees of the Village of Germantown Hills, Illinois,
and APPROVED by its President this _16th___ day of February ____, 2023.
 
                     APPROVED:
 
 
                     ____________________________
                      Village President
 
ATTEST:
 
___________________________
Village Clerk
 
 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 714
   AN ORDINANCE OF THE VILLAGE OF GERMANTOWN HILLS
   ADOPTING THE VILLAGE CODE OF THE VILLAGE OF GERMANTOWN HILLS, ILLINOIS
   WHEREAS, the ordinances of the village of Germantown Hills have, heretofore,
existed only as a collection of separate ordinances; and
   WHEREAS, the village board of the village of Germantown Hills has determined
that it is in the best interest of the village and its citizens to codify the
village's ordinances.
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the president and board of trustees of the
village of Germantown Hills, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1. The code which is presented to the village board this 13th day of
December, 2012, and published by Sterling Codifiers and incorporated herein by
reference is hereby declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official
village code of the village of Germantown Hills.
   Section 2. The code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the Germantown
Hills Village Code and is hereby published by authority of the board of
trustees and shall be supplemented to incorporate the most recent legislation
of the village as provided in section
1-1-3 of the Germantown Hills village code.
   Section 3. All general ordinances of the village passed prior to September
13, 2012, are hereby repealed, except such as are included in the Germantown
Hills village code, subject to the saving clause set forth under title 1,
chapter 2 of the village code of Germantown Hills.
   Section 4. This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
its passage and approval in the manner provided by law.
   Section 5. This ordinance is hereby ordered to be published in pamphlet form
by the village clerk and said clerk is hereby ordered to keep at least three
copies hereof available for public inspection in the future and in accordance
with the Illinois municipal code.
   PASSED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF GERMANTOWN HILLS,
ILLINOIS, AND APPROVED BY ITS PRESIDENT THIS 13TH DAY OF DECEMBER, 2012.
         APPROVED:
            Village President
ATTEST:
   Village Clerk
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
GERMANTOWN HILLS VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the village board of trustees, this code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the official village code of Germantown
Hills. This code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the GERMANTOWN HILLS
VILLAGE CODE and is hereby published by authority of the board of trustees and
shall be supplemented to incorporate the most recent legislation of the village
as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title headings, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this code by title in any legal documents. (2012 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of the
state as the ordinances of the village of general and permanent effect, except
the excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2012 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
numbers of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this code.
(2012 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Said code, while in
actual possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and
remain the property of the village and shall be returned to the office of the
village clerk when directed so to do by order of the village board of trustees.
(2012 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the village passed prior to the adoption of this code
are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this code or are by
necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed:
   A.   Tax levy ordinances;
   B.   Appropriation ordinances;
   C.   Ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations;
   D.   Franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to
persons or corporations;
   E.   Contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants;
   F.   Salary ordinances;
   G.   Ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other
public places;
   H.   Improvement ordinances;
   I.   Bond ordinances;
   J.   Ordinances relating to elections;
   K.   Ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or
from the village; and
   L.   All special ordinances. (2012 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue of section
1-2-1 of this chapter, excepting as this code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case, this code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances with respect to such provisions only. (2012 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not,
as to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act
done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued
or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect
any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the village herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the village under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this code. (2012 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this code,
or any codes or portions of codes adopted herein by reference, is for any
reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness of the remaining portions of this code, or any codes or portions
of codes adopted herein by reference. The village board hereby declares that it
would have passed each section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or
phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared
unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (2012 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATION
SECTION:
1-3-1: General Rules Of Interpretation
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the village president and board of trustees may
be fully carried out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare.
   C.   Computation Of Time: Whenever a notice is required to be given or an
act to be done in a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be held,
the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall not be counted
in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be held shall
be counted.
   D.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or perform
some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or
other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   E.   Gender: A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be
applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to
males.
   F.   Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or
more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such persons or officers.
   G.   May; Shall: The word "may" is permissive; the word "shall" is
mandatory.
   H.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   I.   Number: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be
applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing.
   J.   Officers And Employees Generally: Whenever any officer or employee is
referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by
the words "of the village of Germantown Hills".
   K.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
   L.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the
village has been changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter",
"section" and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to village ordinances is not meant to
amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2012 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
BOARD, THE BOARD OR BOARD OF TRUSTEES: Unless otherwise indicated, the village
board of trustees of the village of Germantown Hills.
CODE: The village code of the village of Germantown Hills.
COUNTY: The county of Woodford, state of Illinois.
FISCAL YEAR: The "fiscal year" of the village of Germantown Hills shall begin
each May 1 and shall end each April 30 of the following year.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or any
act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the village, or any activity which, by its perpetuation, can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of a person or
persons within the community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The village of Germantown Hills, county of Woodford, state of
Illinois.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law on any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person or, in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark. (Ord. 197, 6-17-1982; amd. 2012 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (2012
Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   A.   General Penalty Imposed:
      1.   Violation: Unless specifically provided elsewhere in this code, any
person found to have been in violation of any of the terms and provisions of
this code shall be fined in an amount not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed to be a separate
offense.
      2.   Additional Penalties: In addition to the fine described in
subsection A1 of this section, the circuit court may impose a period of
"conditional discharge", as defined in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1-4,
or "court supervision", as defined in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1-21,
for a period of up to six (6) months, an order of restitution, an order to
perform community service, an order to complete an education program and/or any
other appropriate penalties or conditions authorized in any section of this
code or stand alone ordinance or any conditions for conditional discharge set
forth in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-6-3 or for court supervision in 730
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-6-3.1, as the foregoing are amended from time to
time.
      3.   Costs And Fees: Any person violating the terms or provisions of this
code shall be subject, in addition to the penalties set out in this subsection,
to the payment of court costs and reasonable attorney fees.
      4.   Default In Payment: A default in the payment of a fine or any
installment of a fine may be collected by any means authorized for the
collection of monetary judgments. The village attorney may retain attorneys and
private collection agents for the purpose of collecting any default in payment
of any fine or installment of that fine. Any fees or costs incurred by the
village with respect to attorneys or private collection agents retained by the
village attorney under this subsection A4 shall be charged to the offender.
   B.   Limitation; Compliance With Statute: The provisions of subsection A of
this section notwithstanding, no penalty shall be greater than that established
by state statute for the same offense. (2012 Code)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were a part of
each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2012 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the village board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (2012 Code)
ARTICLE A. ADMINISTRATIVE PAYMENT FOR CERTAIN VIOLATIONS
SECTION:
1-4A-1: Application Of Provisions
1-4A-2: Ticket For Violation
1-4A-3: Payment Of Fine
1-4A-4: Failure To Pay Fine
1-4A-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The procedures established in this article shall apply to violations of the
following village regulations, including amendments of those regulations from
time to time, and to such other regulations as the village may determine to add
by amendment of this article (individually a "substantive regulation" or
collectively the "substantive regulations"):
   A.   Title 4, chapter 4 of this code regulating open burning and
recreational burning within the village, as amended from time to time.
   B.   Title 7, chapter 1, article B of this code regarding mailboxes, as
amended from time to time. (Ord. 609, 4-24-2008)
   C.   Title 8, chapter 2 of this code pertaining to sediment control, runoff
control, and soil stabilization during construction projects. (Ord. 609, 4-24-
2008; amd. 2012 Code)
1-4A-2: TICKET FOR VIOLATION:
   A.   Issuance: The village clerk or a deputy in the county sheriff's office,
under contract with the village, at the request of a member of the corporate
authorities of the village, or at the request of the village clerk, or on his
or her own initiative, shall issue tickets for violations of any of the
substantive regulations. If the ticket is for violation of a substantive
regulation other than a parking regulation, the village clerk or the deputy
shall hand the original ticket to the violator and if served by a deputy, the
deputy shall deliver a copy to the village clerk. If the ticket is for
violation of a parking regulation, the deputy shall place the original ticket
under a windshield wiper of the offending vehicle and shall deliver a copy to
the village clerk. (Ord. 542, 2-24-2005; amd. 2012 Code)
   B.   Form Of Ticket: The village clerk, in consultation with the village
attorney, shall design and arrange to be printed an appropriate form of ticket
that complies with this article and the provisions of the substantive
regulations. In so doing, fines shall be designated for violations of the
substantive regulations in accordance with the penalty provisions of each
respective substantive regulation in a fashion that informs the violator of the
financial benefit of paying the ticket at the village hall no more than thirty
(30) days after issuance of the ticket. (Ord. 542, 2-24-2005)
1-4A-3: PAYMENT OF FINE:
Fines shall be payable to the "Village Of Germantown Hills" at the village
hall, 216 Holland Road, Germantown Hills, IL 61548. (Ord. 542, 2-24-2005)
1-4A-4: FAILURE TO PAY FINE:
If the village determines to file an action in the county circuit court against
a violator who has not paid the fine stated in a particular substantive
regulation within thirty (30) days after issuance of a ticket, the violator,
upon a plea or finding of guilty, shall pay the higher fine stated in the
particular substantive regulation, plus all applicable court costs. The village
attorney shall file such actions in the county circuit court upon the direction
of the village president. (Ord. 542, 2-24-2005)
CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-5-1: Compensation
1-5-1: COMPENSATION:
   A.   Established:
      1.   President: The compensation of the village president shall be a
salary of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) each fiscal year.
      2.   Trustees: The compensation of each village trustee shall be sixty
five dollars ($65.00) for each meeting of the board of trustees actually
attended, if public notice of the meeting was given.
   B.   Effect Of Provisions: The compensation established by this section
shall apply to the village president and trustees who are elected at the
general municipal elections in 2009 and thereafter, until changed by proper
ordinance passed and approved according to law.
   C.   In Addition To Expenses: The compensation established by this section
shall be in addition to reimbursement of proper expenses actually incurred
during the course of performing the duties of village president and trustees.
(Ord. 624, 11-13-2008)
ARTICLE A. ORDER OF BUSINESS AND CONDUCT AT MEETINGS
SECTION:
1-5A-1: Time And Location Of Meetings
1-5A-2: Call Of Special Meetings
1-5A-3: Roll Call; Quorum; Order Of Business
1-5A-4: President Duties And Privileges
1-5A-5: Member Duties And Privileges
1-5A-6: Motions And Resolutions
1-5A-7: Taking And Entering Votes
1-5A-8: Precedence Of Question
1-5A-9: Adjournment
1-5A-10: Previous Question
1-5A-11: Motion To Lay On The Table
1-5A-12: Motion To Amend
1-5A-13: Reconsideration
1-5A-14: Passage Of Ordinances, Contracts And Appropriations
1-5A-15: Committees And Trustee Positions
1-5A-16: Member Under Influence Of Liquor
1-5A-17: Nonattendance
1-5A-18: General Provisions
1-5A-19: Electronic Participation In Meetings
1-5A-20: Conduct Code
1-5A-1: TIME AND LOCATION OF MEETINGS:
The regular stated meetings of the village board shall be held in the village
hall on the fourth Thursday of each month at six o'clock (6:00) P.M., and
special meetings shall be held at such place and at such time as, in the
judgment of the president, or any two (2) members of the board, the same are
necessary or expedient, notice of such special meetings being given to each
member of the board by the village clerk. Such call shall be in writing, duly
signed and presented to the village clerk, who shall proceed immediately to
prepare notices of the special meeting and shall cause them to be served on the
president and members of the board by the village clerk or any person in the
village. Such notices shall describe in brief the nature and object of the
call. No business shall be transacted at any such special meeting except such
as is mentioned in the notice calling the same. (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010; amd. 2012
Code; Ord. 724, 9-26-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
1-5A-2: CALL OF SPECIAL MEETINGS:
At every special meeting, the call for the same shall be read and afterwards
filed with the village clerk. (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-3: ROLL CALL; QUORUM; ORDER OF BUSINESS:
At the hour selected for a meeting, the village clerk (or someone appointed to
fill his/her place) shall proceed to call the roll of the members, mark the
absentees, and announce whether a quorum (i.e., a majority of all the members
elected) is present. Upon the appearance of a quorum, the board shall be called
to order, the president taking his chair, if present, and the board appointing
a temporary chair if he is absent. If a quorum does not appear, the board shall
not thereby stand adjourned until so voted by the members present. When a
quorum is present, the board shall proceed to do the business before it, which
shall be conducted in the following order unless temporarily suspended by not
less than two-thirds (2/3) of the corporate authorities: (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
   A.   Pledge Of Allegiance;
   B.   Approval of the minutes of the preceding meeting and their amendments;
   C.   Public comment;
   D.   Current agenda items;
   E.   Ongoing agenda items;
   F.   Presentment of bills;
   G.   Reports of standing committees:
      1.   Finance;
      2.   Streets/equipment;
      3.   Personnel;
      4.   Police;
      5.   Parks;
      6.   Sewer;
   H.   Reports of special committees;
   I.   Reports of officers:
      1.   Zoning officer;
      2.   Village clerk;
      3.   Public works;
      4.   Village attorney;
      5.   President;
   J.   Communications to the board;
   K.   Adjournment.
(Ord. 725, 9-26-2013; amd. Ord. 875, 11-21-2024)
1-5A-4: PRESIDENT DUTIES AND PRIVILEGES:
   A.   The village president shall preside at all meetings of the village
board. In the absence of the village president, a village president pro tem
shall be elected from one of the village trustees to act as temporary chair.
   B.   The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum, and may speak
to points of order in preference to other members, and shall decide all
questions of order, subject to an appeal to the board, on which appeal, no
member shall speak more than once without the unanimous consent of the board.
   C.   While the presiding officer is putting the question or while business
is being transacted, no member shall walk across the room or out of the board
meeting except by consent of the presiding officer. (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-5: MEMBER DUTIES AND PRIVILEGES:
   A.   When a member wishes to present a communication, petition, order,
resolution or other original matter, he shall briefly state its nature before
presenting the same.
   B.   No member, without leave of the board, shall speak more than once upon
the same subject, until every member desirous of speaking shall have spoken.
   C.   A member called to order by the chair shall immediately cease speaking,
unless permitted to explain. If the member appeals from the decision of the
chair, the board shall decide on the case, but if there is no appeal, the
decision of the chair will be conclusive.
   D.   While a member is speaking, no member shall hold any private discourse,
nor pass between the speaker and the chair.
   E.   Every member who is present when a question is stated from the chair
shall vote thereon, unless excused by the board, or unless he is directly
interested in the question, in which case, he shall not vote. (Ord. 657, 6-24-
2010)
1-5A-6: MOTIONS AND RESOLUTIONS:
   A.   Any matter before the board may be set down as a special order of
business at a certain time if two-thirds (2/3) of the members present vote in
the affirmative, but not otherwise.
   B.   No motion shall be put or debated unless it is seconded. When a motion
is seconded, it shall be stated by the presiding officer before debate; and
every such motion shall be reduced to writing if required by a member, and the
proposer of the motion shall be entitled to the floor.
   C.   After a motion or resolution is stated by the presiding officer, it
shall be deemed to be in possession of the board, but may be withdrawn at any
time before decision or amendment by unanimous consent of the board.
   D.   If the question under consideration contains several distinct
propositions, any member may have the same divided when the sense admits of it.
   E.   In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered on the minutes of
the board, the names of the members moving and seconding the same shall be
entered also. (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-7: TAKING AND ENTERING VOTES:
   A.   If a member requires it, the yeas and nays upon any question shall be
taken and entered on the minutes.
   B.   The result of all votes by yeas and nays shall be announced by the
village clerk, and no vote shall be changed after the tally list has passed
from the village clerk.
   C.   The president may vote: 1) when the vote of the trustees has resulted
in a tie; 2) when one-half (1/2) of the trustees elected have voted in favor of
an ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote; or 3) when
a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities is required by
state statute or local ordinance to adopt an ordinance, resolution, or motion.
(Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-8: PRECEDENCE OF QUESTION:
   A.   When a blank is to be filled and different sums or times proposed, the
question shall be taken first on the least sum or the longest time.
   B.   When a question is under debate, the only motion in order shall be:
first, to adjourn to a certain day; second, to adjourn; third, to lay on the
table; fourth, the previous question; fifth, to refer; sixth, to amend;
seventh, to substitute; eighth, to postpone indefinitely, or to a certain day.
Numbers two (2), three (3) and four (4) are to be decided without debate. (Ord.
657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-9: ADJOURNMENT:
   A.   A motion to adjourn the board shall always be in order except: first,
when a member is in possession of the floor; second, while the yeas and nays
are being called; third, when the members are voting; fourth, when adjournment
was the last preceding motion; and fifth, when it has been decided that the
previous question shall be taken.
   B.   A motion simply to adjourn cannot be debated or amended, but a motion
to adjourn to a time named may be and is open to debate and amendment. (Ord.
657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-10: PREVIOUS QUESTION:
When the previous question is moved and seconded, it shall be put in this form:
"Shall the main question now be put?". If this is carried, all further
amendments and all further motions and debates shall be excluded, and the
questions put, without delay, upon the pending amendment in proper order, and
then upon the main question. (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-11: MOTION TO LAY ON THE TABLE:
   A.   A motion to simply lay a question on the table is not debatable, but a
motion to lay on the table and publish, or any other condition, is subject to
amendment and debate.
   B.   A motion to take subject matter from the table may be proposed at the
same meeting, provided two-thirds (2/3) of the members present voted therefor.
(Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-12: MOTION TO AMEND:
   A.   A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an
amendment to an amendment shall not be entertained.
   B.   An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order, but
an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
   C.   On an amendment to "strike out and insert", the paragraph to be amended
shall first be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be stricken out,
and those to be inserted, and finally, the paragraph as it will stand if so
amended shall be read. (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-13: RECONSIDERATION:
   A.   A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time during the same
meeting or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for
reconsideration being once made and decided in the negative shall not be
renewed, nor shall a vote to reconsider be reconsidered.
   B.   A motion to reconsider must be made and seconded by members who vote in
the majority. Provided, however, that where a motion is lost by reason of not
receiving a two- thirds (2/3) vote required for its passage, a motion to
reconsider may be made and seconded by those voting in the minority. (Ord. 657,
6-24-2010)
1-5A-14: PASSAGE OF ORDINANCES, CONTRACTS AND APPROPRIATIONS:
   A.   The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of every ordinance
and shall be entered on the record.
   B.   No ordinance shall be repealed or passed, or contract or appropriation
of money made, unless by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the members elected.
(Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
1-5A-15: COMMITTEES AND TRUSTEE POSITIONS:
   A.   Standing Committees And Trustee Positions:
      1.   Standing Committees:
         a.   The following shall be the standing committees of the village
board, each of which shall be comprised of five (5) members of the village
board: (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010)
            Finance
            Parks
            Personnel
            Police
            Sewers
            Stormwater
            Streets/equipment
      (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010; amd. Ord. 741, 2-26-2015)
         b.   The village president shall set the responsibilities of the
standing committees and shall, from time to time, require reports from the
standing committees to the village board.
      2.   Trustee Positions: The village board hereby establishes the
following other standing trustee positions, each of which shall consist of one
trustee, who will be responsible for discharging the functions that are clearly
implied by the name of the position:
            Business liaison
            ESDA liaison
            Planning commission liaison
            Plat officer
            Zoning board of appeals liaison
      3.   Appointment Procedure:
         a.   The village president shall make appointments of trustees to each
standing committee and other positions identified in subsections A1 and A2 of
this section. For each standing committee identified in subsection A1a of this
section, the village president shall designate one of the trustees appointed to
the committee as the chairperson of the committee. Likewise, the village
president shall designate one of the trustees appointed to the committee as the
vice chairperson of the committee.
         b.   In making said appointments and in designating a trustee as the
chairperson or vice chairperson of a committee, the village president shall
first confer informally with the village board and the trustee considered for
the appointment. The village president shall consider the following factors in
deciding on the appropriate appointment, understanding that no single factor
automatically carries any greater weight than any other factor, and the village
president should use his or her best judgment under all the circumstances and
should act in the best interest of the village and the board as a whole:
            (1)   Interest or lack of interest by a trustee in a particular
appointment.
            (2)   Seniority of a trustee.
            (3)   Length of time a trustee has served in a particular
appointment.
            (4)   Past performance by a trustee in a particular appointment.
            (5)   Experience of a trustee in a particular area, outside of his
or her experience on the board.
            (6)   The ability or inability of particular trustees to work well
together.
            (7)   The possible need for diversity of viewpoints, experience or
seniority of a particular committee.
         c.   Once the Village President has made appointments, those
appointments stand until changed by the Village President in accordance with
the foregoing procedure. Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as
creating an expectancy or property right in a particular appointment or
position.
      4.   Frequency Of Appointments: The Village President shall make
appointments to each committee and other position identified in subsections A1
and A2 of this section as soon as reasonably practicable after the effective
date hereof. Thereafter, the Village President shall make appointments to each
committee and other position identified in subsections A1 and A2 of this
section as soon as reasonably practicable following the swearing in of Trustees
after elections held regularly in each odd numbered year. Until new
appointments are made, the previous appointments continue in effect. In the
best interests of the Village and the Village Board as a whole, to be
determined by the Village President, the Village President may change the
assignment of Trustees to any particular committee or position (including, but
not limited to, the positions of Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of a
committee) at times other than following the swearing in of newly elected
Trustees. In doing so, the Village President shall follow the procedure in
subsection A3 of this section.
   B.   Ad Hoc Committees And Positions: The Village President, in his or her
discretion, may appoint Trustees to such ad hoc committees or positions as may
be appropriate from time to time. In making those appointments, the Village
President shall follow the procedure in subsection A3 of this section.
   C.   Village President As A Member Of All Committees: The Village President
shall be a member of every standing committee and of every ad hoc committee
which may be created from time to time.
   D.   Reports Of Chair: The Chair of standing and select committees to whom
references are made shall in all cases report, at least once in each month
unless further time is granted by a vote of the Board, the state of facts, with
their opinion thereon, signed by the members concurring therein. Minority
reports may be received at the same time with majority reports. (Ord. 657, 6-
24-2010)
   E.   Economic Development Council: In addition to the standing committees
described in subsection A1 of this section, the Village shall have an Economic
Development Council ("EDC").
      1.   The EDC shall have eight (8) to twelve (12) members and consist of
the following:
         a.   The Village President;
         b.   Two (2) Village Trustees;
         c.   The Economic Development Director;
         d.   One (1) or two (2) representatives of the business community;
         e.   One (1) or two (2) Village residents;
         f.   A representative from the Village Planning Commission and/or a
representative from the Village Zoning Board of Appeals;
         g.   A representative from the Germantown Hills School District 69
and/or a representative from the Caterpillar Trail Water District.
      2.   The Village President shall make appointments to the EDC, using the
procedure set forth in subsections A3 and A4 of this section. The Village
President may also consider the suggestions of the bodies from which the
respective members will be selected.
      3.   The EDC shall be charged with promoting economic growth, recruiting
community minded businesses, and assisting existing business. The Village
President may provide such further direction and responsibilities as he or she
sees fit. (Ord. 727, 9-26-2013)
   F.   ESDA: In addition to the standing committees described in subsection A1
of this section, the Village shall have an Emergency Services and Disaster
Agency ("ESDA") as provided herein and in title 5, chapter 1, article A of this
Code:
      1.   The ESDA shall have twelve (12) to thirteen (13) members and consist
of the following:
         a.   The Village President;
         b.   The ESDA Coordinator, generally the Village Administrator;
         c.   The Village Administrator, if not selected as the ESDA
Coordinator;
         d.   The Superintendent of Public Works;
         e.   The Chief of the Germantown Hills Fire Protection District;
         f.   The Woodford County Sheriff, or his designated deputy;
         g.   The Worth Township Road Commissioner;
         h.   Two (2) Village Trustees;
         i.   One (1) representative of the business community;
         j.   A representative from the Germantown Hills School District 69;
         k.   A representative from the Caterpillar Trail Water District; and
         l.   A member of the Woodford County ESDA.
      2.   The Village President shall make appointments to the ESDA, using the
procedure set forth in subsections A3 and A4 of this section. The Village
President may also consider the suggestions of the bodies from which the
respective members will be selected.
      3.   The ESDA shall be charged with the duties set forth in title 5,
chapter 1, article A of this Code. (Ord. 778, 5-18-2017)
1-5A-16: MEMBER UNDER INFLUENCE OF LIQUOR:
Any member upon any regular or special meeting of the Board of Trustees who
shall, in the judgment of the Board, appear under the influence of liquor to
such a degree that he is incompetent to take part in the deliberations of the
Board shall be expelled from such meeting by a vote of the Board. (Ord. 657, 6-
24-2010)
1-5A-17: NONATTENDANCE:
If any member absents himself from any regular meeting of the Board, unless
excused by the Board, he shall not be compensated for such meeting. (Ord. 657,
6-24-2010)
1-5A-18: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Public Comment At Meetings:
      1.   The purpose of these provisions is to ensure that interested parties
representing various points of view are allowed time to present those
viewpoints while permitting the board to conduct its meetings in an efficient
and effective manner.
      2.   All comments should be addressed to the board as a whole and should
not include any personal attacks.
      3.   The board should refrain from responding, engaging in question and
answer, or debating an issue with the public.
      4.   Each speaker may speak once and shall confine comments to five (5)
minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance if the
village and avoid repetitious statements. If the village president or his or
her designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5)
minutes limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the
village, or has been needlessly repetitious the speaker shall immediately
conclude his or her comments.
      5.   Speakers are not permitted to donate their allotted time to other
people.
      6.   The foregoing rules in the subsection A shall apply to all village
board, committee, and other meetings of the village subject to the Illinois
Open Meetings Act.
   B.   Any person called to order shall immediately take his seat until the
point of order is decided. While any person is speaking, no other person shall
engage in conversations with others or pass between the speaker and the Village
President.
   C.   Only matters relevant to Village business shall be discussed. Any
person indulging in personalties or language calculated to injure the feelings
of any other person or the harmony of the Board shall be called to order.
   D.   The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in "Robert's Rules of
Order" shall govern the Board in all cases to which they are applicable and in
which they are not inconsistent with the standing rules of the Board.
   E.   The rules contained in this section may be temporarily suspended by a
vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the members present, but shall not be repealed,
altered or amended, unless notice thereof shall have been given in writing, and
alteration or amendment submitted at least one (1) meeting prior thereto, and
two-thirds (2/3) of all the members elected shall concur therein.
(Ord. 657, 6-24-2010; amd. Ord. 875, 11-21-2024)
1-5A-19: ELECTRONIC PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS:
   A.   Subject to the provisions of this section, any member of the village
board may electronically attend any open or closed meeting of the village board
via telephone, video, internet connection or other technology which allows
effective audio interaction with the member at a remote location. A member may
electronically attend a meeting of the village board only under the following
conditions:
      1.   The member must notify the village clerk as soon as practicable
before the meeting of the member's request to electronically attend the meeting
so that necessary communications equipment can be made available.
      2.   The member must assert one or more of the following reasons why he
or she is unable to physically attend the meeting and explain to the village
clerk the factual basis for that assertion:
         a.   The member cannot attend because of the member's illness or
disability; or
         b.   The member cannot attend because of conflicting obligations to
his or her employer; or
         c.   The member cannot attend because he or she is otherwise engaged
in business on behalf of the village; or
         d.   The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency;
or
         e.   The member cannot attend because of unexpected childcare
obligations.
      3.   Any member participating electronically and those members of the
village board who are physically present at the site of the meeting must have
the capability during the meeting to effectively and instantaneously engage in
interactive audio communication with each other. During open meetings, members
of the audience must have the capability to hear all audio interactions among
all the members of the village board who are present either physically or
electronically.
   B.   Within a reasonable time after receiving a request from a member of the
village board to electronically attend a meeting of the village board, the
village clerk shall inform the remaining members of the village board of that
request.
   C.   Acceptance or rejection of a request by a member to electronically
attend a meeting of the village board shall be determined in accordance with
the following procedures:
      1.   After establishing that a quorum is physically present at the
meeting which the member of the village board desires to electronically attend
and establishing that the communications equipment necessary to permit
participation in the manner prescribed by this section is functioning properly,
the presiding officer shall state that:
         a.   A member of the village board has requested permission to
electronically attend the meeting; and
         b.   The member will be authorized to electronically attend the
meeting unless a motion objecting to the member's electronic attendance is
made, seconded, and approved by majority of the members of the village board
physically present at the meeting.
      2.   If a motion objecting to the member's participation is made and
approved by a majority of the members of the village board physically present
at the meeting, the member making the request may not electronically attend the
meeting. If no such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion is made
and seconded but not approved by a majority of the members of the village board
physically present at the meeting, then the request by the member to
electronically attend the meeting shall be deemed approved by the village
board, and the presiding officer shall declare the requesting member present.
After such declaration by the presiding officer, the authority of a member to
electronically participate may not be withdrawn by the village board for that
meeting.
   D.   The minutes of any meeting during which a member of the village board
electronically attends shall identify any such member.
   E.   A member permitted to electronically attend a meeting of the village
board shall have the authority to participate in the meeting to the same extent
as those members physically present, subject to the same limitations applicable
to those members physically present. A member attending electronically may
leave a meeting and return to the same extent and under the same conditions as
members who are physically present, provided the member attending
electronically shall announce his or her leaving and returning. (Ord. 657, 6-
24-2010; amd. Ord. 869, 10-19-2023)
1-5A-20: CONDUCT CODE:
   A.   Purpose: The public expects the highest standards of professional
conduct from the village president/trustees elected to local government. The
purpose of the conduct code is to establish guidelines for the ethical and
interpersonal conduct of the village president/trustees. The village president/
trustees are answerable to the community through democratic processes, and the
conduct code will assist in providing for the good government of the village.
   B.   Standards Of Conduct: Village president/trustees shall uphold the law
at all times to:
      1.   Seek to advance the common good of the village as a whole while
conscientiously representing the communities they serve;
      2.   Perform the functions of office truly, faithfully and impartially to
the best of their knowledge and ability in accordance with the following core
values:
         a.   Integrity: Giving the village interests absolute priority over
private individual interests.
         b.   Honesty: Being truthful and open.
         c.   Objectivity: Making decisions based on a careful and fair
analysis of the facts.
         d.   Accountability: Being accountable to each other and the public
for decisions taken.
         e.   Leadership: Confronting challenges and providing direction on the
issues of the day.
      3.   Uphold the conduct code as a means of promoting the standards of
behavior expected of the village president/trustees and enhancing the
credibility and integrity of the board in the broader community.
   C.   Village President/Trustees Responsibilities:
      1.   Conduct To Be Observed: Village president/trustees are agents of the
public whose primary objective is to address the needs of the citizens. As
such, they are entrusted with upholding and adhering to the ordinances and
resolutions of the village as well as all applicable state and federal laws. As
public servants, the village president/trustees must observe a high standard of
ethical conduct in their official duties and faithfully fulfill the
responsibilities of their offices, regardless of their personal or financial
interests.
      2.   Dedicated Service: The village president/trustees should faithfully
work toward developing programs to address the needs of the citizens in the
course of their duties. The village president/trustees should strive to perform
at a level which is expected of those who work in the public's interest.
      3.   Conduct At Meetings: Village president/trustees shall respect the
colleagues, staff and members of the public present during board meetings or
other proceedings of the village. Meetings shall provide an environment for
transparent and healthy debate on matters requiring decision making.
      4.   Refrain From Attacking A Trustee's Motives: When a question is
pending, a trustee can condemn the nature or likely consequences of the
proposed measure in strong terms, but he must avoid personalities, and under no
circumstances can he attack or question the motives of another trustee. The
measure, not the trustee, is the subject of debate. If a trustee disagrees with
a statement by another in regard to an event that both witnessed, he cannot
state in debate that the other's statement "is false". But he might say, "I
believe there is strong evidence that the trustee is mistaken". The moment the
chair hears such words as "fraud", "liar", or "lie" used about a trustee in
debate, he must act immediately and decisively to correct the matter and
prevent its repetition.
   D.   Interpersonal Behavior: Village president/trustees shall treat every
person, including other trustees, employees, individuals providing services on
a contract for service, and the public with dignity, understanding and respect
and ensure that their work environment is free from discrimination, bullying
and harassment.
   E.   Community Representation:
      1.   The village president/trustees shall observe a high standard of
professionalism when representing the village and in their dealings with
members of the broader community.
      2.   All committee members will accurately and adequately communicate the
attitudes and decisions of the committees and village board, even if they
disagree with the majority decision of the committee or village board.
   F.   Governmental Relationships: The village president/trustees recognize
the importance of working constructively with other levels of government and
organizations in Germantown Hills and beyond to achieve the goals of the
village.
   G.   Sexual Harassment Policy:
      1.   The Village President and Board of Trustees shall be bound by the
Village's sexual harassment policy, subject to the provisions of Section
1-5A-20.G.2 of this Code.
      2.   Alleged harassment by the President or a Trustee against another
elected official can be reported to the Village President. If the Village
President is the reporting person, or is implicated by the allegation, or the
reporting person is not comfortable reporting to the Village President, then
the report can be made to any Trustee, or the Village Administrator. Any report
under this section must be referred to the Village's legal counsel, who then
must appoint a qualified independent attorney or consultant to review and
investigate the allegations. (Ord. 657, 6-24-2010; amd. Ord. 822, 1-16-2020)
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
SECTION:
1-6-1: Inauguration Date
1-6-2: Bonds
1-6-3: Personnel Policy Adopted
1-6-4: Social Security
1-6-1: INAUGURATION DATE:
Newly elected officers shall be inaugurated, and their terms of office shall
officially commence, at the beginning of the first regular meeting of the
corporate authorities of the village in the month of May following the regular
municipal election in April at which the officers were elected. (Ord. 622, 9-
25-2008)
1-6-2: BONDS:
   A.   Bond Amounts:
      1.   President: The bond of the village president shall be payable to the
village in the penal sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), with security
to be approved by the corporate authorities.
      2.   Clerk: The bond of the village clerk shall be payable to the village
in the penal sum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), with security
to be approved by the corporate authorities.
      3.   Treasurer: The bond of the village treasurer shall be payable to the
village in the penal sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), with security
to be approved by the corporate authorities. It is hereby found and declared
that said amount is not less than three (3) times the latest federal census
population or any subsequent census figure used for motor fuel purposes. (Ord.
42, 6-26-1961; amd. 2012 Code)
   B.   Filing Bonds: All of said bonds shall be filed with the village clerk
except the bond of the clerk, which shall be filed with the village treasurer.
(Ord. 42, 6-26-1961)
1-6-3: PERSONNEL POLICY ADOPTED:
The "Employee Policy And Procedures Manual", passed April 26, 2012, as the same
may be amended from time to time by ordinance, is hereby adopted by reference.
(2012 Code)
1-6-4: SOCIAL SECURITY:
   A.   Policy And Purpose: It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose
of the governing body of village to extend to the eligible employees thereof,
effective July 1, 1977, the benefits of the federal old age, survivors, and
disability insurance provisions of the federal social security act and
amendments thereto. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the
village president shall take such action with the social security unit of the
state employees' retirement system of Illinois as may be required by applicable
state and federal laws or regulations.
   B.   Agreement With State: The village president is hereby authorized and
directed to execute an agreement with the social security unit of the state
employees' retirement system of Illinois to secure coverage of eligible
employees as provided in subsection A of this section.
   C.   Withholdings: Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees for the
purpose provided in subsection A of this section are hereby authorized to be
made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state
and federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid to the social security unit
in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws or
regulations.
   D.   Employer Contributions And Administrative Expense: Employer
contributions and administrative expense shall be paid to the social security
unit in accordance with applicable state laws and regulations from amounts
appropriated for such purposes.
   E.   Records And Reports: The village clerk shall maintain such records and
submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or
regulations. (Ord. 152, 1-19-1978)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE CLERK AND VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-6A-1: Village Clerk
1-6A-2: Village Treasurer
1-6A-3: Assistants To Clerk And Treasurer
1-6A-1: VILLAGE CLERK:
   A.   Appointment: The office of village clerk is an executive office of the
village. The village clerk is appointed by the village president, with the
advice and consent of the village board.
   B.   Duties: In addition to the duties now imposed upon that office by law,
or provided elsewhere in the ordinances of the village, the village clerk shall
perform the following duties:
      1.   Issue notices to the village board, to the members of the different
committees, and to all persons whose attendance will be required before any
such committees, when directed by the president or chair thereof, and issue
notices of special meetings of the village board.
      2.   Turn over all monies received thereby on behalf of the village to
the village treasurer, promptly upon receipt of the same, and with such monies,
give a statement as to the sources thereof.
      3.   Affix the corporate seal of the village to all papers requiring the
corporate seal.
      4.   Keep a full record of all meetings of the village board.
      5.   Keep all records, receive, mark and properly file all papers coming
to the village clerk's office belonging to the village, grant certified copies
from the records or papers of the village, and execute such orders as may be
received from the village board.
      6.   Countersign all warrants and deliver the same when called for,
taking a proper receipt for same, and generally do and perform such other
duties as may be required thereof by the village board, the ordinances of the
village, and the laws of Illinois.
      7.   Be a custodian and keeper of the corporate seal and of all the
books, ordinances, papers, and instruments of the village, except as otherwise
provided by law or ordinance; and all the books, ordinances, papers, and
instruments mentioned in this subsection B7 shall at all times be kept open to
inspection by the village president, members of the village board, or any other
officer of the village.
      8.   Index all ordinances by their number or title and attend to the
proper and lawful publication of the same, and keep a list of all committees
appointed by the village board, and of the business, respectively, and from
time to time referred to them, and note, when the committees report, the date
and nature of their reports.
      9.   Attest all deeds, contracts, and leases made by the village board
and, in conjunction with the village president, sign all ordinances, bonds,
licenses, and orders of the village treasurer, and affix the seal of the
village thereto.
      10.   Attend and record all regular, special and committee meetings of
the village board and attend, record and electronically record executive
session meetings as required.
      11.   Serve as a notary for the village.
      12.   Work with the codification company and submit ordinances for code
updating.
      13.   Submit a proposed tax levy to the finance committee for its review
and modification and assist the finance committee in the preparation of the
annual tax levy.
      14.   On or before the last Tuesday in December of each year, file with
the county clerk a certified copy of the annual tax levy for the village.
      15.   Prepare and deliver all licenses and bonds on receipt of the
required sums of money therefor.
      16.   At the end of each fiscal year, make out and publish in a manner
prescribed by the village board, a full and complete statement of the receipts
and expenditures of the village during each year, and submit such statement to
the village board and, at the end of six (6) months, submit to the village
board in writing a detailed report, showing the aggregate of the expenditures
during the past six (6) months, classing such expenditures under the respective
heads thereof.
      17.   Without delay, deliver to the village president all ordinances or
resolutions under his charge which may require approval or other action of the
village president, with all the papers on which the same were founded.
      18.   Issue and attest, under the corporate seal of the village, all
licenses granted by the village president or village board and keep a full
record of all licenses granted, transferred, or revoked by the village board or
the village president, under their authority, with the date that the same were
granted, transferred, or revoked (and if revoked, the cause therefor), with the
number thereof and the full name and residence of the applicants for such
licenses, in a book to be kept for that purpose, and when bonds are required,
the names and addresses of the bondsmen or sureties.
      19.   Cause all ordinances of the village imposing any fine, penalty,
imprisonment, or forfeiture or making any appropriation to be timely posted and
published in accordance with law.
      20.   Each year, file with the county clerk a certified copy of the
ordinance in which the total amount of appropriations for all corporate
purposes of the village, legally made, are levied and assessed.
      21.   Receive all petitions or other communications addressed to the
village board and read such petitions or communications at the meeting of the
village board next following receipt unless otherwise directed by the village
president.
      22.   Prepare annual liquor licenses.
      23.   Accept service of process of legal papers served on the village and
deliver to the village attorney and to the village president.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Respond to village resident, village trustee and village president
questions and comments in person or on the telephone with information in a
positive and polite manner.
      2.   Must be able to perform and/or manage multiple tasks, projects, and
priorities concurrently.
      3.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      4.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      5.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including the village trustees and the village president.
      6.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      7.   Be responsible for providing information to appropriate village
committees and the village board with the responsibility to attend appropriate
village meetings and committee meetings as required.
      8.   Maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      9.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position if the work is similar, related, or a logical assignment
to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Must have working knowledge of Microsoft Word/Excel and Adobe
Acrobat.
      3.   Computer experience.
      4.   Must be available to attend village board, special and committee
meetings.
      5.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      6.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
      7.   Must be bondable.
      8.   Must be a notary public.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   F.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village is an equal opportunity
employer. In compliance with the Americans with disabilities act (ADA), the
village will provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with
disabilities and encourages both prospective and current employees to discuss
potential accommodations with the employer. Any essential function or
requirement of this position will be evaluated as necessary should an
incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to a
disability as defined by the Americans with disabilities act. Reasonable
accommodations for the specific disability will be made for the incumbent/
applicant when possible. (2012 Code)
   G.   Compensation: The village clerk shall receive a salary of three hundred
sixty dollars ($360.00) each fiscal year. (Ord. 189, 3-19-1981; amd. 2012 Code)
   H.   Deputy Clerk:
      1.   Appointment And Term: Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
3.1-30-10, the village clerk, when authorized by the board, shall appoint one
deputy clerk. The deputy clerk shall serve until resignation, or revocation of
the appointment, or vacation of office by the appointing village clerk. Any
appointment, resignation or revocation of the appointment shall be in writing.
      2.   Powers And Duties:
         a.   The deputy clerk shall have the powers and duties set forth in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-95, as amended. (Ord. 206, 10-18-1982; amd.
2012 Code)
         b.   The powers and duties of deputy clerk shall be exercised only in
the absence of the village clerk from the place where the clerk's office is
maintained, and only when either written direction has been given by the clerk
to the deputy to exercise such powers, or the board of trustees has determined
by resolution that the clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to
perform such functions.
      3.   Provisions On File: One copy of each appointment, resignation, and
revocation of appointment, and one copy of each written direction from the
clerk to the deputy shall be maintained in the village files. (Ord. 206, 10-18-
1982)
1-6A-2: VILLAGE TREASURER:
   A.   Nature Of Job: The office of village treasurer is an executive office
of the village. The village treasurer is appointed by the village president
with the advice and consent of the village board. In the absence of the village
treasurer the village administrator can perform these duties.
   B.   Essential Job Duties: In addition to the duties now imposed upon this
office by law, or provided elsewhere in the ordinances of the village, the
village treasurer shall perform the following duties:
      1.   Be responsible for coordinating the preparation and publishing of
the annual treasurer's report.
      2.   Be responsible for coordinating and preparing the monthly treasurer
report.
      3.   Be responsible for the coordination and maintaining of all village
funds and issuing receipts.
      4.   Be responsible for the coordination of depositing all funds for the
village.
      5.   Assist in reconciling all village accounts.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Must be able to perform and/or manage multiple tasks, projects, and
priorities concurrently.
      2.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      3.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      4.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including village trustees and village president.
      5.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      6.   Will be responsible for providing information to appropriate village
committees and village board with the responsibility to attend appropriate
village meetings and committee meetings as required.
      7.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      8.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position, if the work is similar, related, or a logical
assignment to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Must have working knowledge of Microsoft Word/Excel and Adobe
Acrobat.
      3.   Must have bookkeeping or accounting experience.
      4.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      5.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
      6.   Must be bondable.
      7.   Employees are subject to random drug/alcohol screening.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   F.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village of Germantown Hills is an
equal opportunity employer. In compliance with the Americans with disabilities
act (ADA), the village will provide reasonable accommodations to qualified
individuals with disabilities and encourages both prospective and current
employees to discuss potential accommodations with the employer. Any essential
function or requirement of this position will be evaluated as necessary should
an incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to
a disability as defined by the Americans with disabilities act. Reasonable
accommodations for the specific disability will be made for the incumbent/
applicant when possible. (Ord. 732, 6-12-2014)
1-6A-3: ASSISTANTS TO CLERK AND TREASURER:
   A.   Appointments:
      1.   The village clerk is authorized to appoint a subordinate to be known
as the "assistant clerk" to work on an hourly basis, not exceeding thirty (30)
hours per week, at such compensation as the board of trustees shall establish
from time to time.
      2.   The village treasurer is authorized to appoint a subordinate to be
known as the "assistant treasurer" to work on an hourly basis, not exceeding
ten (10) hours per week, at such compensation as the board of trustees shall
establish from time to time.
   B.   May Be The Same Person: The assistant clerk and the assistant treasurer
may be, but are not required to be, the same person.
   C.   Responsibilities: The assistant clerk and the assistant treasurer shall
be responsible to the village clerk and the village treasurer, respectively,
and the village clerk and the village treasurer shall be responsible for the
fidelity of the assistant clerk and the assistant treasurer, respectively.
   D.   Terms Of Employment; Discharges: The assistant clerk and the assistant
treasurer shall be employed at the pleasure of the village clerk and the
village treasurer, respectively, and may be discharged from employment at any
time for any reason. Also, the assistant clerk or the assistant treasurer, as
the case may be, shall be discharged from employment if the board of trustees,
by ordinance, shall, in the future, revoke the authority granted by this
section.
   E.   Provisions On File: Any appointment authorized by this section, and any
resignation or revocation of appointment, shall be in writing. One copy of each
appointment, resignation or revocation of appointment shall be given to the
village president and maintained in the village files. (Ord. 307, 6-25-1992)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-6B-1: Office Created; Term
1-6B-2: Qualifications
1-6B-3: Appointment
1-6B-4: Oath And Bond
1-6B-5: Duties
1-6B-6: Compensation
1-6B-1: OFFICE CREATED; TERM:
There is created the office of village attorney, and the person appointed
village attorney shall hold his office from the time of his appointment to the
end of the fiscal year during which he is so appointed and until his successor
is appointed and qualified. (2012 Code)
1-6B-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The person appointed village attorney shall be an attorney at law duly licensed
to practice law in all courts of record in the county. In order to be eligible
to the office of village attorney, it shall not be necessary for such appointee
to be a qualified elector of the village nor a resident of the village;
provided, however, that no person shall be eligible to such office of village
attorney who is or has been a defaulter to the village. (2012 Code)
1-6B-3: APPOINTMENT:
The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall, at
the beginning or during each fiscal year, appoint a village attorney under the
provisions of this article. (2012 Code)
1-6B-4: OATH AND BOND:
Before the village attorney enters upon the duties of his office, he shall take
and subscribe the oath prescribed by law and shall execute a bond, payable to
the village, in the penal sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00), with sureties
to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned for the faithful
performance of the duties of his office and the payment of all monies received
by him and delivery of all properties received by him or coming into his
possession to the proper officers of the village according to law and the
ordinances of the village. (2012 Code)
1-6B-5: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the village attorney to be the legal advisor of all the
officers of the village and, when directed or requested by the proper officer
or officers of the village, to draw or pass upon all ordinances, leases, deeds,
contracts or other legal documents or papers pertaining to matters affecting
the village. He shall also, when directed or requested by the proper officer or
officers of the village, prosecute or defend, as the case may be, on behalf of
the village, all cases in which the village may, in any manner, be interested
or involved, and he shall do and render such other legal services as may be
required of him by the proper officer or officers of the village. (2012 Code)
1-6B-6: COMPENSATION:
The village attorney shall receive such compensation for his services as the
president and board of trustees shall fix, or in case there is no fixed
compensation, then such compensation as may, at the time of the rendition of
the services, be reasonable, usual and customary for like services in the
county. (2012 Code)
ARTICLE C. OTHER VILLAGE OFFICIALS
SECTION:
1-6C-1: Zoning Officer
1-6C-2: Planning And Zoning Secretary
1-6C-3: Village Administrator
1-6C-4: Assistant Bookkeeper
1-6C-5: Superintendent Of Public Works

1-6C-7: Public Works Maintenance Worker
