1-6C-1: ZONING OFFICER:
   A.   Appointment; Nature Of Job: The zoning officer is appointed by the
village president with the advice and consent of the village board. The zoning
officer shall administer and enforce the zoning laws of the village in
accordance with the provisions of the village zoning ordinance. In the absence
of the zoning officer, the superintendent of public works can perform these
duties.
   B.   Duties:
      1.   Review applications for and, if appropriate and in accordance with
the zoning title, issue zoning use permits and timely and periodically monitor
the status of issued permits to confirm compliance.
      2.   Review applications for, and if appropriate and in accordance with
the zoning title, issue zoning compliance certificates.
      3.   Maintain such records as are required to be kept thereby in
accordance with the zoning title.
      4.   Collect fees for the issuance of zoning use permits and the
processing of zoning applications, and promptly turn over all monies received
on behalf of the village to the village treasurer, and with such monies,
provide a statement as to the source thereof.
      5.   Review and act on zoning complaints or potential violations.
      6.   Attend to public inquiries about zoning regulations and provide
information regarding applicable regulations.
      7.   Complete administrative tickets on erosion, mailbox, and open
burning violations.
      8.   Review site plans submitted by property owners or developers.
      9.   Conduct field inspections when needed.
      10.   Send copies of building permits to the county assessment office.
      11.   Complete the building statistics survey monthly and submit.
      12.   Work with the village attorney on zoning violations, variances, and
special use requests.
      13.   Work with business owners regarding lighting, noise, signage,
parking, setbacks and other zoning requirements.
      14.   Schedule special use and variance hearings for the zoning board of
appeals and publish in a newspaper.
      15.   Communicate with architects, engineers, developers, property
owners, elected public officials, attorneys and other organizations on zoning
requests and issues.
      16.   Complete an annual listing of all zoning use permits issued.
      17.   Assign addresses to new homes and businesses.
      18.   Maintain zoning use permits for future reference.
      19.   Coordinate boundary map and plat approval process with the engineer
and plat officer.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Respond to village resident's, village trustees' and village
president's questions and comments in person or on the telephone with
information in a positive and polite manner.
      2.   Thorough knowledge of the village zoning ordinance.
      3.   Must be able to perform and/or manage multiple tasks, projects, and
priorities concurrently.
      4.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      5.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      6.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including the village trustees and the village president.
      7.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      8.   Be responsible for providing information to appropriate planning
commission, zoning board of appeals, village committees and village board with
the responsibility to attend village meetings and committee meetings as
required.
      9.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      10.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position if the work is similar, related, or a logical assignment
to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Knowledge and ability to read and understand zoning maps and
procedures.
      3.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      4.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
      5.   Must be bondable.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   F.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village is an equal opportunity
employer. In compliance with the Americans with disabilities act (ADA), the
village will provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with
disabilities and encourages both prospective and current employees to discuss
potential accommodations with the employer. Any essential function or
requirement of this position will be evaluated as necessary should an
incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to a
disability as defined by the Americans with disabilities act. Reasonable
accommodations for the specific disability will be made for the incumbent/
applicant when possible. (2012 Code)
1-6C-2: PLANNING AND ZONING SECRETARY:
   A.   Nature Of Job: The planning and zoning secretary shall be responsible
for the administrative coordination of the village planning commission and the
village zoning board of appeals.
   B.   Duties:
      1.   Publish notification of all hearings and meetings of the planning
commission and the zoning board of appeals in accordance with village
ordinances.
      2.   Attend meetings of the zoning board of appeals and planning
commission and take minutes of such meetings for approval by the respective
governmental bodies.
      3.   Facilitate communication between the planning commission and zoning
board of appeals and the village board.
      4.   Assign a representative to attend meetings and take minutes when
needed.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Must be able to perform and/or manage multiple tasks, projects, and
priorities concurrently.
      2.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      3.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      4.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including the village trustees and the village president.
      5.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      6.   Be responsible for providing information to appropriate planning
commission, zoning board of appeals, village committees and village board with
the responsibility to attend appropriate village meetings and committee
meetings as required.
      7.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      8.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position if the work is similar, related, or a logical assignment
to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Computer experience.
      3.   Must have working knowledge of Microsoft Word/Excel and Adobe
Acrobat.
      4.   Must be available to attend planning and zoning committee meetings.
      5.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      6.   Employees are subject to random drug/alcohol screening.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   F.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village is an equal opportunity
employer. In compliance with the Americans with disabilities act (ADA), the
village will provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with
disabilities and encourages both prospective and current employees to discuss
potential accommodations with the employer. Any essential function or
requirement of this position will be evaluated as necessary should an
incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to a
disability as defined by the Americans with disabilities act. Reasonable
accommodations for the specific disability will be made for the incumbent/
applicant when possible. (2012 Code)
1-6C-3: VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
   A.   Nature Of Job; Vacancy: The village administrator is a full time
employee of the village of Germantown Hills and is the person designated by the
village board to be responsible for the day to day administrative operations of
the village as assigned by and under the direction of the village board. The
village administrator is responsible for the efficient and effective operation
of services provided by the village. In the absence of the village
administrator the superintendent of public works will coordinate these duties.
   B.   Essential Job Duties:
      1.   Maintain files for all village records, correspondence, and general
information other than those that are required to be maintained or are
maintained by the village clerk.
      2.   Maintain confidential files of those deemed necessary by the village
president and village board and assume responsibility for the content of those
files and the security of those files. This will include all confidential
materials and correspondence.
      3.   Maintain sufficient office supplies for the village operations.
      4.   Keep strict, accurate and detailed records of all employment matters
as required by the village personnel policy.
      5.   Receive payroll reports, check calculation of time worked, prepare
payroll and break down payroll expenditures to the respective funds for each
payroll.
      6.   Prepare all federal income tax, social security contributions, and
state withholding forms and requirements and ensure that all appropriate
payments are sent electronically via the internet before due date.
      7.   On a monthly basis, prepare checks for signatures of the designated
officials.
      8.   Prepare state and federal tax forms (W-2 and 1099) and deliver to
employees and vendors prior to January 31 of each year.
      9.   Prepare the necessary transmittals and reports for the year end (W-
2, W-3, 1096 and 1099 forms) to the federal and state agencies by February 28
of each year.
      10.   Together with the finance committee, shall submit to the board a
report of budget estimates of monies necessary to defray the expenses of the
village during the fiscal year for which the appropriations are to be made.
This report shall include other information deemed necessary so that the board
may fully understand the financial necessities of the current year.
      11.   Without delay, deliver to the officers of the village and to all
committees of the board, all resolutions and communications referred to such
officers or committees by the village board.
      12.   Perform other general office duties such as filing, typing,
preparation of board materials, and other duties essential to the operation of
the village office, including covering the functions for telephone answering,
receiving payments for village services, etc.
      13.   Receive and send e-mails from all boards, village residents and
employees.
      14.   Communicates with the village president and the village board to
advise of project status, accomplishments and when needed prepare written
reports.
      15.   Track trustee, planning commission and ZBA terms of office.
      16.   Receives resident's suggestions and complaints and works toward
acceptable solutions with the president, trustees and committees if required.
      17.   Coordinate varied issues with surrounding cities and villages,
Woodford County and assorted state agencies.
      18.   Schedule use of the community center.
      19.   Attend seminars, meetings and training in order to stay updated to
the latest techniques, procedures and regulations.
      20.   Update website as needed.
      21.   Assist with the updating of the village's comprehensive plan.
      22.   Serve as the general supervisor of the village clerk's office and
coordinates the duties of the superintendent of public works in his absence.
      23.   Assist the personnel committee in the performance evaluation of the
village staff.
      24.   Assist village president/village board in the evaluation of
professional services.
      25.   Determine work projects as well as work schedules when needed in
coordination with the superintendent of public works, or in the absence of the
superintendent of public works.
      26.   In the absence of the superintendent of public works, coordinate
daily jobs and job schedules of public works maintenance workers in conjunction
with the public works team lead maintenance worker.
      27.   Coordinate and prepare the pager and holiday rotation schedule for
the year with the superintendent of public works.
      28.   Complete NPDES annual fiscal report.
      29.   Work with the village attorney regarding compliance with the open
meetings act and proper responses to the freedom of information act requests.
      30.   Complete the Illinois department of revenue central registration
forms for new and discontinued businesses.
      31.   Certify annual list of businesses.
      32.   Certify and approve the tax rate computation from Woodford County.
      33.   Complete certification of tax exempt status for business requests.
      34.   Prepare and certify the list of all board members and employees to
the Woodford County clerk for the statement of economic interest requirements.
      35.   Prepare application for grants.
      36.   Assist in the MFT process with the required forms and
certifications.
      37.   Coordinate census process with completion of census payrolls and
mileage reimbursements.
      38.   Update census maps and address list verification along with
annexation information.
      39.   Coordinate annual audit along with completion of audit assessment
forms.
      40.   Prepare financial reports and close out month ends.
      41.   Assist in IDOT audit.
      42.   Complete fiscal year end grinder pump transfers.
      43.   Prepare annual sewer rate information and work with finance and
sewer committees for recommendation to sewer committee.
      44.   Complete detailed sewer rate process.
      45.   Communicate garbage exemptions to board for approval and work with
McCullough Disposal on garbage customers and recycling toters.
      46.   Be responsible for providing information to appropriate village
committees and village board with the responsibility to attend appropriate
village meetings and committee meetings as required.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Responds to village resident's, village trustees' and village
president's questions and comments in person or on the telephone with
information in a positive and polite manner.
      2.   Must be able to perform and/or manage multiple tasks, projects, and
priorities concurrently.
      3.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      4.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      5.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including village trustees and village president.
      6.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      7.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      8.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position, if the work is similar, related, or a logical
assignment to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Supervisor experience required.
      3.   Computer experience.
      4.   Must have working knowledge of Microsoft Word/Excel and Adobe
Acrobat.
      5.   Must be available to attend village board, special and committee
meetings.
      6.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      7.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
      8.   Must be bondable.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   F.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village of Germantown Hills is an
equal opportunity employer. In compliance with the Americans with disabilities
act (ADA), the village will provide reasonable accommodations to qualified
individuals with disabilities and encourages both prospective and current
employees to discuss potential accommodations with the employer. Any essential
function or requirement of this position will be evaluated as necessary should
an incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to
a disability as defined by the Americans with disabilities act. Reasonable
accommodations for the specific disability will be made for the incumbent/
applicant when possible. (Ord. 756, 11-19-2015)
1-6C-4: ASSISTANT BOOKKEEPER:
   A.   Nature Of Job; Vacancy: The assistant bookkeeper is an employee of the
village of Germantown Hills and is the person designated by the village board
to be responsible to support the village administrator and operations of the
village as assigned by and under the direction of the village board. The
assistant bookkeeper is responsible for supporting the efficient and effective
operation of services provided by the village. The assistant bookkeeper reports
to the village administrator. In the absence of the assistant bookkeeper the
village administrator can perform these duties.
   B.   Essential Job Duties:
      1.   Responsible for maintaining records for sewer and grinder alarms.
      2.   Responsible for preparing sewer and garbage bills to residents.
      3.   Receives payments from village residents for garbage and sewer.
      4.   Responsible for maintaining the sewer and garbage accounts tracking
residents moving in and out of the village.
      5.   Send delinquency and disconnection notices and filing and releasing
of liens.
      6.   Attend village board/committee meetings when requested or in the
absence of the village clerk. The assistant bookkeeper will attend, record and
electronically record executive session meetings when required.
      7.   Serve as backup to the village clerk/village administrator for any
and all of the duties.
      8.   Maintain official village files and records in the village clerk's
absence.
      9.   Maintain confidential files of those deemed necessary by the village
president and village board and assume responsibility for the content of those
files and the security of those files. This will include all confidential
materials and correspondence.
      10.   Keep strict, accurate and detailed records of all employment
matters as required by the village personnel policy.
      11.   Be responsible for providing information to appropriate village
committees and village board with the responsibility to attend appropriate
village meetings and committee meetings as required.
   C.   Job Requirements:

priorities concurrently.
      2.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      3.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      4.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including village trustees and village president.
      5.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      6.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      7.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position, if the work is similar, related, or a logical
assignment to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Office and bookkeeping experience.
      3.   Must have working knowledge of Microsoft Word/Excel and Adobe
Acrobat.
      4.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      5.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
      6.   Must be bondable.
      7.   Employees are subject to random drug/alcohol screening.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as

is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.

1-6C-5: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
   A.   Nature Of Job; Vacancy:
      1.   Directs and oversees all aspects of the public works department and
sanitary treatment and collection system. The superintendent of public works
shall plan, organize, implement and supervise activities related to the
sanitary sewer system, village streets and rights of way, parks, stormwater
system, buildings, properties and grounds maintenance. Works under the
direction of the village president/village board who gives guidance regarding
village policy and procedures.
      2.   Responsible for supervising the maintenance of village streets,
rights of way, vehicles and equipment, plus the maintenance and construction of
utilities and other village infrastructure with some participation when needed.
Work includes responsibilities for ensuring the proper materials, tools and
equipment at work sites and performing in accordance with safety regulations.
Supervise work through delegation to the public works team lead maintenance
worker, observation, conferences and reports. The ability to take the
initiative to complete jobs with pride and communicate the presence of a task
that needs to be completed or take the initiative to complete it themselves.
      3.   Oversees the job completion and job performance of public works
maintenance workers and public works team lead maintenance worker, including
daily communication with the public works team lead maintenance worker for
purposes of scheduling daily job assignments, review of daily job assignment
progress and proper job completion, and discussion of performance and
disciplinary matters.
      4.   In the absence of the superintendent of public works the village
administrator will coordinate these duties.
   B.   Essential Job Duties:
      1.   Supervises and schedules work for public works maintenance workers
in coordination with the public works team lead maintenance worker, and meets
with the public works team lead maintenance worker daily for regular job
assignments.
      2.   Assist the personnel committee in the performance evaluation of
applicable village staff.
      3.   Assist village president/village board in the evaluation of
professional services.
      4.   Supervises and schedules maintenance personnel for the plowing of
snow and dispensing of salt and cinders/sand and participates when needed.
      5.   Causes plans for public works projects to be reviewed, reviews
preliminary plans, updates standards and specifications.
      6.   Makes field design decisions regarding maintenance work on village
structures, wastewater facilities, and parks.
      7.   Works with all committees to prepare annual budgets and determine
resource needs.
      8.   Maintains stockpiles of materials and supplies necessary for public
works responsibilities.
      9.   Controls and oversees the purchasing of materials and equipment
necessary for public works as defined by the village board and finance
committee.
      10.   Oversees independent contractors performing work for the village.
      11.   Works with the village engineer and village attorney to develop
specifications and bid documents for a variety of public works and utility
related designs, construction and maintenance projects; recommends contract
awards, negotiates contract provisions and coordinates, reviews and approves
contractor's performance.
      12.   Prepares reports, analyses, and recommendations for public works
projects.
      13.   Ensures that water, street, stormwater and wastewater systems are
operated in compliance with village, state and federal laws.
      14.   Possesses knowledge of safety principles and practices.
      15.   Investigates, interacts and responds to complaints and concerns by
the public.
      16.   Takes disciplinary action, up to and including termination, to
address performance deficiencies, in accordance with the village's personnel
policy.
      17.   Reviews plans submitted by independent contractors with the village
engineer.
      18.   Reviews plans and monitors developments related to public works and
utility matters and evaluate their impact on the village.
      19.   Represents the village with other governmental agencies on a wide
variety of issues pertaining to public works and utilities.
      20.   Works with developers and builders regarding development matters
including plan review and determining infrastructure needs.
      21.   Recommends updates and revisions of ordinances, policies and
procedures.
      22.   Supervises the operation of village equipment associated with
street maintenance, including the backhoe, trucks and other equipment.
      23.   Supervises the repairs and maintenance of village buildings, parks
and grounds.
      24.   Supervises the maintenance of the sewer collection system, which
includes lift stations, grinder pumps, etc., including testing and readings as
required by the EPA.
      25.   Coordinates light duty work programs in conjunction with the
Illinois municipal risk management coordinator.
      26.   Coordinate the safety and loss control activities of the village.
      27.   Recommend and advise on proposed policies and procedures, which
will help promote safety and minimize liability. Work with Illinois municipal
risk management coordinator in order to minimize village costs and liabilities.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Responds to village resident's, village trustees' and village
president's questions and comments in person or on the telephone with
information in a positive and polite manner.
      2.   Thorough knowledge of street construction and maintenance, sewer
system operation and maintenance, parks and grounds maintenance, and building
maintenance.
      3.   Must be able to perform and/or manage multiple tasks, projects, and
priorities concurrently.
      4.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      5.   Knowledge of the materials, methods and practices used in vehicle
maintenance repair.
      6.   Knowledge of safety principles and practices.
      7.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      8.   Ability to lift and carry heavy objects up to one hundred (100)
pounds.
      9.   Knowledge of the principles and practices of wastewater treatment.
      10.   Ability to function as a work team lead member through effective
communication including village trustees and village president.
      11.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      12.   Will be responsible for providing information to appropriate
village committees and village board with the responsibility to attend
appropriate village meetings and committee meetings as required.
      13.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      14.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position, if the work is similar, related, or a logical
assignment to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Possession of a valid Illinois state CDL license. The village board
may approve an exemption.
      3.   Supervisor experience required.
      4.   Must be available for after hour emergencies.
      5.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      6.   Employees are subject to random drug/alcohol screening.
      7.   Must be available to attend the village board, special and committee
meetings.
      8.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   F.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village of Germantown Hills is an
equal opportunity employer. In compliance with the Americans with disabilities
act (ADA), the village will provide reasonable accommodations to qualified
individuals with disabilities and encourages both prospective and current
employees to discuss potential accommodations with the employer. Any essential
function or requirement of this position will be evaluated as necessary should
an incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to
a disability as defined by the Americans with disabilities act. Reasonable
accommodations for the specific disability will be made for the incumbent/
applicant when possible. (Ord. 754, 11-19-2015)
1-6C-6: CHIEF WASTEWATER OPERATOR:
   A.   Nature Of Job; Vacancy:
      1.   Direct and oversee all aspects of the sanitary treatment and
collection system. Work with the superintendent of public works to plan,
organize, implement and supervise activities related to the sanitary sewer
system. Work under the direction of the superintendent of public works who
gives guidance regarding village policy and procedures.
      2.   Responsible for working with the superintendent of public works in
the maintenance and operation of the village sanitary sewer system. Work
includes responsibilities for ensuring the proper materials, tools and
equipment are at work sites and performing in accordance with safety
regulations. The ability to take the initiative to complete jobs with pride and
communicate the presence of a task that needs to be completed or take the
initiative to complete it himself. Take necessary training courses and seminars
in order to stay updated to the latest techniques, procedures and regulations.
      3.   In the absence of the chief wastewater operator, the superintendent
of public works will coordinate duties.
   B.   Duties:
      1.   Perform the maintenance and repair of the sewer collection system,
which includes lift stations, grinder pumps, etc., including testing and
readings as required by the EPA under the direction of the superintendent of
public works.
      2.   Monitor the performance of all equipment, gauges, and charts in the
treatment plant and pump stations.
      3.   Record statistical data concerning plant operations.
      4.   Operate, maintain and repair malfunctions at the wastewater
treatment plant.
      5.   Chart lab test results for trend analysis and maintain accurate
results for analysis and test results.
      6.   Collect samples and identify concentrations of chemical, physical or
biological characteristics of wastewater required in accordance with local,
state and federal requirements.
      7.   Gather and test wastewater samples for plant efficiency reports as
required in accordance with local, state and federal requirements.
      8.   Perform quality control tests on lab equipment and lab analysis.
      9.   Evaluate procedures and results for accuracy and determine
appropriate methods.
      10.   Assure the plant operates in required standards.
      11.   Train other personnel on acceptable operations/lab methods and
procedures to assure accuracy of operations and test results.
      12.   Maintain drawings and schematics of the collection system,
electrical and other systems in the treatment facilities and collection system.
      13.   Attend the sewer committee meetings as requested.
      14.   Assigned to work with the village engineer on the treatment
facility and collection system.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Respond to village resident's and superintendent of public works'
questions and comments in person or on the telephone with information in a
positive and polite manner.
      2.   Thorough knowledge of the sewer system operation and maintenance.
      3.   Must be able to perform and/or manage multiple tasks, projects, and
priorities concurrently.
      4.   Must be efficient, a self-starter, an independent worker, a detail
person, and possess good work habits.
      5.   Knowledge of safety principles and practices.
      6.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      7.   Ability to lift and carry heavy objects up to one hundred (100)
pounds.
      8.   Knowledge of the principles and practices of wastewater treatment.
      9.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including the village trustees and the village president.
      10.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      11.   Be responsible for providing information to appropriate village
committees and the village board with the responsibility to attend appropriate
village meetings and committee meetings as required.
      12.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      13.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position if the work is similar, related, or a logical assignment
to the position.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent.
      2.   Must have a valid Illinois class professional wastewater operator's
license.
      3.   Possession of a valid Illinois state CDL license. The village board
may approve an exemption.
      4.   Must be available for after hour emergencies.
      5.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      6.   Employees are subject to random drug/alcohol screening.
      7.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
   E.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   F.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village is an equal opportunity
employer. In compliance with the Americans with disabilities act (ADA), the
village will provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with
disabilities and encourage both prospective and current employees to discuss
potential accommodations with the employer. Any essential function or
requirement of this position will be evaluated as necessary should an
incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to a
disability as defined by the Americans with disabilities act. Reasonable
accommodations for the specific disability will be made for the incumbent/
applicant when possible. (2012 Code)
1-6C-6-1: PUBLIC WORKS TEAM LEAD MAINTENANCE WORKER:
   A.   Nature Of Job:
      1.   Individuals in this position provide a variety of maintenance,
repair and construction tasks for the village, in all areas of village
responsibility, and under the supervision of the superintendent of public
works, who assigns work and evaluates employees in the position. In the absence
of the superintendent of public works the village administrator will coordinate
these duties. In addition to the duties of a public works maintenance worker,
the team lead maintenance worker under supervision from the superintendent of
public works, or village administrator in the superintendent of public works'
absence, is responsible to team lead a crew of public works maintenance workers
in performing maintenance, repair and construction tasks for the village. (Ord.
751, 10-29-2015)
      2.   Responsible for participating in the maintenance of village streets,
rights of way, vehicles and equipment, plus the maintenance and construction of
utilities and other village infrastructure. Work includes responsibilities for
ensuring the proper materials, tools and equipment at work sites and performing
in accordance with safety regulations. Work is performed under the direction of
the superintendent of public works and is reviewed through observation,
conferences and reports. The ability to take the initiative to complete jobs
with pride and communicate the presence of a task that needs to be completed or
take the initiative to complete it themselves. The ability to receive direction
from supervisors and oversee completion of jobs in accordance with said
direction, assume responsibility for the timely and proper completion of jobs
and report to supervisors regarding job progress, and provide general input
regarding employee performance, and/or employee disciplinary matters. The
public works team lead maintenance worker differs from the public works
maintenance worker position in level of responsibility. This is a working level
team lead position. The public works team lead maintenance worker does not
directly supervise public works maintenance workers but may provide direction,
establish priorities, assign tasks, coordinate work projects of the public
works maintenance workers, while fully participating in work projects as
assigned by supervisors. (Ord. 761, 3-24-2016)
   B.   Essential Job Duties: Typical duties include, but are not limited to,
the following:
      1.   Performs manual labor associated with the maintenance, rebuilding,
new construction, and the drainage of streets, roads and bridges/culverts.
Utilizes whatever tools are available and proper for work assigned.
      2.   Plows snow and dispenses salt and cinders/sand.
      3.   Operates equipment associated with street maintenance, including the
backhoe, trucks and other equipment.
      4.   Performs basic equipment maintenance; purchase parts or supplies
necessary for maintenance up to a specific amount.
      5.   Repairs and maintains village buildings and grounds. Mows grass,
weeds, and trims. Maintains building and work areas to be clean, safe and
organized. Remove trash from buildings including main office as assigned on a
regular basis.
      6.   Keep the shop/restrooms safe, clean, and organized on a regular
basis at least weekly.
      7.   Assists the superintendent of public works in the operation of the
wastewater treatment plants, performing tasks as assigned, regular and
reoccurring duties, regular testing maintenance, cleaning, rebuilding of unit
and parts, installations and the operating of specific equipment.
      8.   Maintains sewer collections system, which includes lift stations,
grinder pumps, etc.; performs repairs and replacements as needed; does testing
and readings as assigned.
      9.   Performs JULIE locates for collection system under the direction of
JULIE coordinator and/or superintendent of public works.
      10.   Keep the sewer plant safe, clean and organized on a regular basis
at least weekly.
      11.   Maintains parks, playgrounds, greenways, public easements, and
drainageways.
      12.   Repairs and cleans playground equipment.
      13.   Replacement of playground equipment.
      14.   Receive direction from supervisors and oversee completion of jobs
in accordance with said directions.
      15.   Responsible for the timely and proper completion of jobs and
reporting to supervisors regarding job progress.
      16.   Report to supervisors regarding job progress, employee performance,
and/or employee disciplinary matters.
   C.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Responds to village resident's, supervisor's, village trustees' and
village president's questions and comments in person or on the telephone with
information in a positive and polite manner.
      2.   Considerable knowledge of the tools, materials, methods and
procedures used in street maintenance and repair.
      3.   Knowledge of the materials, methods and practices used in vehicle
maintenance repair.
      4.   Knowledge of safety principles and practices.
      5.   Some knowledge of basic mechanical repair skills in order to make
repairs to vehicles and equipment.
      6.   Ability to participate in a variety of semiskilled street
maintenance and repair assignments.
      7.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      8.   Ability to lift and carry heavy objects up to one hundred (100)
pounds.
      9.   Ability to perform manual labor work for extended periods under
adverse environmental conditions including, but not limited to, extended
periods of time of walking, standing, shoveling, bending, etc.
      10.   Skill in the operation of hand and power tools.
      11.   Skill in the safe and efficient operation of motorized equipment
under hazardous and emergency conditions.
      12.   Knowledge of the principles and practices of wastewater treatment.
      13.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including supervisor, village trustees and village president.
      14.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      15.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      16.   Ability to supervise and coordinate daily activities of public
works maintenance workers.
      17.   Ability to communicate with supervisors, receive and carry out
directions and instructions and report to supervisors on a daily basis.
      18.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
   D.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent. The village board may approve an
exemption.
      2.   Must obtain a class 4 wastewater operator Illinois license within
three (3) years of employment. This may be extended upon village board
approval.
      3.   Possession of a valid Illinois state CDL license. The village board
may approve an exemption.
      4.   Required to be on a pager rotation call.
      5.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      6.   Employees are subject to random drug/alcohol screening.
      7.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
   E.   Interpretation:

between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.

1-6C-7: PUBLIC WORKS MAINTENANCE WORKER:
   A.   Nature Of Job: Individuals in this position provide a variety of
maintenance, repair and construction tasks for the village, in all areas of
village responsibility, and under the supervision of the superintendent of
public works, who assigns work and evaluates employees in the position. In the
absence of the superintendent of public works the village administrator will
coordinate these duties. In addition, individuals in this position accept
direction, prioritization, task assignments and work project coordination from
the public works team lead maintenance worker. (Ord. 755, 11-19-2015)
   B.   Distinguishing Characteristics: Responsible for participating in the
maintenance of village streets, rights of way, vehicles and equipment, plus the
maintenance and construction of utilities and other village infrastructure.
Work includes responsibilities for ensuring the proper materials, tools and
equipment at work sites and performing in accordance with safety regulations.
Work is performed under the direction of the superintendent of public works and
is reviewed through observation, conferences and reports. The ability to take
the initiative to complete jobs with pride and communicate the presence of a
task that needs to be completed or take the initiative to complete it
themselves. (Ord. 762, 3-24-2016)
   C.   Essential Job Duties: Typical duties include, but are not limited to,
the following:
      1.   Performs manual labor associated with the maintenance, rebuilding,
new construction, and the drainage of streets, roads and bridges/culverts.
Utilizes whatever tools are available and proper for work assigned.
      2.   Plows snow and dispenses salt and cinders/sand.
      3.   Operates equipment associated with street maintenance, including the
backhoe, trucks and other equipment.
      4.   Performs basic equipment maintenance; purchase parts or supplies
necessary for maintenance up to a specific amount.
      5.   Repairs and maintains village buildings and grounds. Mows grass,
weeds, and trims. Maintains building and work areas to be clean, safe and
organized. Remove trash from buildings including main office as assigned on a
regular basis.
      6.   Keep the shop/restrooms safe, clean, and organized on a regular
basis at least weekly.
      7.   Assists the superintendent of public works in the operation of the
wastewater treatment plants, performing tasks as assigned, regular and
reoccurring duties, regular testing maintenance, cleaning, rebuilding of unit
and parts, installations and the operating of specific equipment.
      8.   Maintains the sewer collections system, which includes lift
stations, grinder pumps, etc.; performs repairs and replacements as needed;
does testing and readings as assigned.
      9.   Performs JULIE locates for the collection system under the direction
of JULIE coordinator and/or superintendent of public works.
      10.   Keep the sewer plant safe, clean and organized on a regular basis
at least weekly.
      11.   Maintains parks, playgrounds, greenways, public easements, and
drainageways.
      12.   Repairs and cleans playground equipment.
      13.   Replacement of playground equipment.
   D.   Job Requirements:
      1.   Responds to village resident's, supervisor's, village trustees' and
village president's questions and comments in person or on the telephone with
information in a positive and polite manner.
      2.   Considerable knowledge of the tools, materials, methods and
procedures used in street maintenance and repair.
      3.   Knowledge of the materials, methods and practices used in vehicle
maintenance repair.
      4.   Knowledge of safety principles and practices.
      5.   Some knowledge of basic mechanical repair skills in order to make
repairs to vehicles and equipment.
      6.   Ability to participate in a variety of semiskilled street
maintenance and repair assignments.
      7.   Ability to follow oral and written instructions.
      8.   Ability to lift and carry heavy objects up to one hundred (100)
pounds.
      9.   Ability to perform manual labor work for extended periods under
adverse environmental conditions including, but not limited to, extended
periods of time of walking, standing, shoveling, bending, etc.
      10.   Skill in the operation of hand and power tools.
      11.   Skill in the safe and efficient operation of motorized equipment
under hazardous and emergency conditions.
      12.   Knowledge of the principles and practices of wastewater treatment.
      13.   Ability to function as a work team member through effective
communication including supervisor, village trustees and village president.
      14.   Ability to perform village functions and services with priority and
loyalty to the village.
      15.   Ability to accept direction, prioritization, task assignments and
work project coordination from the public works team lead maintenance worker.
      16.   Must maintain proper personal hygiene and a proper and professional
appearance.
      17.   Ability to assume additional duties or responsibilities as may be
required by circumstances, emergencies or other situations.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific duties does not exclude
them from the position, if the work is similar, related, or a logical
assignment to the position.
   E.   Qualifications:
      1.   High school diploma or equivalent. The village board may approve an
exemption.
      2.   Must obtain a class 4 wastewater operator Illinois license within
three (3) years of employment. This may be extended upon village board
approval.
      3.   Possession of a valid Illinois state CDL license. The village board
may approve an exemption.
      4.   Required to be on a pager rotation call.
      5.   Applicants are subject to a preemployment physical and drug
screening.
      6.   Employees are subject to random drug/alcohol screening.
      7.   Must agree to a preemployment background check.
   F.   Interpretation:
      1.   This job description does not constitute an employment agreement
between the employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as
the needs of the employer and requirements of the job change.
      2.   This job description should not be interpreted as all inclusive. It
is intended to identify the essential functions and requirements of this job.
Incumbents/applicants may be requested to perform job related responsibilities
and tasks other than those stated in this section.
   G.   Village Compliance With ADA: The village of Germantown Hills is an

an incumbent/applicant be unable to perform the function or requirement due to

CHAPTER 7
ETHICS
SECTION:
1-7-1: State Regulations Adopted
1-7-2: Definitions
1-7-3: Interpretation
1-7-4: Prohibited Acts
1-7-5: Penalties
1-7-6: Amendments
1-7-7: Unconstitutionality Of Provisions
1-7-1: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The regulations of section 5-15 1  and article 10 2  of the state officials and
employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter
referred to as the "act" in this chapter), are hereby adopted by reference and
made applicable to the officers and employees of the village to the extent
required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5. (Ord. 528, 5-20-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 430/5-15.
2 2. 5 ILCS 430/10-10 - 430/10-40.
1-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be
defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c). (Ord. 528, 5-
20-2004)
1-7-3: INTERPRETATION:
Other than ordinance 432, this chapter does not repeal or otherwise amend or
modify any existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of
village officers and employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances
or policies are less restrictive than this chapter, however, the provisions of
this chapter shall prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a). (Ord. 528, 5-20-2004)
1-7-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Gifts:
      1.   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited
or accepted under the act by an officer or any employee of the village is
hereby prohibited.
      2.   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to
an officer or employee of the village under the act is hereby prohibited.
   B.   Political Activities: The participation in political activities
prohibited under the act by any officer or employee of the village is hereby
prohibited. (Ord. 528, 5-20-2004)
1-7-5: PENALTIES:
The penalties for violations of this chapter shall be the same as those
penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar
violations of the act. (Ord. 528, 5-20-2004)
1-7-6: AMENDMENTS:
Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date hereof
shall be incorporated into this chapter by reference and shall be applicable to
the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited
political activities. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional
for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this chapter by
reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village.
(Ord. 528, 5-20-2004)
1-7-7: UNCONSTITUTIONALITY OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its
entirety, then this chapter shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois
supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This chapter shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the corporate authorities of the village if the act is found unconstitutional
by the Illinois supreme court.
   B.   If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional
but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act or does not
address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted by
this chapter shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this
chapter relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed
repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village.
(Ord. 528, 5-20-2004)
CHAPTER 8
PUBLIC RECORDS; VILLAGE DIRECTORY
SECTION:
1-8-1: Requests For Public Records; State Regulations Adopted
1-8-2: Village Directory
1-8-3: Display And Availability Of Provisions
1-8-1: REQUESTS FOR PUBLIC RECORDS; STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The Illinois freedom of information act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/1 et
seq., as may from time to time be amended, is hereby adopted by reference and
shall govern the village responses to requests for public records. (2012 Code)
1-8-2: VILLAGE DIRECTORY:
The village clerk shall prepare and keep current a village directory setting
forth a brief statement of the purpose of the village government, a block
diagram giving its functional subdivisions, the total amount of its operating
budget, the location of its office, the approximate number of full and part
time employees, and the identification and membership of its boards and
commissions. (Ord. 228, 6-20-1984)
1-8-3: DISPLAY AND AVAILABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
Copies of the village directory set forth in section
1-8-2 of this chapter and the public records provisions of section
1-8-1 of this chapter shall be prominently displayed at the village hall, shall
be made available for inspection and copying without charge, and shall be
mailed upon request. (Ord. 228, 6-20-1984)
CHAPTER 9
VILLAGE TAXES
SECTION:
1-9-1: Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax
1-9-2: Municipal Service Occupation Tax
1-9-3: Municipal Cannabis Retailers’ Occupation Tax
1-9-1: MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate; Exemptions: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons
engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in the
village at the rate of one percent (1%) of the gross receipts from such sales
made in the course of such business while this section is in effect, in
accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-1.6 of the Illinois municipal
code; except, that this tax shall not be imposed on the sales of food for human
consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other
than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food that has been prepared for
immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs,
medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles
used by diabetics.
   B.   Monthly Returns Required: Every such person engaged in such business in
the village shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the
report to the state department of revenue required by section 3 of the
retailers' occupation tax act 1 .
   C.   Payment Of Tax: At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid
to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account
of the receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding
month. (2012 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 120/3.
1-9-2: MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate; Exemptions: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons
engaged in the village in the business of making sales of service at the rate
of one percent (1%) of the cost price of all tangible personal property
transferred by said servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property
or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service, in
accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-1.7 of the Illinois municipal
code; except, that this tax shall not be imposed on the sales of food for human
consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other
than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food that has been prepared for
immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs,
medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles
used by diabetics.
   B.   Monthly Return Required: Every supplier or serviceman required to
account for municipal service occupation tax for the benefit of the village
shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the
state department of revenue required by section 9 of the service occupation tax
act 1 .
   C.   Payment Of Tax: At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid
to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account
of the receipts from transfers of tangible personal property or real estate
incident to a sale of service during the preceding month. (2012 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 115/9.
1-9-3: MUNICIPAL CANNABIS RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate:
      1.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling cannabis, other than cannabis purchased under the Compassionate Use of
Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act, at retail in the village at the rate of
three percent (3%) of the gross receipts from these sales made in the course of
that business.
      2.   The imposition of this tax is in accordance with the provisions of
Illinois Municipal Cannabis Retailers’ Occupation Tax Law, as set forth in
Sections 8-11-22 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-22), as the
same may be amended from time to time.
   B.   Collection Of Tax By Retailers:
      1.   The tax imposed by this section shall be remitted by such retailer
to the Illinois Department of Revenue (“Department”). Any tax required to be
collected pursuant to or as authorized by this section and any such tax
collected by such retailer and required to be remitted to the department shall
constitute a debt owed by the retailer to the State. Retailers may reimburse
themselves for their seller’s tax liability hereunder by separately stating
that tax as an additional charge, which charge may be stated in combination, in
a single amount, with any State tax that sellers are required to collect.
      2.   The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be
assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the
department. The department shall have full power to administer and enforce the
provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-11-22 and the provisions of this section. (Ord. 817,
9-19-2019)
CHAPTER 10
BIDDING REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
1-10-1: Contracts For Public Improvements
1-10-2: Responsible Bidder
1-10-3: Public Improvements Definition
1-10-4: Emergency Purchases; Report Required
1-10-1: CONTRACTS FOR PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
Any contract for public improvements anticipated to cost more than twenty five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall be awarded in the following manner: (Ord.
718, 6-27-2013; amd. Ord. 729, 1-24-2014; Ord. 789, 9-26-2017)
   A.   In accordance with any procedure authorized or required by applicable
State or Federal law; or
   B.   Unless otherwise prohibited by law, pursuant to a solicitation for bids
advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village. Any such
solicitation shall include a general description of the supplies, materials,
equipment, work or services sought by the Village, shall state where
specifications and all related documentation may be secured, the time and place
for opening bids and such other information as the Village Board deems
appropriate.
All such contracts shall be awarded by the Village Board to the lowest
responsible bidder whose bid is determined to serve the best interest of the
Village, taking into consideration the quality of the articles or services to
be supplied, or the work to be performed, conformity with specifications,
price, delivery terms, the service reputation of the vendor or contractor and
such other factors as the Village Board deems appropriate. Any other provisions
of this chapter or this Code to the contrary notwithstanding (and except as
otherwise required by State or Federal law), the Village Board may by ordinance
or resolution adopted by an affirmative vote of four (4) of the Trustees enter
into any contract without the solicitation of bids or quotations, with an
entity that meets the "responsible bidder" criteria described in section
1-10-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 718, 6-27-2013)
1-10-2: RESPONSIBLE BIDDER:
With respect to construction projects of more than twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) involving the construction of new facilities, the renovation of
current facilities or road construction, the term "responsible bidder" means a
bidder who is capable of meeting all of the specifications for the construction
project, who meets the following criteria and who submits evidence satisfactory
to the Village that the bidder meets such criteria: (Ord. 718, 6-27-2013; amd.
Ord. 752, 10-29-2015; Ord. 789, 9-26-2017)
   A.   The bidder is in compliance with all applicable laws prerequisite to
doing business in the State of Illinois;
   B.   The bidder has obtained a Federal employer tax identification number
or, in the case of an individual contractor, a social security number;
   C.   The bidder is in compliance with the equal opportunity employer
provisions of section 2000(e) of chapter 21, title 42 of the United States Code
and Federal executive order no. 11246 as amended by Federal executive order no.
11375;
   D.   The bidder provides certificates of insurance demonstrating that the
bidder has obtained the following forms of insurance coverage which will be
effective during the term of the construction project:
         Comprehensive general liability;
         Workers' compensation;
         Completed operations;
         Motor vehicle;
         Hazardous occupation; and
         Where appropriate, products liability.
   E.   The bidder is in compliance with all provisions of the Illinois
Prevailing Wage Act and pays wages, and provides or pays for medical and
hospitalization insurance and retirement for those trades covered by the
Prevailing Wage Act in the amounts determined in accordance with the Prevailing
Wage Act. All such bidders awarded a contract for a construction project and
their subcontractors shall provide certified payrolls to the Village in
accordance with the provisions of the Prevailing Wage Act; and
   F.   The bidder and all subcontractors performing work on the construction
project must participate in an active apprenticeship and training program
approved and registered with the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of
Apprenticeship and Training for each trade which performs work on the
construction project. (Ord. 718, 6-27-2013)
1-10-3: PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS DEFINITION:
The term "public improvements", as used in this chapter, shall have the same
meaning ascribed to that term in division 9 of article 8 of the Illinois
Municipal Code 1 , and as such may be interpreted by the courts of the State of
Illinois. (Ord. 718, 6-27-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-9-1 et seq.
1-10-4: EMERGENCY PURCHASES; REPORT REQUIRED:
In the case of the occurrence of any breakage or loss of equipment, or in other
circumstances which could not reasonably be anticipated whereby any necessary
regular service of the Village is, or is about to be, interrupted, or whereby
the Village will suffer any great or continuing loss, the department head, upon
the approval of the Village President, may negotiate any emergency purchase or
contract to restore or maintain such service as to terminate such loss, without
advertising for bids and in such amount as may be necessary in the
circumstances. In case of such emergency purchases involving amounts of more
than twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), the department head shall use
reasonable efforts to contract with an entity meeting the "responsible bidder"
criteria as described in section
1-10-2 of this chapter, and shall tender a full report on the case at the next
meeting of the Board of Trustees thereafter. (Ord. 718, 6-27-2013; amd. Ord.
752, 10-29-2015; Ord. 789, 9-26-2017)
CHAPTER 11
TRAVEL, MEAL AND LODGING EXPENSES
SECTION:
1-11-1: Definitions
1-11-2: Maximum Reimbursement
1-11-3: Expense Reimbursement Request Form
1-11-4: Approval
1-11-5: Reimbursements That Exceed Maximum
1-11-6: Entertainment
1-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
ENTERTAINMENT: Includes, but is not limited to, shows, amusements, theaters,
circuses, sporting events, or any other place of public or private
entertainment or amusement, unless ancillary to the purpose of the program or
event.
PUBLIC BUSINESS: Expenses incurred in the performance of a public purpose which
is required or useful for the benefit of the village to carry out the
responsibilities of village business.
TRAVEL: Any expenditure directly incident to official travel by employees and
officers of the village or by wards or charges of the village involving
reimbursement to travelers or direct payment to private agencies providing
transportation or related services. (Ord. 775, 2-23-2017, eff. 3-2-2017)
1-11-2: MAXIMUM REIMBURSEMENT:
The village shall only reimburse the following types of travel, meal, and
lodging expenses incurred by its employees and officers up to the following
maximum allowable amounts:
   A.   Travel: When using personal vehicles to conduct public business the
employee will be reimbursed at the IRS approved rate, plus tolls and parking. A
mileage reimbursement form will be submitted by the employees and/or officers
for mileage reimbursement only.
   B.   Lodging: The village will reimburse employees for daily lodging
expenses. Lodging expenses will be reimbursed: 1) in accordance with the
applicable per diem rates in compliance with the current edition of IRS
publication 463 entitled "Travel, Entertainment, Gift, And Car Expenses" and as
set forth on the GSA (U.S. general services administration) website at
www.gsa.gov; or 2) the actual cost of lodging arranged by the host for the
seminar/conference attended.
   C.   Meals: The village will reimburse employees for daily meal expenses not
to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) each day. Alcohol is specifically excluded
from reimbursement. (Ord. 775, 2-23-2017, eff. 3-2-2017)
1-11-3: EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT REQUEST FORM:
No reimbursement of travel, meal or lodging expenses incurred by a village
employee or officer shall be authorized unless the "travel, meal, and lodging
expense reimbursement request form", on file in the city, has been submitted
and approved. All documents and information submitted with the form shall be
subject to disclosure under the freedom of information act 1 . (Ord. 775, 2-23-
2017, eff. 3-2-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.
1-11-4: APPROVAL:
Reimbursement or prepayment of travel, meal or lodging expenses of any officer
or employee that does not exceed the maximum reimbursement amount allowed under
the regulations adopted under section
1-11-2 of this chapter may only be approved by the village president, the
chairperson of the personnel committee, or the village board. (Ord. 775, 2-23-
2017, eff. 3-2-2017)
1-11-5: REIMBURSEMENTS THAT EXCEED MAXIMUM:
Expenses for travel, meals, and lodging of: a) any officer or employee that
exceeds the maximum reimbursement allowed under the regulations adopted under
section
1-11-2 of this chapter or b) any member of the village board of trustees may
only be approved by roll call vote at an open meeting of the village board of
trustees. However, in the event of an emergency or other extraordinary
circumstances, the village board of trustees may approve more than the maximum
allowable expenses set forth above. (Ord. 775, 2-23-2017, eff. 3-2-2017)
1-11-6: ENTERTAINMENT:
The village shall not reimburse any elected official, employee, or officer for
any activities which would be considered entertainment. Activities which would
otherwise be considered entertainment, but which are excluded from the
prohibition on reimbursement due to being ancillary to the purpose of the
program or event, may be reimbursed in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 775, 2-23-2017, eff. 3-2-2017)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
PLANNING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-1-1: Created; Purpose
2-1-2: Membership; Residency; Appointment
2-1-3: Term Of Office; Vacancies; Compensation
2-1-4: Organization And Procedure
2-1-5: Powers And Duties
2-1-6: Land Subdivision Or Resubdivision; Official Map
2-1-7: Public Improvements
2-1-8: Secretary; Technical Advisors
2-1-1: CREATED; PURPOSE:
In order that adequate provisions be made for the preparation of a
comprehensive village plan for the guidance, direction and control of the
growth and development or redevelopment of the village and contiguous territory
not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits and not
included in any municipality, a planning commission is hereby created under
authority of an act of the general assembly of the state of Illinois entitled
"Illinois municipal code", approved May 29, 1961, effective July 1, 1961, as
amended. (Ord. 57, 8-19-1965)
2-1-2: MEMBERSHIP; RESIDENCY; APPOINTMENT:
The planning commission shall consist of seven (7) members, each of whom shall
either reside within the village or within territory contiguous to the village
and not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits of
the village and not included within any other municipality. All members shall
be appointed by the village president, subject to confirmation by the board of
trustees, on the basis of their particular fitness for their duty on the
planning commission and subject to the approval of the village board. (Ord.
195, 4-22-1982; amd. 2012 Code)
2-1-3: TERM OF OFFICE; VACANCIES; COMPENSATION:
All members of the planning commission shall serve for a period of three (3)
years which term shall begin on July 1 and end on June 30 three (3) years
later. Vacancies shall be filled by appointments for unexpired terms only. All
members of the commission shall serve without compensation; except, that if the
village board of trustees deems it advisable, they may receive such
compensation as may be fixed from time to time by said village board of
trustees and provided in the appropriation ordinance. (Ord. 195, 4-22-1982;
amd. Ord. 261, 11-17-1988)
2-1-4: ORGANIZATION AND PROCEDURE:
There shall be an organizational meeting of the planning commission to be held
annually. At such meeting, the commission shall elect such officers as it may
deem necessary, and adopt and later change or alter rules and regulations of
organization and procedure, subject to approval by the village board and
consistent with village ordinances and state laws. The commission shall keep
written records of its proceedings, which shall be open at all times to public
inspection. The commission shall also file an annual report with the village
president and board of trustees setting forth its transactions and
recommendations. (Ord. 57, 8-19-1965; amd. 2012 Code)
2-1-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The planning commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   1. To prepare and recommend to the village board of trustees a
comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of
the village and contiguous unincorporated territory not more than one and one-
half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits of the village and not included
in any other municipality. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate
geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the
official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the village. Such plan shall
be advisory except as to such part thereof as has been implemented by
ordinances duly enacted by the village board of trustees.
      2.   As provided by law, there shall be compliance with all requirements
for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption with the county recorder of
deeds and filing of said plan and ordinances with the village clerk.
      3.   To provide for the health, safety, comfort and convenience of the
inhabitants of the village and contiguous territory, such plan or plans shall
establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for
resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in
respect to public improvements as herein defined and shall establish reasonable
requirements governing the location, width, course, and surfacing of public
streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs,
gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, size of
lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater drainage, water supply and
distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment. The
requirements specified herein shall become regulatory only when adopted by
ordinance.
   B.   To designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the
recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation.
   C.   To recommend to the village board of trustees, from time to time, such
changes in the comprehensive plan, or any part thereof, as may be deemed
necessary.
   D.   To prepare and recommend to the village board of trustees, from time to
time, plans and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of
the official comprehensive plan.
   E.   To give aid to the officials of the village charged with the direction
of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, or parts
thereof, to further the making of such improvements and generally to promote
the realization of the official comprehensive plan.
   F.   To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities
for the general purpose of public understanding.
   G.   To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions and other
agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure
harmonious and integrated planning for the area. (Ord. 57, 8-19-1965)
   H.   To accept and receive a plat of subdivision of land for preliminary
approval and advise and assist the village board in final approval thereof.
(2012 Code)
   I.   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted under
authority of an act of the general assembly of the state of Illinois entitled
"Illinois municipal code", approved May 29, 1961, effective July 1, 1961, as
amended, as may be conferred by the village board of trustees. (Ord. 57, 8-19-
1965)
2-1-6: LAND SUBDIVISION OR RESUBDIVISION; OFFICIAL MAP:
   A.   At any time before or after the formal adoption of the official
comprehensive plan by the corporate authorities, an official map may be
designated by ordinance, which map may consist of the whole area included
within the official comprehensive plan, or one or more separate geographical or
functional parts, and may include all or any part of the contiguous
unincorporated area within one and one-half (11/2) miles from the corporate
limits of the village. As provided by law, there shall be compliance with all
requirements for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption with the county
recorder of deeds, and filing of said plan and ordinances, including the
official map, with the village clerk.
   B.   No map or plat of any subdivision or resubdivision presented for record
affecting land within the corporate limits of the village or within contiguous
territory which is not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the
corporate limits shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless the
subdivision shown thereon provides for standards of design and standards
governing streets, alleys, public ways, ways for public service facilities,
streetlights, public grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes,
stormwater and floodwater runoff channels and basins, water supply and
distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment in
conformity with the applicable requirements of the ordinances, including the
official map. (Ord. 57, 8-19-1965)
2-1-7: PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
The village clerk shall furnish the planning commission, for its consideration,
a copy of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any
nature. The planning commission may report in relation thereto, if it deems a
report necessary or advisable, for consideration by the village board of
trustees. (Ord. 57, 8-19-1965)
2-1-8: SECRETARY; TECHNICAL ADVISORS:
