Hills" at the village hall, 16 Holland Road, Germantown Hills, IL 61548.
   D.   Failure To Pay Fines: If the village determines to pursue violators in
court who have not paid their fines within one month after the dates of their
violation notices, the violators shall be responsible for payment of all court
costs if found guilty. The village attorney shall pursue such violators in
court upon the direction of the village president. (Ord. 411, 7-23-1998)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
ARTICLE A. DRIVEWAY CULVERTS AND UNDERDRAINS
SECTION:
7-1A-1: Permit Requirements
7-1A-2: Driveway Culvert Construction Requirements
7-1A-3: Roadside Underdrain Construction Requirements
7-1A-4: Violation; Penalty
7-1A-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall begin installation of driveway
culverts or roadside underdrains without first having secured a permit from the
superintendent of public works.
   B.   Notice To Install: Any person intending to begin such installation
shall so notify the superintendent of public works in writing and shall submit
plans or drawings showing the nature and location of the proposed installation.
   C.   Inspections:
      1.   Prior To Permit Issuance: Before issuance of the permit, the
superintendent of public works shall inspect the site of the proposed
installation and shall inform the applicant in writing of any changes to the
plans or drawings necessary to ensure compliance with this article.
      2.   Completion Of Installation; Certificate Of Compliance: After
completion of the installation, the applicant shall notify the superintendent
of public works who shall inspect the completed installation to ensure that it
has been built in compliance with this article and with any requirements
specified upon the issuance of the permit. If the completed installation is
satisfactory, the superintendent of public works shall issue a certificate of
compliance so stating. (Ord. 175, 3-27-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
7-1A-2: DRIVEWAY CULVERT CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
All driveways, except those leading onto streets improved with curb and gutter,
shall have culverts installed in accordance with the following standards unless
otherwise approved by the superintendent of public works:
   A.   Pipe material shall conform to the Illinois department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" for
pipe culverts type 1-A. The culvert shall be sized to adequately handle the
drainage area to be served. Said culvert size shall be determined by the
superintendent of public works and/or his representative. In no case, however,
shall a pipe culvert of less than twelve inches (12") in diameter be installed.
The culvert shall be placed in line with the existing or proposed roadway ditch
horizontally, and shall be placed with its invert at a vertical depth of not
less than two feet (2') below the crown of the road. Minimum depth to cover
over the top of the pipe culvert to the surface of the driveway shall be six
inches (6"). If the existing ditch is not of sufficient depth to provide these
minimum standards, the builder shall regrade the existing ditch as directed by
the superintendent of public works to provide the necessary drainageway.
   B.   All areas disturbed in the course of the installation shall be repaired
to their original conditions, and all waterways shall be hand raked and seeded
as directed by the superintendent of public works. (Ord. 175, 3-27-1980; amd.
2012 Code)
   C.   Culvert pipe shall be of sufficient length to extend from the toe of
the slope to the toe of the slope of the driveway cross section. In no case
shall these slopes be steeper than three feet (3') horizontal per each vertical
foot as measured from the flow line of the invert of the culvert to the edge of
the driveway.
   D.   The driveway surface shall be graded so that it meets the edge of the
existing street surface and drains toward the culvert at a minimum slope of
0.50 percent. The low point of the driveway shall not be closer to the street
than the existing ditch, but in no case shall it be closer than four feet (4').
   E.   All work and materials used on the village rights of way shall be in
accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction"
as well as exhibit A attached to the ordinance codified herein. (Ord. 175, 3-
27-1980)
   F.   No fences, posts, retaining walls, shrubs or curbs shall be constructed
along the driveway between the right of way line or the property line and the
street pavement, except as approved by the superintendent of public works. In
no event, however, does the village assume any responsibility for damage or
removal of such items, should such be necessary to provide adequate drainage
maintenance.
   G.   Reflectors may be placed at the top of the slope in line with the
culvert. Reflectors shall not exceed four inches (4") in any dimension and
shall not project more than twenty four inches (24") above the low point of the
driveway surface. Reflectors must bend or break away when struck.
   H.   All driveways shall cross the existing or proposed sidewalk at sidewalk
grade causing neither a depression nor a hump in the sidewalk without the
express permission of the superintendent of public works. (Ord. 175, 3-27-1980;
amd. 2012 Code)
7-1A-3: ROADSIDE UNDERDRAIN CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
Underdrains will only be allowed in circumstances dictated by and at the
discretion of the superintendent of public works and/or the street committee.
When previously authorized by the superintendent of public works, an underdrain
system may be installed in lieu of the roadside ditch and shall be constructed
in accordance with the following standards unless otherwise approved by the
superintendent of public works:
   A.   Pipe material shall conform to the Illinois department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" for
pipe culverts type 1-A. The size of the underdrain shall be determined by the
superintendent of public works and/or his representative. In no case, however,
shall an underdrain of less than twelve inches (12") in diameter be installed.
The minimum pipe slope shall be two percent (2%), and all underdrain systems
shall be laid to line and grade. In addition, manholes and/or catch basins
shall be provided at the side yard property lines of each homeowner should the
underdrain system be continuous.
   B.   Each lot shall have, at minimum, an inlet structure on the downstream
end of the underdrain. Additional inlet structures shall be required, at the
direction of the superintendent of public works, when necessary to prevent the
obstruction of the drainageways or to prevent ponding. Each inlet structure
shall be constructed with an inside dimension of two feet by two feet (2' x 2')
square. It shall be constructed on block or brick and mortar with a minimum
wall thickness of four inches (4") where walls are eighteen inches (18") high
or less. If greater than eighteen inches (18") high, the wall thickness shall
be eight inches (8"). It shall be set on a portland cement concrete base slab
with a minimum thickness of six inches (6"). The inlet shall be covered with a
frame and grate suitable for use in streets or trafficways (similar to Neenah
Foundary no. R3405 or approved equal). The surface of the grate shall be laid
flush with the flow line of the surface drainage swale so as to deposit all
surface waters from the adjacent road and lot area into the underdrain system.
(Ord. 175, 3-27-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
   C.   Culvert pipe on the upstream end of the underdrain shall be connected
to an existing inlet structure. If no inlet structure exists on the upstream
end, the ground at the upstream end shall be sloped from the new surface
drainage swale to the existing surface drainage swale with a slope not steeper
than three feet (3') horizontal per each vertical foot. The ground on the
downstream side of the downstream inlet structure, if no adjoining underdrain
exists, shall be similarly sloped. If a downstream inlet structure between two
(2) driveways, as shown on exhibit B attached to the ordinance codified herein,
and sufficient space exists between the inlet structure and the downstream
driveway to accommodate the required slope, then the underdrain leading from
the inlet structure shall be connected to the existing downstream driveway
culvert, and the entire area between the driveways shall be filled and graded
so that the surface of the inlet structure grate is flush with the new surface
drainage swale. (Ord. 175, 3-27-1980)
   D.   All areas disturbed in the course of construction shall be repaired to
their original condition, and all waterways shall be hand raked and seeded as
directed by the superintendent of public works. (Ord. 175, 3-27-1980; amd. 2012
Code)
   E.   All work and materials used on the village rights of way shall be in
accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction"
as well as exhibit B attached to the ordinance codified herein. (Ord. 175, 3-
27-1980)
7-1A-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Notice Of Violation: Any person found to be in violation of any
provision of this article shall be served by the superintendent of public works
with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a
reasonable time for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall,
within the period of time stated in such notice, make the necessary corrections
and permanently cease all violations stated.
   B.   Penalty: Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time
limit provided in subsection A of this section shall be fined in an amount not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each violation. Each day in which a violation shall continue
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 175, 3-27-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
ARTICLE B. MAILBOXES
SECTION:
7-1B-1: Interference With Traffic And Street Use Prohibited
7-1B-2: Location And Construction Requirements
7-1B-3: Information On Mailboxes
7-1B-4: Responsibility For Damages
7-1B-5: Noncompliant Mailboxes And Support Structures
7-1B-6: Penalties
7-1B-1: INTERFERENCE WITH TRAFFIC AND STREET USE PROHIBITED:
No mailbox or support structure will be allowed to exist on village rights of
way if it interferes with the safety of the traveling public or the function,
maintenance or operation of the village street system. (Ord. 745, 3-26-2015)
7-1B-2: LOCATION AND CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
The location and construction of mailboxes and support structures shall conform
to the standards established by the village in this article. A mailbox
installation that conforms to the following criteria will be acceptable unless,
in the judgment of the United States postal service or the corporate
authorities of the village, the installation interferes with the safety of the
traveling public or the function, maintenance or operation of the village
street system:
   A.   Location: Mailboxes shall be located in accordance with the following
requirements:
      1.   Mailboxes shall be located on the right hand side of the roadway in
the direction of the mail delivery route except on one-way streets where they
may be placed on the left hand side.
      2.   The bottom of the mailbox shall be set at an elevation of thirty six
inches (36") to forty two inches (42") from the roadway surface or as otherwise
established by the United States postal service.
      3.   The roadside face of the mailbox shall be set back not more than six
inches (6") from the edge of the pavement, if there is no all weather shoulder;
or not more than six inches (6") from the edge of an all weather shoulder; or
not more than six inches (6") from the front of a flat faced curb; or not more
than six inches (6") from the back of a roll curb.
      4.   Where a mailbox is located at a driveway entrance, it shall be
placed on the far side of the driveway in the direction of the mail delivery
route, except where the mailbox is located on a curve or cul-de-sac, in which
case, it shall be located before and as close as possible to the driveway in
the direction of the mail delivery route.
      5.   Where a mailbox is located at an intersecting street, it shall be
located a minimum of one hundred feet (100') beyond the center of the
intersecting street in the direction of the mail delivery route.
   B.   Construction: The village encourages mailbox construction to conform to
the guidelines of the United States postal service. (Ord. 745, 3-26-2015)
7-1B-3: INFORMATION ON MAILBOXES:
   A.   Every curbside mailbox must bear the following information: A house
number, if street names and house numbers have been assigned by the village and
if the postmaster authorizes their use as a postal address. If the mailbox is
on a different street from the homeowner's residence, both the house number and
the street name must be inscribed on the mailbox.
   B.   The mailbox may bear the owner's name.
   C.   All required information must be inscribed in contrasting color in neat
letters and numerals at least one inch (1") high on the side of the mailbox
visible to the carrier's regular approach or on the door if mailboxes are
grouped. (Ord. 745, 3-26-2015)
7-1B-4: RESPONSIBILITY FOR DAMAGES:
   A.   Any mailbox placed in the right of way is at the sole risk of the owner
of the mailbox, and the village assumes no liability with respect to same. The
owner shall also indemnify and hold harmless the village from any liability,
claims, or damages that might be asserted by a third party as a result of the
placement of a mailbox in the public right of way.
   B.   The village shall not be responsible and assumes no responsibility for
repairing or replacing any damaged mailbox or support structure when:
      1.   The mailbox or support structure is constructed or located in a
manner that is in violation of the standards established by the United States
postal service or as required by this article.
      2.   The mailbox or support structure is damaged as a result of objects,
snow, sleet, ice, water or other precipitation thrown by a snowplow.
      3.   The mailbox or support structure is found to have been in an unsound
condition prior to the damage, regardless of the circumstances causing the
damage.
      4.   The mailbox or support structure is damaged by any person who is not
acting under the direction or at the request of the village.
   C.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section, the village shall
be financially responsible for damage to a mailbox or support structure when
the mailbox or support structure is physically struck by a village owned and
operated maintenance truck or snowplow, or when the mailbox or support
structure is physically struck by a snowplow owned and operated by a
subcontractor performing precipitation removal operations at the request of the
village, as follows:
      1.   The owner of the mailbox or support structure shall report the
damage to the village clerk within forty eight (48) hours of the incident.
      2.   The owner shall be responsible for repairing or replacing the
damaged mailbox or support structure.
      3.   Upon receipt of the owner's proof of payment for the repair or
replacement, the village shall reimburse the owner, but in no event shall the
village be responsible to reimburse the owner an amount in excess of one
hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) per incident for the repair or
replacement.
   D.   In the event the village, or any utility company which has easement
rights within the village right of way, needs to use said area to repair,
maintain, or install any utility system or appurtenance, or needs to maintain
or repair the right of way, or for any other reason: 1) the village shall not
be liable for any damage caused to any mailbox or support structure located
within the right of way, regardless of the cause of said damage, except as
provided for in this section; and 2) if the mailbox and/or support structure
interferes with said rights of the village or utility company, the owner shall
remove the mailbox and/or support structure at the owner's sole expense. (Ord.
745, 3-26-2015)
7-1B-5: NONCOMPLIANT MAILBOXES AND SUPPORT STRUCTURES:
Any mailbox or support structure erected after the effective date hereof that
is found to be in violation of this article shall be removed and replaced by
the owner upon written notice from the village. At the discretion of the
village, based on assessment of the hazard to the public, the owner will be
granted not less than twenty four (24) hours nor more than thirty (30) days to
remove or replace an unacceptable mailbox or support structure. After the
specified removal and replacement period has expired, the unacceptable mailbox
or support structure will be removed by the village at the owner's expense.
(Ord. 745, 3-26-2015)
7-1B-6: PENALTIES:
   A.   This article shall be subject to the provisions and procedures
established in title 1, chapter 4, article A of this code which provides an
opportunity for administrative payment of tickets for certain ordinance
violations (the "administrative ticket ordinance"). Any person violating this
article:
      1.   Shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) if a ticket issued pursuant to
the administrative ticket ordinance procedures is paid to the "Village Of
Germantown Hills" at the village hall (216 Holland Road, Germantown Hills, IL
61548) no more than thirty (30) days after issuance of the ticket; or
      2.   Shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) if a ticket issued
pursuant to the administrative ticket ordinance procedures is paid to the
"Village Of Germantown Hills" at the village hall more than thirty (30) days
after issuance of the ticket, but before the village files an action for
violation of this article in the county circuit court; or
      3.   Shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus all applicable
court costs, if the village files an action for violation of this article in
the county circuit court more than thirty (30) days after issuance of the
ticket.
   B.   Each day a violation of this article continues shall be considered a
separate violation and may be separately charged. (Ord. 745, 3-26-2015)
CHAPTER 2
SEWER USE AND SERVICE

7-2-12: Violations; Penalties
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
CLARIFICATION OF WORD USAGE: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
FEDERAL GOVERNMENT:
   Administrator: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection
agency.
   Federal Act: The federal clean water act (33 USC 466 et seq.), as amended
(Pub.L. 95-217).
   Federal Grant: The U.S. government participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided by "Title II - Grants For
Construction Of Treatment Works" of the federal act and implementing
regulations.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT:
   President: The president of the village of Germantown Hills or his
designated appointee who shall be confirmed by the village board.
   Village: The village of Germantown Hills.
NPDES PERMIT: Any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the
administrator or, where appropriate, by the director, after enactment of the
federal clean water act, to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to
section 402 of the federal act.
PERSON: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual,
firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society,
institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
SEWER TYPES AND APPURTENANCES:
   Building Drain: That part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which
receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the
walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved
point of discharge, beginning five feet (5') beyond the foundation wall where
it is connected to the building sewer.
   Building Sewer: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal.
   Combined Sewer: A sewer which is designed and intended to receive
wastewater, stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage.
   Easement: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by
others.
   Public Sewer: A sewer provided by or subject to jurisdiction of the village.
The term also includes sewers within or outside the village boundaries that
serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the village sanitary
sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed with
village funds.
   Sanitary Sewer: A sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes, or a
combination of both, and into which stormwaters, surface waters, and
groundwaters or unpolluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted.
   Sewer: A pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids,
including stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage.
   Sewerage: The system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection,
transportation and pumping of sewage.
   Storm Sewer: A sewer that carries stormwater, surface water and groundwater
drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted
cooling water.
   Stormwater Runoff: That portion of the precipitation that is drained into
the sewers.
STATE GOVERNMENT:
   Director: The director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
   State Act: The Illinois anti-pollution bond act of 1970.
   State Grant: The state of Illinois participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided by the Illinois anti-pollution bond
act and for making such grants as filed with the secretary of state of the
state of Illinois.
TREATMENT:
   Pretreatment: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction
into the wastewater treatment works.
   Wastewater Treatment Works: An arrangement of devices and structures for
treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge; sometimes used as
synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or
"pollution control plant".
TYPES OF CHARGES:
   Basic User Charge: The basic assessment levied on all users of the public
sewer system.
   Debt Service Charge: The amount to be paid each billing period for payment
of interest, principal and coverage of bonds outstanding, and shall be computed
by dividing the annual debt service by the number of users connected to the
wastewater facilities.
   Replacement: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment,
accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the
treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works
were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes
replacement.
   Sewer Fund: The principal accounting designation for all revenues received
in the operation of the sewerage system.
   Surcharge: The assessment in addition to the basic user charge and debt
service charge which is levied on those persons whose wastes are greater in
strength than the concentration values established in article A of this
chapter.
   Useful Life: The estimated period during which the collection system and/or
treatment works will be operated.
   User Charge: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of
operation, maintenance and replacement.
   Wastewater Service Charge: The charge per one month period levied on all
users of the wastewater facilities. The service charge shall be computed as
outlined in article A of this chapter and shall consist of the total of the
basic user charge, the debt service charge and a surcharge, if applicable.
USER TYPES:
   Commercial User: Includes transit lodging, retail and wholesale
establishments or places engaged in selling merchandise, or rendering services.
   Control Manhole: A structure located on a site from which industrial wastes
are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The
purpose of a "control manhole" is to provide access for the village
representative to sample and/or measure discharges.
   Industrial User: Includes establishments engaged in manufacturing activities
involving the mechanical or chemical transformation of materials or substances
into products.
   Institutional/Governmental User: Includes schools, churches, penal
institutions, and users associated with federal, state, and local governments.
   Residential User: All dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes,
apartments, and permanent multi-family dwellings.
   User Class: The type of user, either "residential", "institutional/
governmental", "commercial" or "industrial", as defined in this section.
WASTEWATER AND ITS CHARACTERISTICS:
   BOD (Denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in
the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure
in five (5) days at twenty degrees Celsius (20°C), expressed in milligrams per
liter.
   Effluent Criteria: Defined in any applicable "NPDES permit".
   Floatable Oil: Oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will
separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment
facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable oil if it is
properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection
system.
   Garbage: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking,
and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of food.
   Industrial Waste: Any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged,
permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or
business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or
processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage.
   Milligrams Per Liter: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater
constituents. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters
(1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per
million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of
water and wastewater analyses.
   ppm: Parts per million by weight.
   pH: The logarithm (base-10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion
concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA division
of laboratories "Manual Of Laboratory Methods".
   Population Equivalent: A term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or
other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is one
hundred (100) gallons of sewage per day, containing 0.22 pound of BOD and 0.25
pound of suspended solids. (Numbers are for systems with a garbage grinder.)
   Properly Shredded Garbage: The wastes from the preparation, cooking, and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") (1.27 centimeters)
in any dimension.
   Sewage: The term is used interchangeably with "wastewater".
   Slug: Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which, in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds, for any
period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes, more than five (5) times
the average twenty four (24) hour concentration of flows during normal
operation.
   Standard Methods: The examination and analytical procedures set forth in the
most recent edition of "Standard Methods For The Examination Of Water And
Wastewater", published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the
American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation.
   Suspended Solids (SS): Solids that either float on the surface of or are in
suspension in water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a
laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids
shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the IEPA division of
laboratories "Manual Of Laboratory Methods".
   Unpolluted Water: Water quality equal to or better than the effluent
criteria in effect, or water that would not cause violation of receiving water
quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewer
and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
   Wastewater: The spent water of a community. From this standpoint, of course,
it may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences,
commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any
groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present.
   Water Quality Standards: Defined in the water pollution regulations of
Illinois.
WASTEWATER FACILITIES: The structures, equipment, and processes required to
collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport
effluent to a watercourse.
WATERCOURSE AND CONNECTIONS:
   Natural Outlet: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other
body of surface water or groundwater.
   Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously
or intermittently. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. Ord. 231, 9-20-1984; 2012 Code)
7-2-2: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
   A.   Vacancy In Office: During the absence or disability of the
superintendent of public works, the superintendent, with the consent of the
president and/or the village board, must designate some properly qualified
person to perform the duties of the office.
   B.   Powers And Duties: In addition to other duties as may be assigned from
time to time by the village board of trustees, the superintendent of public
works shall have the responsibility of operating and maintaining the village
wastewater treatment facilities. It shall be the duty of the superintendent of
public works to:
      1.   Conduct tests thereon.
      2.   Keep records of all actions, examinations, inspections, and tests.
      3.   Advise the public, when requested, in matters concerning regulations
of the wastewater treatment facilities.
      4.   Make monthly reports of his acts and doings to the village board.
      5.   Report all violations of this chapter to the village president for
enforcement.
      6.   Be responsible for all property and equipment pertaining to the
wastewater treatment facilities, and supervise all other employees therein.
      7.   Perform all other duties pertaining to the village as directed by
the village president. (Ord. 137, 11-18-1976; amd. 2012 Code)
7-2-3: CONTRACTOR REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Application For Registration; Bond: Any person who desires to engage in
or who shall hereafter at any time engage in the business of the construction,
alteration or repair of any sewer, sanitary connection or storm drain within
the village shall, before commencing such work, make application to the village
clerk for registration as a sewer contractor, and shall deliver to the clerk
his certificate of bond, with sureties to be approved by the trustees, in the
amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) payable to the village, conditioned
that such person shall indemnify and save harmless the village and its officers
and employees from all liability for damages to persons or property by reasons
of or resulting directly or indirectly from the construction, alteration,
maintenance or repair by such person of any sanitary sewer connection or storm
drain or any work or act of omission or commission incidental thereto or in
connection therewith; conditioned further upon the conformance by such person
with all provisions of this chapter with respect to such work; and conditioned
further upon the restoration by such applicant of any street, alley, sidewalk
or pavement disturbed by him so as to leave the same in as good condition as
before the work was commenced. Provided, however, that any owner or occupant of
a single-family residence or duplex dwelling shall not be considered a sewer
contractor for the purpose of this section.
   B.   Issuance Of Certificate Of Registration; Fee: Upon approval of the bond
by the village board, the clerk shall forthwith issue to such applicant a
certificate of registration to operate as a sewer contractor within the
village. No registration shall be complete until the applicant shall pay to the
clerk an annual registration fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 135, 9-16-
1976; amd. 2012 Code)
   C.   Term Of Registration: Registration shall be valid until December 31 of
the year in which it was issued.
   D.   Conflicting Provisions: If this section is in conflict with any other
ordinance, present or future, the most restrictive shall apply. (Ord. 135, 9-
16-1976)
7-2-4: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
   A.   Discharge Of Human And Animal Wastes: It shall be unlawful for any
person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on
public or private property within the village, or in any area under the
jurisdiction of the village, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other
objectionable waste.
   B.   Discharge To Natural Outlets: It shall be unlawful to discharge to any
natural outlet within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the
village, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment
has been provided in accordance with this chapter.
   C.   Private Systems: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful
to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or
other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
   D.   Connection To Sewer System Required: The owners of all the houses,
buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or
other purposes situated within the village and abutting on any street, alley,
or right of way in which there is now located or may in the future be located
any public sanitary (or combined) sewer of the village is hereby required, at
his expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such
facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter, within ninety (90) days after date of official
notice to do so; provided, that said public sewer is within three hundred feet
(300') of the property line. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
   E.   Connection For Annexed Property: Unless otherwise agreed to by the
village and the property owner, property annexed to the village shall connect
to the village's public sewer within five (5) years after the date on which
both: 1) the property has been annexed and 2) an adequate public sewer is
within three hundred feet (300') of the property line of the annexed property.
(Ord. 770, 9-26-2016)
7-2-5: CONNECTION CHARGES:
   A.   Established: Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-150-1,
there is hereby established a connection charge for connection to the sewerage
system of the village in the amounts specified in this subsection. The
connection charge is imposed on and is assessed against all owners and users of
real property, jointly and severally, who constitute new or additional users of
the sewerage system. To the extent and in the manner provided by law, the
connection charge shall be a lien on the affected real property.
      1.   Residential Connections: The amount of the connection charge
applicable to residential connections shall be two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00). A "residential connection" is defined as a connection to a
"residential user", which term is defined in section
7-2-1 of this chapter under "user types".
      2.   Nonresidential Connections:
         a.   The amount of the connection charge applicable to nonresidential
connections shall be in the same proportion to the two thousand five hundred
dollar ($2,500.00) residential connection charge as the actual or projected use
of the sewage plant capacity by the particular nonresidential user bears to the
use of the sewage plant capacity by an average residential user, as determined
by water usage records; provided, however, that the nonresidential connection
charge shall in no event be less than two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00). In the case of a nonresidential user with an established history
of water usage, the superintendent of public works shall calculate the
connection charge in accordance with the formula above. In the case of a
nonresidential user without an established history of water usage, the
superintendent of public works shall estimate and project the water usage for
calculation of the connection charge in accordance with the formula above. In
that event, after water usage figures have been established for a period of a
year, the connection charge shall again be calculated and an additional charge
collected from the nonresidential user, or an amount refunded to the
nonresidential user, depending on application of the formula above. (Ord. 244,
8-21-1986; amd. Ord. 669, 10-14-2010; 2012 Code)
         b.   A "nonresidential connection" is defined as a connection to a
"commercial user", an institutional or governmental user, or an "industrial
user", all of which are defined in section
7-2-1 of this chapter under "user types".
   B.   Use Of Revenues: In accordance with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
150-1, connection charges collected pursuant to this chapter shall be used by
the village for its general corporate purposes in relation to the sewerage
system, with primary application thereof being made by the necessary expansion
of the works of the system to meet the requirements of the new users thereof.
(Ord. 244, 8-21-1986; amd. 2012 Code)
   C.   Charge Is Additional: The connection charge established and imposed by
this section is in addition to all other fees and charges established by this
chapter, including the permit and inspection fee described in subsection
7-2-6A3 of this chapter, and including the wastewater service charges described
in section
7-2A-3 of this chapter.
   D.   Payment Prerequisite To Building Sewer Permit Issuance: The connection
charge established by this section must be paid before issuance of the building
sewer permit described in subsection
7-2-6A of this chapter. (Ord. 244, 8-21-1986)
7-2-6: BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Permit To Connect:
      1.   Permit Required: No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any
connections with, or opening into; use; alter; or disturb any public sewer or
appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the
superintendent of public works. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
      2.   Classes Of Permits; Applications: There shall be two (2) classes of
building sewer permits: a) for residential wastewater service; and b) for
commercial, institutional/governmental or industrial wastewater service. In
either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form
furnished by the village. The permit application shall be supplemented by any
plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the
judgment of the superintendent of public works.
      3.   Permit And Inspection Fee: A permit and inspection fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per residential living unit, and twenty dollars
($20.00) per population equivalent, as determined by the superintendent of
public works, for a commercial, institutional/governmental, or industrial
building shall be paid to the village at the time the application is filed. Any
commercial or industrial applicant, as a condition of permit authorization,
must provide information describing its wastewater constituents,
characteristics, and type of activity. (Ord. 245, 8-21-1986)

(2012 Code)
      4.   Conditions Of Permit: A building sewer permit will only be issued
and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the
downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater
treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and
efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load.
   B.   Separate Building Sewers: A separate and independent building sewer
shall be provided for every building; except, that where one building stands at
the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can
be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or
driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the
rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. (Ord. 221, 12-1-
1983)
   C.   Use Of Old Building Sewers: Old building sewers may be used in
connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination by the
superintendent of public works, to meet all requirements of this chapter. The
old building sewer shall be televised for review by the superintendent of
public works prior to proceeding with connection.
   D.   Installation And Connection Requirements:
      1.   The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building
sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing,
testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of
the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of
the village. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the
materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the
American Society Of Testing Materials, "Water Pollution Control Federation
Manual Of Practice No. 9" and "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois" (latest revisions) shall apply. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983;
amd. 2012 Code)
      2.   Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the
building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which
any building drain is too low to permit gravity to flow to the public sewer,
sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means which
is approved in accordance with subsection E2 of this section, and discharged to
the building sewer. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
      3.   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other
applicable rules and regulations of the village or the procedures set forth in
appropriate specifications of the American Society Of Testing Materials, "Water
Pollution Control Federation Manual Of Practice No. 9" and "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois" (latest
revisions). All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any
deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the
superintendent of public works before installation. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd.
2012 Code)
      4.   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course
of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village.
   E.   Prohibited Discharges:
      1.   No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior
foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or
groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
      2.   All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except
those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to
the Federal Act and more stringent State and local standards. (Ord. 221, 12-1-
1983)
   F.   Inspections: The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify
the Superintendent of Public Works when the building sewer is ready for
inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made
under the supervision of the Superintendent of Public Works. (Ord. 221, 12-1-
1983; amd. 2012 Code)
   G.   Liability For Costs And Expenses; Indemnification: All costs and
expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer
shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the Village from any
loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the
installation of the building sewer including, but not limited to, sewer
backups. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
7-2-7: PRESSURE SEWERS AND GRINDER PUMPS:
   A.   Permitted; Compliance Required: When authorized or directed in writing
by the Village President and Board of Trustees, certain users shall discharge
wastes into the Village sewerage system by means of a pressure sewer and
grinder pump. Such users shall be bound by all provisions of this chapter
except as may be otherwise required by this section. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
   B.   Permit Required; Fees: Persons who will be installing pressure sewers
and grinder pumps must make application with the Superintendent of Public Works
for a pressure sewer permit on a form to be furnished by the Village. In
addition to the information and fees required by subsections
7-2-6A2 and A3 of this chapter, the applicant shall also pay, at the time the
application is filed, a sum of money, as determined from time to time by the
Superintendent of Public Works, sufficient to reimburse the Village for its
actual cost in purchasing a grinder pump, and shall also pay an additional
twenty percent (20%) of the cost of the grinder pump to help defray the future
cost of its replacement by the Village. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
   C.   Specifications; Installation By Village; Responsibility For Costs:
Persons who will be installing pressure sewers and grinder pumps must use
grinder pumps and related material approved and supplied by the Village and
must have the pressure sewer and grinder pump installed by the Village, through
its employees or through such contractors as it may select from time to time.
All labor and material costs for such installation shall be the responsibility
of the person securing the permit. Once the pressure sewer and grinder pump are
installed to the satisfaction of the Superintendent of Public Works, the pump
and all piping from the pump to the pressure sewer main shall be owned and
maintained by the Village. All piping from the house or other structure to the
pump shall be owned and maintained by the property owner. All power necessary
to operate the pump, however, shall be supplied and paid for by the owner or
occupant of the house or user of the pump. (Ord. 231, 9-20-1984; amd. 2012
Code)
   D.   Easement Required: In addition to other permit requirements, the owner
of any property that will be served by a pressure sewer and grinder pump must
furnish the Village a perpetual easement ten feet (10') wide with its
centerline located along the line of the lateral sewer pipe running across the
property from the main to the grinder pump, for the purposes of the
installation, inspection, testing, replacement and maintenance of the pump and
the lateral. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
   E.   Installation Requirements: Persons holding permits for the installation
of a pressure sewer and grinder pump should make specific arrangements with the
Village for the installation at mutually convenient times. Location of the
grinder pump on the property will be designated by the applicant, subject to
approval by the Superintendent of Public Works. Installation by the Village
shall be in accordance with manufacturer's specifications. The property owner
should specifically note the following items, however:
      1.   One Pump: One (1) pump, and only one (1), is required per house,
unless written approval is obtained from the Board of Trustees on account of
special circumstances.
      2.   Power Connection: The property owner must supply a power connection
for the grinder pump control panel on the outside of the house, as required by
manufacturer's specifications.
      3.   Control Panel: The grinder pump control panel, with warning light
and audible alarm, must be visible from the street. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd.
2012 Code)
      4.   PVC Pipe: The property owner must supply a four inch (4") PVC pipe
connected at the foundation wall of the house and extending at least five feet
(5') from the foundation wall, for connection of the building drain to the
grinder pump. (Ord. 231, 9-20-1984; amd. 2012 Code)
      5.   Tamper Or Repair: Once the grinder pump is installed, no
unauthorized person shall tamper with or attempt to repair or maintain the
pump, and the cover of the pump apparatus, at ground level, shall not be
covered or obstructed in any fashion. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
      6.   Grinder Pump Misuse:
         a.   If the Village technician determines that a grinder pump failure
was caused by misuse, meaning improper items (as described in subsection E6b of
this section) were disposed into the system, a service charge will be issued to
the homeowner, and added to the homeowner's sewer bill, as follows:
            (1)   First offense in a thirty six (36) month period: One hundred
dollars ($100.00).
            (2)   Second offense in a thirty six (36) month period: Two hundred
dollars ($200.00).
            (3)   Third offense in a thirty six (36) month period: Four hundred
dollars ($400.00).
            (4)   Fourth and subsequent offenses in a thirty six (36) month
period: Five hundred dollars ($500.00).
         b.   Examples of improper items that should not be disposed of through
the grinder system and will result in assessment of the service charge
described in subsection E6a of this section:
            (1)   Personal hygiene wipes.
            (2)   Feminine hygiene products.
            (3)   Solid waste, including food, garbage, and rags.
            (4)   Grease.
            (5)   Chemicals.
            (6)   Drugs.
            (7)   Hair. (Ord. 791, 10-26-2017)
      7.   Location: The grinder pump must be located at least five feet (5')
from the foundation wall of the house at a location for access for maintenance.
(Ord. 231, 9-20-1984; amd. 2012 Code)
7-2-8: USE OF THE SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM:
7-2-8-1: DISCHARGES INTO SYSTEM:
   A.   Stormwater And Surface Waters; Storm Sewers:
      1.   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any
stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage,
uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any
sanitary sewer. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
      2.   Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to
such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers,
or to a natural outlet approved by the Superintendent of Public Works. (Ord.
221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
   B.   Prohibited Discharges: No person shall discharge, or cause to be
discharged, any of the following described waters or wastes to any public
sewers:
      1.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
      2.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids,
or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other
wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a
hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in
the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
      3.   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having any other
corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures,
equipment, and personnel of the sewage works.
      4.   Solid or viscous substances in quantity or of such size capable of
causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the
proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes,
cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar,
plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and
fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole
or ground by garbage grinders. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
   C.   Restricted Discharges:
      1.   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following
described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely, in the
opinion of the Superintendent of Public Works, that such wastes can harm either
the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment; have an adverse effect on
the receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or
constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these
wastes, the Superintendent of Public Works will give consideration to such
factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities
in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage
treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of
treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and maximum limits
established by regulatory agencies. The substances prohibited are: (Ord. 221,
12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
         a.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (65°C).
         b.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or
oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter
(100 mg/l) or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at
temperatures between thirty two degrees (32°) and one hundred fifty degrees
Fahrenheit (150°F) (0° and 65°C). (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
         c.   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/
4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and
approval of the superintendent of public works.
         d.   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling
wastes, or concentrated plating solution, whether neutralized or not.
         e.   Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or
similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive
chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the
composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established
by the superintendent of public works for such materials.
         f.   Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor
producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be
established by the superintendent of public works as necessary, after treatment
of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or
other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving
waters.
         g.   Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or
concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent of public
works in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations.
         h.   Any wastes or waters having a pH in excess of 9.5.
         i.   Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 milligram
per liter as Hg at any time except as permitted by the superintendent of public
works in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations.
         j.   Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 milligram per liter at any time
except as permitted by the superintendent of public works in compliance with
applicable state and federal regulations.
         k.   Any ammonia nitrogen (as N) in excess of eighty milligrams per
liter (80 mg/l) at any time except as permitted by the superintendent of public
works in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. (Ord. 221,
12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
         l.   Materials which exert or cause:
            (1)   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as,
but not limited to, fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of
dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium
sulfate).
            (2)   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye
wastes and vegetable tanning solutions).
            (3)   Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements
in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment
works.
            (4)   Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes
constituting "slugs", as defined in section
7-2-1 of this chapter under "wastewater and its characteristics".
         m.   Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to
treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are
amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant
effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over
discharge to the receiving waters. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
      2.   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be
discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess
the characteristics enumerated in subsection C1 of this section, and/or which
are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in 40 CFR 403, June
26, 1978, and any amendments thereto, and which, in the judgment of the
superintendent of public works, may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage
works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a
hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent of public
works may: (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
         a.   Reject the wastes;
         b.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to
the public sewers;
         c.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/
or
         d.   Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating
the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions
of section
7-2-8-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
      3.   If the superintendent of public works permits the pretreatment or
equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and
equipment shall be subject to the review by the superintendent of public works
and approval by the board of trustees, and subject to the requirements of all
applicable codes, ordinances, and laws. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
7-2-8-2: INTERCEPTORS:
Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of
the superintendent of public works, they are necessary for the proper handling
of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable
wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except, that such interceptors
shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All
interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent of
public works, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for
cleaning and inspection. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
7-2-8-3: PRELIMINARY TREATMENT OR FLOW EQUALIZATION:
Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided, they
shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the
owner at his expense. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
7-2-8-4: CONTROL MANHOLE:
Each industry shall be required to install a control manhole, and when required
by the board of trustees, the owner of any property serviced by a building
sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole,
together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building
sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such
manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be
constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent of public
works. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be
maintained by him as to be safe and accessible at all times. (Ord. 221, 12-1-
1983; amd. 2012 Code)
7-2-8-5: MEASUREMENTS, TESTS AND ANALYSES:
   A.   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying
industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of
waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and any special
conditions for discharge established by the village or regulatory agencies
having jurisdiction over the discharge.
   B.   The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed
by the owner shall be as stipulated by the village, but no less than once per
year, the industry must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of the
wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the federal, state, and
local standards are being met.
   C.   The owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory
analyses to the village at such times and in such a manner as prescribed by the
village. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements, analyses, and
reporting required by the village. At such times as deemed necessary, the
village reserves the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an
outside laboratory service.
   D.   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of IEPA division of laboratories "Manual Of
Laboratory Methods", and shall be determined at the control manhole provided,
or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no
special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to
be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the
building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily
accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works
and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. The
particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty four (24) hour
composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample
or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids
analyses are obtained from twenty four (24) hour composites of all outfalls,
whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
7-2-8-6: SPECIAL AGREEMENTS:
No statement contained in this section
7-2-8 shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement
between the village and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of
unusual strength or character may be accepted by the village for treatment,
subject to payment therefor, in accordance with article A of this chapter, by
the industrial concern, provided such payments are in accordance with federal
and state guidelines for user charge system. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
7-2-9: EXCESS STORMWATER AND SUMP PUMP DISCHARGES:
   A.   Short Title: This section shall be known as the EXCESS STORMWATER AND
SUMP PUMP DISCHARGE ORDINANCE OF GERMANTOWN HILLS, ILLINOIS.
   B.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning:
    DRY BOTTOM DETENTION BASIN: A facility designed to be normally dry and
maintained with a grass vegetative cover that will contain water only when
excess stormwater runoff occurs. Earthen type dry bottom stormwater detention
basins shall have a concrete paved channel or pipe capable of conveying low
flow through the basin and, where necessary, a system of underdrains to prevent
soggy areas. The embankments around any earthen type detention basin or swale
shall have a slope of no greater than four to one (4:1), horizontal to
vertical, to allow for safe and easy mowing.
   EXCESS STORMWATER: That portion of stormwater runoff from a specific
watershed at a specified rainfall frequency which exceeds the transportation
capacity of natural drainageways or the runoff from the area in its natural
undeveloped state. Excess stormwater includes subsurface as well as surface
runoff. Excess stormwater typically includes roof runoff and runoff from
nonporous surfaces.
   NATURAL DRAINAGEWAYS: Channels formed in the existing surface topography
prior to changes made by unnatural causes.
   NATURAL UNDEVELOPED STATE: The condition of the existing surface topography
and vegetative cover of a parcel of land prior to any development having
occurred, with the exception of typical agricultural practices.
   STORMWATER DETENTION FACILITY: An area designed and designated to store
excess stormwater. A stormwater detention facility may include a dry bottom
detention basin or a wet bottom detention basin.
   25-YEAR STORM: A 25-year storm would have an intensity of rainfall which
would, on the average, be equaled or exceeded only once in twenty five (25)
years. This does not imply that it will occur only once in twenty five (25)
years or, having occurred, will not happen again for twenty five (25) years.
   WET BOTTOM DETENTION BASIN: A facility designed to be maintained as a pond
with a free water surface, and which has capacity to contain excess stormwater
runoff. A wet bottom detention basin must have a minimum normal water depth of
four feet (4') and shoreline protection to prevent erosion from wave action.
The embankments around the detention basin shall have a slope of no greater
than four to one (4:1), horizontal to vertical, to allow for safe and easy
mowing.
   C.   Prohibitions:
      1.   Discharge Upon Streets And Sidewalks: No person, firm or corporation
shall discharge, or allow to be discharged, any excess stormwater or water from
a sump pump upon a paved public street or sidewalk.
      2.   Discharge Upon Neighboring Properties: No person, firm or
corporation shall discharge, or allow to be discharged, any excess stormwater
or water from a sump pump upon property owned by another person or entity.
      3.   Accumulation Or Pooling: No person, firm or corporation shall
discharge, or allow to be discharged, any excess stormwater or water from a
sump pump in such a manner as to allow water to accumulate or pool on the
surface of the land, or to accumulate or pool in any ditch or depression.
Nothing in this subsection C3 shall be construed as preventing the use of
detention ponds or other reasonable means to control water runoff or erosion.
Nothing in this subsection C3 shall be construed as prohibiting natural
wetlands.
   D.   Duty To Take Corrective Action: No person, firm or corporation, having
discharged or having allowed to have been discharged, any excess stormwater or
water from a sump pump, roof runoff or subsurface drainage upon a public
street, right of way or sidewalk, shall fail to take all reasonable corrective
action to prevent or mitigate harm or damage to the public street, right of way
or sidewalk, or the users of said public street, right of way or sidewalk. At a
minimum, required mitigation shall include, but is not limited to, promptly
salting the area of water discharge to prevent the accumulation of ice, or to
melt any such accumulation of ice which may have already occurred, should the
discharge occur or should water accumulate or pool during any period of
freezing temperatures. The failure to take corrective action, as required by
this subsection, is a separate and distinct offense from any discharge in
violation of subsection C1, C2 or C3 of this section.
   E.   Defenses:
      1.   It shall be no defense that the person, firm or corporation does not
own the property from which a discharge of excess stormwater or water from a
sump pump originates (either in whole or in part), if the person, firm or
corporation has control over said property.
      2.   It shall be a defense to an alleged violation of subsection C1, C2
or C3 of this section if a developed property from which a discharge of excess
stormwater originates contains one or more stormwater detention facilities
designed to provide sufficient storage volume to detain excess stormwater
produced by a 25-year rainfall event from the developed drainage area for any
and all durations. Nothing in this subsection E2 shall be deemed as allowing
the purposeful discharge of sump pump water upon a paved street, sidewalk or
property owned by another. (Ord. 654, 3-25-2010)
   F.   Violations, Penalties And Enforcement:
      1.   Notice Of Violation: If any person, firm or corporation violates
this section, the village may send notice to correct the violation. The notice
may issue from the superintendent of public works, any subordinate of the
superintendent of public works, the village attorney, or any other person
designated by the village president. The notice may be delivered by certified
mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service upon any person over
eighteen (18) years of age residing with the person violating this section;
provided further, that notice may be given by any means (including, but not
limited to, posting, telephone, electronic mail or facsimile transmission) to
correct a violation of subsection D of this section. (Ord. 654, 3-25-2010; amd.
2012 Code)
      2.   Fine: If, after ten (10) days' notice to correct a violation of
subsection C1, C2, or C3 of this section, or after twenty four (24) hours'
notice to correct a violation of subsection D of this section, the person, firm
or corporation so notified fails to correct the violation, said person shall be
subject to prosecution for violating this section, and shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
      3.   Injunction: In addition, the village may make application to the
circuit court for an injunction requiring conformance with this section or make
such other order as the court deems necessary to secure compliance with this
section.
      4.   Recovery Of Costs: The village shall be entitled to recover from any
person, firm or corporation violating this section all costs connected with any
enforcement activity, including court costs, reasonable attorney fees and the
fees of any private collection agents retained by the village attorney.
      5.   Remedies Cumulative: The above remedies are cumulative, not
exclusive, and are in addition to any other remedies provided by law or
ordinance.
   G.   Interpretation: This section is in addition to all other ordinances on
the subject and shall be construed therewith excepting as to that part in
direct conflict with any other ordinance, and in the event of such conflict,
the provisions of this section shall govern. Nothing in this section shall be
construed as repealing the prohibitions and penalties for the discharge of
certain water into the village sanitary sewer system in this chapter. (Ord.
654, 3-25-2010)
7-2-10: DAMAGE TO, TAMPERING WITH SYSTEM:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which
is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this section shall be
subject to penalty and potential prosecution. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012
Code)
7-2-11: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   A.   Entry Powers; Limitation On Requested Information:
      1.   The president, members of the board of trustees and other duly
authorized employees of the village, the Illinois environmental protection
agency, and the U.S. environmental protection agency, bearing proper
credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for
the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The president, members of the
board of trustees or his representative shall have no authority to inquire into
any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper,
or other industries, beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and
source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste
treatment.
      2.   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred
to in subsection A1 of this section, the president, members of the board of
trustees or duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois
environmental protection agency, and the U.S. environmental protection agency
shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the
company, and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the
village employees, and the village shall indemnify the company against loss or
damage to its property by the village employees and against liability claims
and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company
and growing out of the gauging and sampling operations, except as such may be
caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain conditions as
required in sections
7-2-8-4 and
7-2-8-5 of this chapter.
   B.   Safety Precautions: The president, members of the board of trustees and
other duly authorized employees of the village, bearing proper credentials and
identification, shall be permitted to enter all private properties through
which the village holds a duly negotiated easement for the purpose of, but not
limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and
maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within said easement. All
entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full
accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the
private property involved. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012 Code)
7-2-12: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   Notice Of Violation: Any person found to be violating any provision of
this chapter, except section
7-2-10 of this chapter, shall be served by the village with written notice
stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for
the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of
time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations.
   B.   Revocation Of Permit: The village may revoke any permit for sewage
disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this chapter. (Ord.
221, 12-1-1983)
   C.   Fine: Any person found to be violating section
7-2-10 of this chapter, or who shall continue any violation beyond the time
limit provided in subsection A of this section, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each violation. Each day in which any such violation shall
continue shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 221, 12-1-1983; amd. 2012
Code)
   D.   Liability For Violations: Any person violating any of the provisions of
this chapter shall become liable to the village by reason of such violation.
(Ord. 221, 12-1-1983)
ARTICLE A. WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGES
SECTION:
7-2A-1: Basis For Charges; Surcharge
7-2A-2: Measurement Of Flow
