8-3-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the SIGN CODE OF THE VILLAGE OF GERMANTOWN
HILLS, ILLINOIS, and may be cited and referred to herein as "this chapter".
(Ord. 688, 7-21-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
8-3-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to promote and protect the public health, safety
and welfare by regulating existing and proposed outdoor signs and advertising
of all types. This chapter is intended to:
   A.   Reduce sign or advertising distractions;
   B.   Reduce visual and physical obstructions;
   C.   Prevent traffic accidents or other potential hazards;
   D.   Maintain the current rural character of the village by regulating the
number, size and quality of signs available to commercial and industrial
entities; and
   E.   Establish and preserve an aesthetically pleasing environment, in part
through prevention of the visual clutter caused by signs, which is common in
more populated and developed communities. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
8-3-3: INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Authority To Interpret: This chapter shall be construed by the zoning
officer, the zoning board of appeals, and the courts in a manner designed to
give effect to its stated purposes.
   B.   Conflicting Provisions: If any portion of this chapter is found to be
in conflict with any other provision of any zoning, building, fire safety, or
other ordinance of the village, the provision that establishes the higher
standard shall prevail. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
8-3-4: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, unless the context clearly requires a
different meaning, the following words shall have the following meanings:
A-FRAME: A portable sign that is intended to be used by an existing business to
advertise business specials, menu choices, and similar matters relating
directly to a purpose of the business.
APARTMENT IDENTIFICATION SIGN: A sign identifying an apartment building or
buildings with more than four (4) units.
ATTACHED SIGN: A sign attached to a building wall, the generally vertical plane
of a mansard type roof, the face of a canopy, portico or marquee, a fence, or
an electronic scoreboard.
BALLFIELD: The enclosed field and surrounding fence of an athletic facility
attached to or within school property.
BANNER SIGN: A sign that may possess colors, characters, letters,
illustrations, or ornamentations and is intended to be hung without frames made
of plastic or fabric of any kind.
BILLBOARD: A free standing sign, which is located off premises, used for
advertising.
BUS STOP OR BENCH TYPE SIGN: A sign attached to or painted upon a bus stop
bench or other type of bench.
BUSINESS CENTER: A single premises, or multiple premises in a single business
development, containing three (3) or more businesses sharing a common building
entrance or private parking lot.
BUSINESS CENTER COMPREHENSIVE SIGN PLAN: An integrated signage plan for a
business center.
CHANGE PANEL SIGN: A sign designed to permit an immediate change of copy which
may be other than the name of the business. A change panel sign shall be
limited to either an attached sign or a ground sign.
CHURCH BULLETIN BOARD SIGN: A sign attached to the exterior of a church or
located elsewhere on the church premises used to identify the church name and
to indicate the services and/or other activities of the church.
CHURCH IDENTIFICATION SIGN: A sign attached to the exterior of a church used to
identify the church name.
CONSTRUCTION SIGN: A temporary sign used during construction of new buildings
or reconstruction of or additions to existing buildings, such as those
identifying the project and denoting the owner, architect, engineer, contractor
and/or financing institutions of the project.
CREDIT CARD OR CHARGE PLATE SIGN: A sign advertising the acceptance of, or
being a replica of, any credit card or charge plate, whether national, local or
otherwise. The sign shall be subject to the standards applicable to the type of
sign used for this advertising purpose.
DIRECTIONAL SIGN: A sign which indicates a direction for movement of vehicular
or pedestrian traffic.
DIRECTORY SIGN: A sign containing the names of more than one business or
occupation within a single sign.
DURABLE MATERIALS: Materials capable of not less than a five (5) year life
without visible deterioration.
ELECTRONIC MESSAGE BOARD/LED: A sign, or portion of a sign, that displays an
electronic image and/or video, which may or may not include text. Such signs
include any sign, or portion of a sign, that uses changing lights to form a
sign message or messages in text form, or uses electronic means to change the
sign message wherein the sequence of messages and the rate if electronically
programmed can be modified by electronic processes.
ELECTRONIC SCOREBOARD: A sign, or portion of a sign, that, at least in part,
uses changing lights to form numbers and/or text to designate a score.
FEATHER FLAG: A free standing feather like structure made of cloth, canvas,
plastic or other flexible material typically constructed of a single plastic or
metal shaft driven in the ground with an attached pennant that is vertically
elongated and attached to the shaft that moves or is designed or intended to
move or blow in the wind.
FENCE: A barrier, railing, or other upright structure, made of wood or wire,
enclosing an area of ground to mark a boundary or to control access.
FLASHING SIGN: An illuminated sign on which artificial or reflected light is
not steady or on which colors change.
FLUTTERING SIGN: A sign that flutters and includes pennants, banners,
nongovernmental flags or other flexible material that moves with the wind or by
some artificial means.
FRONTAGE: The length of a lot on its side bordering a street. A lot bordering
more than one street is considered to have separate frontage for each street
bordered.
GARAGE OR YARD SALE SIGN: A sign used to advertise a sale of personal property
from a home, but not for the purpose of deriving steady income.
GASOLINE SERVICE STATION PRICE SIGN: A sign containing thereon the price per
gallon of gasoline or diesel fuel sold at the station. The words "gas",
"ethyl", "self-service", "miniservice", "regular", "premium", "diesel" or
"unleaded" or similar matter, or a combination thereof, also may be placed on
the sign.
GRAND OPENING; ANNIVERSARY SIGN: A sign advertising the opening of a new
business or the yearly commemoration of the opening of the business, which may
include banners, posters, pennants, ribbons, flags, streamers, strings of light
bulbs, or other moving devices, and may also include inflatable signs, balloons
or other air or gas filled devices.
GROUND SIGN: A detached sign on the same lot as the use it advertises which has
its bottom portion erected upon or supported by the ground, a ground planter
box or other supports. Any sign which meets the definition of a "pole sign"
shall not be considered a ground sign.
HANGING SIGN: A sign hanging entirely beneath a canopy, portico or marquee.
HOME OCCUPATION SIGN: A sign identifying the type of business offered in a
residence.
ILLUMINATED SIGN: Any sign that is illuminated by light sources mounted on or
in the sign or at some other location.
LOT: A parcel, tract, plot, site or area of land accessible by means of a
street or other permanently reserved principal means of access. It may be a
single parcel separately described in a deed or plat that is recorded in the
office of the county recorder of deeds, or it may include parts of or a
combination of such parcels when adjacent to one another and used as one.
MOVING SIGN: A sign all or any part of which moves by any means. Such sign
includes a fluttering sign.
NONCONFORMING SIGN: A sign legally erected under the previously existing sign
ordinance of the village but that does not conform to the provisions of this
chapter.
OFF PREMISES SIGN: A sign that advertises products, services or businesses
which are not located or offered for sale on the same lot, building or premises
as the sign.
ON SITE INFORMATIONAL SIGN: An informational sign located on a commercial or
industrial site which gives parking, fire protection, traffic flow (other than
directional signs), height clearance, pedestrian or other similar information
and which does not advertise the business or use located on the site, and any
signs required to be posted relating to self- service gasoline stations.
PERMANENT WINDOW SIGN: A sign of durable construction materials that is
permanently affixed to either side of the glass of an exterior door or window.
For the purpose of this chapter, a glass brick wall shall be deemed a window.
PERSON: Any natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company, organization or entity of any kind.
POLE BANNER: A banner sign that is attached to the supporting standard for a
streetlight, a utility pole or other similar structure.
POLE SIGN: A detached sign located on the same lot as the use it advertises
which is supported by one or more stationary supports longer than three feet
(3') in height, where the bottom of the sign is at least one-half (1/2) as high
as the total sign height. Any sign which meets this definition shall not be
considered a ground sign.
POLITICAL SIGN: A temporary sign advocating or opposing any political
proposition or candidate for public office.
PORTABLE SIGN: A sign which is not permanently mounted to a pole, building, or
foundation.
PREMISES: That portion of a lot or building occupied by a single occupant,
exclusive of common area, if any, shared with adjacent occupants.
PYLON SIGN: A sign used to advertise a shopping center development and its
related businesses.
REAL ESTATE DIRECTIONAL SIGN: A sign providing directions to property for
rental, lease or sale.
REAL ESTATE SIGN: A sign pertaining only to the prospective rental, lease or
sale of the property on which it is located.
ROOF SIGN: A sign erected on any part of a roof, or on top of a marquee, canopy
or portico.
SEASONAL DISPLAY: Decorations or displays celebrating or denoting religious
holidays or events, the seasons of the year, state and national holidays and
similar occasions.
SIGN: A device or a structure, or part of a structure, including structural
trim, which displays or upon which is displayed any colors, message, name or
symbol of any kind for the purpose of advertising, announcing, directing or
attracting attention from the outside of a building. A cross or other religious
symbol on a religious building shall not be considered a sign. Sign supports
are not considered a part of the sign.
SIGN AREA: The area of the sign face, including structural trim. If a sign or
letters are attached to a building or suspended in any manner whereby there is
no apparent trim or confining border, the sign area shall be computed by
drawing imaginary straight lines around generally rectangular margins and
measuring the area so encompassed by these lines. Square footage restrictions
in sign area shall be interpreted as applying to each sign face, e.g., a ten
(10) square foot restriction means ten (10) square feet per sign face.
SIGN FACE: Any surface of a sign upon, against or through which the advertising
message is displayed or illustrated on the sign; provided, that the ends, or
thickness, of a sign shall not be considered as a separate sign face unless an
advertising message is conveyed thereon.
SIGN HEIGHT: The height of a sign measured from the top of the sign structure
to the surrounding elevation at the base of the sign structure; provided,
however, that if a sign is mounted on a berm, the sign height shall be measured
from the base of the berm.
SIGN STRUCTURE: The sign and all parts associated with its construction.
SIGN SUPPORTS: All devices by which a sign is held up, including, for example,
poles, braces, guys and anchors.
SPECIAL SIGN: A sign used for holidays, public demonstrations or the promotion
of civic welfare or charitable organizations and not for the advertisement of
any product or business.
STRUCTURAL TRIM: The molding, battens, cappings, nailing strips, latticing and
platforms which are attached to the sign structure.
SUBDIVISION IDENTIFICATION SIGN: A sign identifying an entrance to a
residential subdivision, including the subdivision name and/or street names
within the subdivision.
SUBDIVISION REAL ESTATE SIGN: A temporary real estate sign advertising an
entire residential or commercial subdivision.
TEMPORARY SIGN: A sign intended for a limited or intermittent period of
display. A sign to be hung with frames made of plastic, fabric of any kind,
wood, or metal that may possess colors, characters, letters, illustrations, or
ornamentations.
TEMPORARY WINDOW SIGN: A temporary sign of paper, cardboard, canvas, cloth or
other nondurable materials affixed to the inside of an exterior window or glass
door.
UNLAWFUL SIGN: A sign which does not currently meet the requirements of this
chapter and any amendments hereto, and which did not meet the requirements of
the regulations in effect at the time it was erected.
UTILITY IMPROVEMENT SIGN: A temporary sign used to advertise a utility company
and its utility improvement project during: a) construction of a new
subdivision or b) the improvement or expansion of a utility in an existing
subdivision.
VENDING MACHINE SIGN: A sign affixed to or part of a vending machine such as
those machines that sell and dispense soft drinks, snacks and cigarettes.
VILLAGE PROVIDED SIGN: A sign authorized by the Village to be erected on
private commercial/industrial property for the purpose of identifying and
providing direction to businesses that are not located on Route 116.
WALL: That part of a building from its location on the ground to the lowest
part of the related roofline; provided, however, that the generally vertical
plane of a mansard type roof shall be considered as part of the wall of a
building. Wall area shall be calculated using a flat plane projection of the
building elevation from one end of the building to the other. Vertical height
of a wall shall be measured from the grade line to the lower roofline.
(Ord. 688, 7-21-2011; amd. Ord. 704, 6-28-2012; Ord. 743, 2-26-2015; Ord. 790,
10-26-2017; Ord. 808, 8-16-2018; Ord. 853, 11-17-2022; Ord. 878, 1-16-2025)
8-3-5: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required; Exemptions: A sign permit is required for the
construction, installation, erection, relocation or alteration of any sign,
except those signs that are otherwise exempted under this chapter, and except
painting, repainting, cleaning, and other normal repair and maintenance of a
sign structure. In addition, the following signs shall be exempt from the
permit requirements of this section:
      Garage and yard sale signs.
      Political signs.
      Real estate signs.
      Temporary window signs.
      Vending machine signs.
      Village provided signs.
   B.   Application For Permit: An application for a sign permit shall be filed
with the Zoning Officer by the owner of the sign or his agent. The application
shall contain the following information, as noted on the Village sign permit
form:
      1.   Name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the sign, and
agent, if any.
      2.   Location of building, structure, or lot to which or upon which the
sign is to be attached or erected.
      3.   Position of the sign in relation to nearby buildings, structures,
property lines and right-of-way lines.
      4.   Two (2) prints or scale drawings of the plans and specifications
indicating sign materials, design, dimensions (including square footage area),
structural supports, electrical components, and the method of construction and
attachment to the buildings or in the ground. Plans shall show the location of
the sign relative to the ground line and/or roofline as applicable. Plans shall
also show proposed landscaping, if applicable.
      5.   Name of the person erecting the sign.
      6.   Evidence of written consent of the owner of the building, structure
or lot to which or upon which the sign is to be attached or erected.
      7.   Dollar amount of the installed cost of the sign.
      8.   Such other information as the Zoning Officer shall require to show
full compliance with this chapter.
      9.   Type of sign and sign structure being considered for permit in
accordance with this chapter.
      10.   Statement as to whether or not other signs currently exist on the
property.
      11.   A site plan showing the proposed location of the sign along with
the locations and square footage area of all existing signs on the same
premises, if any.
      12.   If the sign is to be illuminated, a statement from the sign company
or owner shall be attached to the application stating the measured light
intensity and that the illumination is in conformance with the requirements
specified by this chapter and the Village zoning ordinance.
   C.   Business Center Comprehensive Sign Plan:
      1.   No permit shall be issued for a sign to be located in a business
center until a comprehensive sign plan has been approved for the center and the
sign complies with the provisions thereof.
      2.   Application for approval of a comprehensive sign plan shall be made
in writing to the Planning Commission on a form and in a manner prescribed
thereby.
      3.   The application shall include a format for all signs to be used in
the center, including their maximum size, color, location, illumination
details, lettering type, mounting details, and (if any) landscaping details.
      4.   Approval of a comprehensive sign plan shall be at the discretion of
the Village Board after receiving the recommendation of the Planning
Commission.
      5.   The criteria for approval of a comprehensive sign plan shall be the
following:
         a.   Every sign shall have good scale and proportion in its design and
in its visual relationship to the other signs, buildings and surroundings.
         b.   The signs in the plan shall be designed as an integral
architectural element of the building and site to which they principally relate
and shall not appear as "add ons" or intrusions.
         c.   Signs shall be designed and constructed such that the materials,
colors, lettering, images and trade identification of the businesses are,
insofar as possible, integrated and similar in appearance within the center.
         d.   The colors, materials, and lighting of every sign shall be
restrained and harmonious with the building and site to which it principally
relates.
         e.   The number of graphic elements and letters shall be held to the
minimum needed to convey each sign's major message and shall be composed in
proportion to the area of the sign's face.
         f.   Each sign shall be compatible with signs on adjoining premises
and shall not compete for attention.
   D.   Conditions Of Permit Issuance: Issuance of a sign permit shall be
subject to the following additional requirements:
      1.   The permit shall be issued by the Zoning Officer within fourteen
(14) days from the date an application is submitted with the appropriate
application fee if the Zoning Officer finds that the sign complies with the
provisions of this chapter and all other laws and regulations of the Village.
Should the Zoning Officer determine that information provided with the
application was insufficient, or that more information is required to determine
whether the application for a sign permit should be granted, the Zoning Officer
shall notify the applicant within this initial fourteen (14) day period, and
the Zoning Officer shall specify what further information is required. The
Zoning Officer shall then issue a permit or deny the same within fourteen (14)
days from the date an applicant provides any required additional information.
      2.   The permit signifies nothing more than approval for the
construction, installation, erection, relocation or alteration of the sign.
Thereafter, the sign must continue to comply with the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
      3.   For each sign requiring a permit, a fee shall be paid at the time of
application for the permit. The fee charged for each sign, other than a B/TS or
a feather flag, shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00), plus an additional five
dollars ($5.00) for each one hundred (100) square feet of surface area of the
sign. The fee charged for each B/TS shall be ten dollars ($10.00). The fee
charged for each feather flag permit shall be ten dollars ($10.00). (Ord. 808,
8-16-2018)
      4.   The applicant who has been issued a sign permit shall, upon
completion of the work, notify the Zoning Officer, who shall inspect the sign
with respect to its compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
      5.   If the work authorized by a sign permit has not been substantially
completed within six (6) months after the date of issuance, the permit shall
become void and a new permit is required.
      6.   Sign permits issued under the terms of this section are not
transferable.
   E.   Appeals: Any person aggrieved by any decision of the Zoning Officer
relative to the provisions of this section may appeal such decision to the
Zoning Board of Appeals as is otherwise provided in the Village zoning
ordinance. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
8-3-6: EXEMPT SIGNS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the term "sign" shall not include the
following:
   A.   Signs of duly constituted governmental bodies, including traffic or
similar regulatory devices, legal notices, or warnings at railroad crossings.
   B.   Flags or emblems of civic, philanthropic, educational, or religious
organizations, provided flags are less than thirty two (32) square feet in
area.
   C.   Memorial plaques, cornerstones, historical tablets, and the like which
are a permanent part of a building and which denote the name of a building,
date of erection, historical significance, or other similar information.
   D.   Signs posted in conjunction with doorbells not exceeding fifteen (15)
square inches in area.
   E.   Signs required to be maintained or posted by law or governmental order,
rule or regulation, unless specifically prohibited, limited, or restricted.
   F.   Address signs, not more than one for each frontage of each principal
use on a lot and not exceeding one hundred forty four (144) square inches in
area, showing only the numerical address designations of the premises upon
which they are located.
   G.   Signs located on mailboxes identifying occupants and address, provided
the sign area does not exceed one hundred forty four (144) square inches in
area. Signs must comply with postal regulations.
   H.   Seasonal displays; provided, that the display shall not be in place for
a period longer than sixty (60) days. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
   I.   Welcome signs erected near community entrances if such sign is provided
by the Village and approved by the Village Board of Trustees prior to
construction. (Ord. 743, 2-26-2015)
8-3-7: PERMITTED SIGNS IN ZONING DISTRICTS:
   A.   Lots used for residential purposes in R-1 Districts: Subject to
limitations set forth in this chapter, only the following signs shall be
permitted on lots used for residential purposes in R-1 Districts:
   Attached Signs to ballfield fences, with special use permit for school
purposes.
   Construction signs.
   Electronic Scoreboards on each ballfield, with special use permit for school
purposes.
   Garage and yard sale signs.
   Home occupation signs.
   Pole Signs, with special use permit for school purposes.
   Political signs.
   Real estate directional signs.
   Real estate signs.
   B.    Agricultural and R-2 Districts, and lots not used for residential
purposes in R-1 Districts: Subject to limitations set forth in this chapter,
only the following signs shall be permitted in agricultural and R-2 districts,
and lots not used for residential purposes in R-1 districts:
   All signs permitted on lots used for residential purposes in R-1 Districts.
   Apartment identification signs.
   Billboard Signs, with a special use permit for school purposes.
   Church identification signs/church bulletin board signs.
   Feather flags.
   Pole banners.
   Real estate directional signs.
   Real estate signs.
   Special signs.
   Subdivision identification signs.
   Subdivision real estate signs.
   C.   Commercial And Industrial Districts: Subject to limitations set forth
in this chapter, only the following signs shall be permitted in commercial and
industrial districts:
   All signs permitted in agricultural and residential districts.
   A-frame signs.
   Attached signs.
   Banner/temporary signs.
   Change panel signs.
   Credit card or charge plate signs.
   Directional signs.
   Directory signs.
   Electronic message boards/LED signs.
   Feather flags.
   Gasoline service station price signs.
   Grand opening/anniversary signs.
   Ground signs.
   Hanging signs.
   Off premises signs.
   On site informational signs.
   Permanent window signs.
   Pole signs.
   Pylon signs.
   Temporary window signs.
   Village provided signs.
   Vending machine signs.
(Ord. 876, 11-21-2024; amd. Ord. 878, 1-16-2025)
8-3-8: PROHIBITED SIGNS:
The following types of signs and sign features are prohibited unless otherwise
permitted in this chapter:
   A.   Signs that flash or make noise. The only exceptions shall be dial
clocks or time and temperature light banks with flashing cycles exceeding four
(4) seconds.
   B.   Colored lights or illuminated signs employing colors that are used in
traffic control devices cannot be within thirty feet (30') of or the same
height as an official traffic control device. Signs using such colors or
illumination are also prohibited where, regardless of their distance from
traffic control devices, they may otherwise be confused for such a device.
   C.   Imitation or resemblance to an official traffic control sign or device,
or use of such words as "stop", "look", "danger", "go slow", "caution", or
"warning". (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
   D.   Moving signs (operated mechanically, electrically, electronically, or
by wind or other forces of nature) or signs with any moving devices, except
clocks and feather flags. Also, the use of posters, pennants, ribbons, flags,
streamers, strings of light bulbs, spinners, or other moving devices when not
part of any sign, are similarly prohibited. Pennants, ribbons, flags and
streamers are allowed for anniversary and grand opening signs. (Ord. 688, 7-21-
2011; amd. Ord. 808, 8-16-2018)
   E.   Paper, cloth, cardboard or other similar nondurable signs located on
the exterior of a building or structure.
   F.   Abandoned signs and signs advertising an activity, business or service
no longer conducted on the lot or premises upon which the sign is located.
   G.   Signs which contain statements, words or pictures of an obscene,
indecent or immoral character such as will offend public morals or decency.
   H.   Roof signs.
   I.   Signs, logos or trademarks painted directly upon a building or wall.
   J.   Signs which project above the highest point of the roof of the
principal building on the lot upon which the signs are located. (Ord. 688, 7-
21-2011)
   K.   Signs attached to a tree, streetlight, public bench or seating area, or
utility pole, except for pole banners pursuant to subsection
8-3-10EE of this chapter. (Ord. 743, 2-26-2015)
   L.   Signs displayed in or on a vehicle or merchandise of any type
advertising the vehicle or merchandise for sale if the vehicle or merchandise
is parked or located on the right-of- way of Route 116 or its parallel frontage
road.
   M.   Signs that do not otherwise comply with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
8-3-9: RESTRICTIONS GENERALLY:
All signs shall be subject to the following restrictions, in addition to any
other standards appearing in this chapter or the Village zoning ordinance:
   A.   Hazardous Signs:
      1.   If, in the opinion of the Zoning Officer, any sign becomes hazardous
to pedestrian or vehicular traffic by reason of, but not limited to,
deterioration, damage, obstruction of walkways or fire access or exit lanes,
restriction of sight distances for vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or its
location so close to travel lanes or parking areas that it is struck by
maneuvering vehicles, then such sign shall be relocated, removed, or protected
by the owner, agent, or person having beneficial use of the premises or lot
within ten (10) days of notification by certified letter from the zoning
officer that such hazard exists.
      2.   If, in the opinion of the zoning officer, the condition or location
of the sign presents imminent danger to the public, it shall be removed or
corrected by the owner, agent, or person having beneficial use of the premises
or lot promptly upon receipt of written notice from the zoning officer. Any
aggrieved business owner may seek review of the zoning officer's ruling by the
village board.
   B.   Signs To Be Durable:
      1.   All new signs shall be constructed from materials that are durable
and weatherproof. These materials include high impact plastics with fade
resistance, wood treated in such a manner as to retain color and strength, wood
that is naturally resistant to weathering such as cedar and redwood, brick and
other masonry materials, aluminum and associated alloys resistant to visible
corrosion, painted steels with baked on finish, and other corrosion resistant
steels.
      2.   Vinyl signs shall have minimum weight of sixteen (16) ounces per
square yard, minimum tensile strength of 270/270 pounds, and minimum tear
strength of 75/85 pounds. Lettering for vinyl signs shall be either of vinyl
pressure sensitive material or transparent vinyl material. Structural support
for vinyl signs shall be one inch (1") square aluminum or galvanized steel
tubing; electrical conduit is not permitted for vinyl sign supports.
      3.   Signs should be constructed to avoid degeneration over time, to
withstand weather, and to require little or no maintenance. Signs shall be
constructed in such a way as to maintain proper alignment both level and plumb.
Signs shall not become misaligned due to frost conditions, and masonry signs
shall have adequate footings to prevent damage due to frost.
      4.   Broken panels, missing letters, flaking or peeling paint and other
visual damage to a sign shall be repaired within forty five (45) days of
occurrence or within thirty (30) days of notification by certified letter from
the zoning officer, whichever occurs first.
      5.   The sign's owner may seek review by the village board of the zoning
officer's determination of compliance with this subsection.
   C.   Illuminated Signs: Illuminated signs shall be subject to the following
standards:
      1.   No signs designated as permitted in an agricultural or residential
district, or actually existing in such a district, may be illuminated, except
subdivision identification signs.
      2.   All signs permitted only in commercial and industrial districts may
be illuminated.
      3.   All illuminated signs, including electronic message boards/LED
signs, located within one hundred feet (100') of a residential property shall
be extinguished no later than the later of: a) the time of business closing; or
b) between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M.; provided,
that this shall not prohibit continuous illumination of permitted flags,
subdivision signs, vending machine signs and directional signs.
      4.   All illumination devices shall be designed to be weather resistant
and shatter resistant.
      5.   The use of unshielded lights, including incandescent light bulbs
strung on poles, wires, or any other type of support, to illuminate signs is
prohibited. Whenever external illumination is used for a sign, the source of
light shall be located, shielded, and directed in such a manner that the source
is not directly visible from any public street or private residence. In no case
shall the lighting intensity of any sign, whether resulting from internal or
external illumination, exceed seventy five (75) foot-candles when measured with
a standard light meter perpendicular to the face of the sign at a distance
equal to the narrowest dimension of the sign face.
      6.   a. Allowable area for an illuminated attached, ground, gas station
price or pole sign shall be increased by ten percent (10%) if the sign is an
internally illuminated sign as described in subsection C6b of this section.
This increase shall not be counted towards the maximum sign area allowed in the
aggregate sign display calculation under this chapter.
         b.   Internally illuminated signs shall permit light to shine fully
through only the lettering and graphic elements of the sign. The background for
such lettering and graphics shall be opaque or translucent and shall transmit
light at a level substantially less than that transmitted through the lettering
and graphics.
   D.   Signs Shall Not Obstruct: All signs shall be located so as to not
obstruct vision at an intersection or a vehicular entry or exit from the lot on
which the sign is located. No sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained
so as to obstruct a fire escape, exit, window or door opening used as a means
of egress. Nor shall any sign be attached in form, shape or manner such that it
will interfere with any opening required for ventilation. However, this
subsection will not prevent a sign from being erected in front of or covering a
transom window when not in violation of the provisions of the building or fire
prevention regulations that may apply.
   E.   Setbacks: All signs shall be set back at least ten feet (10') from
property lines unless specifically exempted in this chapter. Directional signs
shall not be subject to the ten foot (10') restriction, except at corners.
   F.   Landscaping: All ground, pole, or other signs or sign structures that
originate from or otherwise touch the ground shall be appropriately landscaped
so as to blend with the surrounding area.
   G.   Wind Load And Anchoring:
      1.   All signs, except those attached flat against the wall of a
building, shall be constructed to withstand wind loads as follows:
         a.   For solid signs, thirty (30) pounds per square foot on one face
of the sign.
         b.   For skeleton signs, thirty six (36) pounds per square foot of the
total face area of the letters and other sign surfaces, or ten (10) pounds per
square foot of the gross area of the sign as determined by the overall
dimensions of the sign, whichever is greater.
      2.   The wind loadings quoted in subsection G1 of this section are normal
averages and must be adjusted for areas subject to unusually high velocity
winds, for signs of extraordinary height or wind tunneling effects created by
large buildings.
      3.   Further, no sign shall be suspended by chains or other devices that
will allow the sign to swing due to wind action. Signs shall be anchored to
prevent any lateral movement that would cause wear on supporting members or
connections.
   H.   Compliance With Applicable Regulations: All signs shall comply with all
applicable laws and regulations, including, without limitation, other
applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance and building and electrical
requirements promulgated by the village. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
8-3-10: ADDITIONAL STANDARDS, RESTRICTIONS AND CONDITIONS:
In addition to the general requirements, restrictions or other provisions of
this chapter, the following standards, restrictions and conditions shall be
applicable to the signs listed herein:
   A.   A-Frame Sign:
      1.   An “A-frame sign” (sometimes referred to as a “sandwich board sign”)
shall be referred to herein as an “AFS”. “Operator” signifies the operator of a
particular business within a building located on a commercially zoned property.
      2.   An AFS shall meet the following requirements:
         a.   Only one AFS is permitted per business, although each business
located in a building containing two (2) or more businesses may have an AFS.
(If more than 1 business operates within a single business premises, i.e., a
premises accessed by single front entrance, only 1 AFS is permitted for the
business premises, although the operators of each business within the premises
may jointly apply for a permit for the AFS and may share space on the AFS.)
         b.   An AFS shall be no wider than three feet (3') and no taller than
five feet (5') from the top of the sign structure to the surface upon which it
is placed.
         c.   An AFS shall not be located off premises.
         d.   An AFS shall be located no greater than twenty feet (20') from a
front entrance to the business premises it advertises, and shall not be located
in a place that impedes vehicular movement or visibility or that unreasonably
impedes pedestrian movement.
         e.   An AFS shall be displayed only during the business hours of the
business it advertises.
         f.   An AFS shall either be secured down or sufficiently weighted so
as not to blow out of position, or shall be removed whenever weather conditions
might make it susceptible to blowing out of position.
         g.   An AFS shall not be externally illuminated; provided, that an AFS
shall not be considered to be externally illuminated if a fixture attached to a
building or under a canopy, for example, but which is not specifically directed
at the AFS, happens to cast light on the AFS.
         h.   An AFS shall not count against the allowable square feet of
signage otherwise permitted by this chapter.
         i.   An AFS may have advertising on each side of the AFS. The operator
may change the advertising on the AFS as often as he/she sees fit, so long as
the AFS is used as stated in the definition of an AFS in section
8-3-4 of this chapter.
      3.   The right to display an AFS is extended to operators. Operators are
responsible for securing AFS permits and for otherwise assuring compliance with
this chapter. An operator shall only be required to secure an AFS permit one
time for any particular AFS. Once issued, an AFS permit shall be of unlimited
duration, so long as the AFS is used in conformity with the AFS policy.
   B.   Apartment Identification Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed twenty four (24) square feet in area;
provided, that the sign structure shall not be included when determining sign
area.
      2.   Sign, including structure, shall not exceed a height of five feet
(5').
      3.   Only one sign shall be permitted per frontage.
   C.   Attached Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not extend more than fifteen inches (15") beyond the
vertical plane of the wall or other building feature to which it is attached.
      2.   Sign shall not project more than twenty four inches (24") above the
parapet wall or roofline of the wall where the sign is placed; provided, that
the projection above the parapet wall or roofline shall not exceed the
projection of the sign below the top of the parapet wall or roofline.
      3.   Sign shall not exceed a height of twenty five feet (25').
      4.   No more than three (3) attached signs per frontage shall be
permitted for a single business or for each business located within a single
building.
      5.   All mounting brackets and other hardware used to affix a sign to a
wall shall be concealed by the sign or integrated into the design of the sign.
      6.   Signs within Ballfield shall face inward towards field. No sign
shall be permitted on the reverse, facing outward from the field.
      7.   Signs within Ballfield are excluded from the general restriction of
subsection C4 of this section.
   D.   Banner Signs And Temporary Signs: Banner signs and temporary signs
shall be referred to herein collectively as "B/TS", and both types of sign are
subject to the following standards:
      1.   For purposes of this subsection regarding B/TS, "owner" signifies
the owner of a business property, which includes the land and any buildings.
"Operator" signifies the operator of a particular business within a building
located on a business property.
      2.   A B/TS may be freestanding. If so, the B/TS can be mounted no higher
than four feet (4') from the ground and can be no longer than fifteen feet
(15') or fifteen percent (15%) of the wall space to which it is adjacent. A
freestanding B/TS may not be located off premises. The specific location(s) for
freestanding B/TS shall be specified in the permit application and must be
approved by the reviewing zoning officer. The location(s) must be set back at
least ten feet (10') from any property line and must not create a traffic
hazard by reason of limited visibility or otherwise. A B/TS must be mounted
securely. A B/TS shall not be attached to a utility pole or utility structure.
      3.   A B/TS may be attached to a building. If so, it can be a maximum of
three feet (3') high by ten feet (10') long or fifteen percent (15%) of the
wall space to which it is adjacent, and cannot be mounted so as to extend
higher than the roofline of the building. The specific location(s) on the
building shall be specified in the permit application and must be approved by
the reviewing zoning officer. A B/TS attached to a building must be mounted
securely.
      4.   A B/TS may be externally illuminated.
      5.   A B/TS shall not count against the allowable square feet of signage
otherwise permitted in this chapter.
      6.   The right to display B/TS is extended to owners. Owners are
responsible for securing B/TS permits and for otherwise assuring compliance
with this chapter, not only for themselves and their businesses, if any, but
for all operators and their businesses. Owners may designate an agent to act on
their behalf with respect to B/TS matters, but the owners remain responsible.
If an owner wishes to designate an agent to deal with B/TS matters, the owner
must inform the Zoning Officer of that designation in writing, providing all
contact information for the agent.
      7.   If an owner's building contains two (2) or more operators, it is the
owner's responsibility to allocate among the operators opportunities for them
to display B/TS, consistent with the requirements of the B/TS policy, and to
apply for B/TS permits on behalf of the operators, and to assure the operators'
compliance with the B/TS policy, including abiding by all permit requirements.
The Village will not be in the business of mediating disputes among owners and
operators, or among various operators, concerning any perceived "unfairness" in
the allocation of opportunities to display B/TS. Finally, consistent with the
owner's ultimate responsibility, if an operator violates any B/TS policy, the
owner will be liable for any penalty imposed under this chapter.
      8.   A B/TS requires a permit.
      9.   An owner whose building contains a single business is limited to
four (4) B/TS permits per year per frontage (up to a maximum of 2 frontages).
      10.   An owner whose building contains two (2) or more businesses is
limited to six (6) B/TS permits per year per frontage (up to a maximum of 2
frontages).
      11.   For the purpose of determining that the specific limitation on the
number of B/TS that may be displayed on a particular frontage per year is met,
a freestanding B/TS is assigned to the frontage it faces or to the nearest
adjoining frontage, and an attached B/TS is assigned to the frontage that the
wall on which the B/TS is attached faces.
      12.   No more than one B/TS (either freestanding or attached) may be
displayed on a single frontage at any time. If there are two (2) frontages, one
B/TS (either freestanding or attached) may be displayed on each frontage at the
same time.
      13.   Operators may have grand opening or anniversary signs in accordance
with the terms of this chapter. Grand opening or anniversary sign permits do
not count against the number of B/TS that may be displayed per frontage per
year, even if those signs include banners.
      14.   Permits for B/TS will be for a period of twenty (20) days. A twenty
(20) day period may be divided among multiple operators so long as the division
among operators is specified in the permit application. A period of at least
one week must elapse between the end of one permit period and the beginning of
the next permit period.
      15.   B/TS must be in good condition and maintained at all times. Failure
to comply will be a violation of this chapter and may result in the banner
being removed.
      16.   No B/TS permit may be issued while a feather flag permit is in
effect, or during the one week period after the expiration of a feather flag
permit.
   E.   Change Panel Signs: A change panel sign is designed to permit immediate
change of copy, which may be other than the name of the business. Sign shall
not exceed twenty four (24) square feet. Only one change panel sign will be
allowed per property.
   F.   Church Identification Signs/Church Bulletin Board Signs:
      1.   Signs shall not exceed twenty four (24) square feet in area;
provided, that sign structures shall not be included when determining sign
area.
      2.   Signs along Route 116 are allowed up to sixty (60) square feet in
area.
      3.   Signs may be attached to the building or may be ground signs.
      4.   Ground signs, including structure, shall not exceed a height of six
feet (6').
      5.   Only one church identification sign is allowed on the primary
building. In addition, one church bulletin board sign shall be permitted for
each frontage on a public street.
      6.   Church identification signs attached to the building shall not
extend above the roofline.
   G.   Construction Signs:
      1.   On lots used for residential purposes in R-1 districts, one (1) sign
not exceeding six (6) square feet in area and shall not exceed a height of four
feet (4').
      2.   In agricultural and R-2 districts, and lots not used for residential
purposes in R-1 districts, one (1) sign not exceeding sixteen (16) square feet
in area and a height not exceeding five feet (5') shall be permitted on the
work site of each frontage.
      3.   In commercial and industrial districts, one (1) sign not exceeding
thirty two (32) square feet in area and a height not exceeding five feet (5')
shall be permitted on the work site of each frontage.
      4.   Sign shall not be erected prior to sixty (60) days before the
beginning of construction for which a valid building permit has been issued.
Sign shall be removed upon completion of the work or occupancy of the premises
or building, whichever occurs first.
   H.   Directional Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed four (4) square feet in area and shall not
exceed a height of three and one-half feet (3.5').
      2.   No more than two (2) such signs shall be permitted per entry/exit
unless said entry/exit is divided by a raised median, in which case, each side
of the median shall be treated as a separate entry/exit.
      3.   At least fifty percent (50%) of any directional sign face shall
contain one of the following words, phrases or similar traffic directions:
         a.   "Entrance" or "entrance only".
         b.   "One-way".
         c.   "Exit" or "exit only".
         d.   "Do not enter".
         e.   "No exit" or "no entrance".
         f.   "Right turn only" or "no left turn".
         g.   Directional arrows.
      4.   In the remaining fifty percent (50%) of the sign face, there may be
provided the name of the business or development, or name of the use or
building, or a trademark, logo or similar matter.
   I.   Directory Signs: A directory sign shall conform to the standards
applicable to the type of sign used in providing such directory information.
   J.   Electronic Message Board/LED Signs:
      1.   Length of display or dwell time for electronic multiple message
signs shall be permitted, and the message on said signs may be changed no more
than once every four (4) seconds.
      2.   Automatic dimming must be maintained by light sensing devices or a
scheduled dimming timer that automatically dims the intensity of the light
emitted by the sign during ambient low light and nighttime hours not to exceed
five hundred (500) nits of intensity and during daytime hours not to exceed
five thousand (5,000) nits of intensity.
      3.   Multiple message signs must contain a default design that will
freeze the message in one position if a malfunction occurs.
      4.   Location of multiple message signs must not be within thirty feet
(30') of or the same height as an official traffic control sign that could
confuse the motoring public.
      5.   Maintenance of multiple message signs shall include replacement of
bulbs, LEDs, and pixels and shall be in working and properly illuminating
condition at all times.
      6.   Sign shall not exceed twenty four (24) square feet in area.
   K.   Garage And Yard Sale Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed four (4) square feet in area and shall not
exceed a height of four feet (4').
      2.   Sign shall not be erected prior to three (3) days before the start
of the sale and shall be removed within one day following the sale.
      3.   No more than one sign shall be permitted on premises, and no more
than two (2) signs shall be permitted off premises.
      4.   Sign shall be set back a minimum of five feet (5') from the road
surface.
   L.   Gasoline Service Station Price Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed thirty six (36) square feet in area.
      2.   Sign shall not exceed a height of ten feet (10') where pole signs
are permitted and five feet (5') in all other locations. A price sign may be
attached to and supported by a pole sign.
      3.   Only one price sign shall be permitted on any frontage, and no more
than two (2) price signs shall be permitted per business.
      4.   Credit card or charge plate signs shall be permitted as a part of or
in lieu of gasoline service station price signs, subject, however, to the
location and size standards contained herein.
   M.   Grand Opening; Anniversary Signs:
      1.   Grand opening signs shall be permitted only once for a business and
shall be in place for a period no longer than thirty (30) days.
      2.   Anniversary signs shall be permitted only once for a business in any
calendar year and shall be in place for a period no longer than fourteen (14)
days.
      3.   Flag ropes, pennants, ribbons, flags, streamers, inflatable signs,
balloons, or other air or gas filled devices are allowed during grand opening
and anniversary celebrations. Portable signs may be utilized.
   N.   Ground Signs:
      1.   Signs Along Route 116 Or Its Parallel Frontage Road Or Corner Lot
Parcels That Intersect Parallel Frontage Roads:
         a.   Sign area shall not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the area of
either the surface of the building wall which they are in front of or relate to
or the adjacent building wall. Except as otherwise provided by this chapter,
the maximum square footage of the sign shall be limited in relation to its
height, as follows:
Height No More Than Maximum Square Footage
Height No More Than Maximum Square Footage
5 feet              125 square feet
6 feet              121 square feet
7 feet              116 square feet
8 feet              112 square feet
9 feet              107 square feet
10 feet             103 square feet
11 feet             98 square feet
12 feet             94 square feet
13 feet             89 square feet
14 feet             85 square feet
15 feet             80 square feet
18 feet             80 square feet
 
         b.   Only one ground sign shall be permitted per frontage. No more
than two (2) ground signs shall be permitted for each building; except, that
only one ground sign shall be permitted if used in combination with a pole
sign.
         c.   Sign shall not exceed a height of eighteen feet (18').
         d.   A ground sign shall not be permitted in combination with a pole
sign on the same frontage.
      2.   Signs Not Along Route 116 Or Its Parallel Frontage Road:
         a.   Sign area shall not exceed ten percent (10%) of the area of the
surface of the building wall which they are in front of or relate to.
         b.   Only one ground sign shall be permitted per frontage. No more
than two (2) ground signs shall be permitted for each building.
         c.   Sign shall not exceed a height of five feet (5').
   O.   Hanging Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area.
      2.   Clearance from the sidewalk or other ground surface to the bottom of
the hanging sign shall not be less than seven feet (7').
      3.   No more than one hanging sign shall be permitted per business.
   P.   Home Occupation Signs:
      1.   No more than one home occupation sign shall be permitted per
dwelling unit. In addition, a sign not to exceed one square foot in size shall
be permitted at the entrance to the home occupation if the entrance is not the
main entrance to the building.
      2.   Sign shall not exceed two (2) square feet in area; it shall be
attached to the wall of the residential unit, no higher than six feet (6')
above grade. Lettering shall not exceed six inches (6") in height.
      3.   Sign shall reference the home occupation on the same premises.
   Q.   Off Premises Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed eighty (80) square feet in area;
      2.   Sign shall not exceed a height of eighteen feet (18'). The sign's
height measurement shall include the base, apron, or support structure, and
shall be measured from the lowest point of the same to the highest element of
the sign or its structure;
      3.   Sign shall not exceed a width of ten feet (10'), inclusive of sign
structure and supports;
      4.   Sign shall not be located within one hundred fifty feet (150') of a
residential property, school, park, or place of worship;
      5.   Sign shall not be erected further than one hundred fifty feet (150')
from Route 116;
      6.   Sign shall not be erected within one thousand feet (1,000') of an
off premises sign on the same side of the roadway;
      7.   Sign shall not be illuminated; and
      8.   Sign shall not use automatic changeable technology or contain moving
parts.
   R.   On Site Informational Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area, but may be
increased up to a maximum of twenty four (24) square feet in area by written
authority of the Zoning Officer after review of the public necessity and/or
safety purpose of the sign.
      2.   Sign shall not exceed a height of three feet (3') in any location
within twenty feet (20') of a public right-of-way or within ten feet (10') of
any property line, nor shall a sign elsewhere on the lot or premises exceed a
height of four feet (4').
      3.   Credit card or charge plate signs shall not be construed as on site
informational signs.
   S.   Permanent Window Signs: Permanent window signs, including borders,
shall not cover more than a total of sixty percent (60%) of the combined area
of the window or glass door to which they are applied.
   T.   Pole Signs:
      1.   A pole sign shall only be permitted for use by businesses located on
Route 116 or its parallel frontage road.
      2.   Except as otherwise provided herein, no advertising other than a
registered trademark, copyrighted logo, or name of a business shall be
permitted on any pole sign. More than one (1) business may advertise on the
same pole sign.
      3.   Notwithstanding the general restriction of subsection T2 of this
section, a gasoline service station price sign or a “drive-through” sign may be
attached to and supported by the one (1) permissible pole sign.
      4.   Only one (1) pole sign shall be permitted per building, even if the
building contains multiple tenants.
      5.   Sign shall not exceed a height of twenty five feet (25').
      6.   Sign shall not exceed forty (40) square feet in area. An attached
gasoline service station price sign shall not be included in this forty (40)
square foot restriction, but a pole sign and attached “drive-through” sign
shall not exceed this forty (40) square foot restriction in the aggregate.
      7.   A pole sign shall not be permitted in combination with a ground sign
on the same frontage, unless: a) the pole sign is located on a lot bordering
more than one (1) street, one of which is the Route 116 parallel frontage road
and b) the pole sign is within the frontage of both streets on which the lot
borders.
      8.   No pole sign shall have more than two (2) poles, and no single pole
on a two (2) pole sign shall have a cross sectional area at any point greater
than one hundred forty (140) square inches. If the pole sign is supported by
only one pole, that pole shall not have a cross sectional area greater than two
hundred ten (210) square inches.
      9.   Sign within Ballfield shall face inward towards field. No sign shall
be permitted on the reverse, facing outward from the field.
   U.   Political Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area and shall not
exceed a height of four feet (4').
      2.   Sign shall be set back a minimum of five feet (5') from the edge of
the roadway.
      3.   Signs may be placed on residential property during any period of
time.
   V.   Pylon Signs:
      1.   Sign shall be permitted only for shopping center developments
consisting of a single lot at least fifteen (15) acres in size, or multiple
lots totaling at least fifteen (15) acres in size that are part of one
development and are subject to an annexation agreement with the Village.
      2.   Only one sign shall be permitted per shopping center development.
      3.   Sign shall not exceed three hundred (300) square feet in area and
shall not exceed a height of thirty feet (30').
      4.   No advertising other than the name of the shopping center
development and its related businesses shall be permitted on a pylon sign. No
advertising for businesses that are off premises is permitted, except for
advertisements by or for nonprofit organizations.
      5.   No pylon sign shall be supported by more than two (2) poles, and no
single pole on a two (2) pole pylon sign shall have a cross sectional area at
any point greater than one hundred forty (140) square inches. If the pylon sign
is supported by only one pole, that pole shall not have a cross sectional area
greater than two hundred ten (210) square inches. The foregoing pole size
restrictions apply solely to sign supports and shall not apply to a skirt or
other nonstructural material surrounding the sign support.
   W.   Real Estate Signs:
      1.   No more than one sign shall be permitted on each frontage; except,
that one additional open house sign is permitted for a period of three (3) days
per open house, beginning two (2) days before the open house.
      2.   Sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area in residential
districts, or thirty two (32) square feet in area in agricultural, commercial
or industrial districts.
      3.   Sign shall be removed within seven (7) days after sale closing or
lease initiation date.
      4.   Sign shall not exceed a height of four feet (4') in residential
districts, or a height of five feet (5') in agricultural, commercial or
industrial districts.
   X.   Real Estate Directional Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area and shall not
exceed a height of four feet (4').
      2.   Sign shall be removed within one day following the rental, lease or
sale.
      3.   No more than two (2) signs shall be permitted off premises.
      4.   Sign shall be set back a minimum of five feet (5') from the edge of
the roadway.
   Y.   Special Signs:
      1.   A special sign may be in the form of a banner. Signs/banners shall
be limited to four (4) per year per frontage (up to a maximum of 2 frontages).
Permits will be for a period of twenty (20) days. Permits may be strung
together in successive twenty (20) day periods, but each twenty (20) day period
counts against the annual limitations.
      2.   Sign, either singly or in the aggregate, shall not exceed thirty two
(32) square feet in area and shall not exceed a height of five feet (5').
   Z.   Subdivision Identification Signs:
      1.   Sign shall not exceed thirty two (32) square feet in area; provided,
that the sign structure shall not be included when determining sign area.
      2.   Sign, including structure, shall not exceed a height of five feet
(5').
      3.   Only one sign shall be permitted per entrance road.
      4.   A homeowners' association shall be responsible for the maintenance
of each sign.
   AA.   Subdivision Real Estate Signs:
      1.   Only one sign shall be permitted per subdivision.
      2.   Sign shall not exceed thirty two (32) square feet in area and shall
not exceed a height of five feet (5').
      3.   Sign shall be removed within thirty (30) days after the sale of
ninety percent (90%) of the homes or lots advertised in the subdivision.
   BB.   Temporary Window Signs:
      1.   The combined area of temporary window signs and permanent window
signs shall not exceed sixty percent (60%) of the window to which they are
applied.
      2.   The combined area of temporary door signs and permanent door signs
shall not exceed thirty percent (30%) of the door to which they are applied.
   CC.   Vending Machine Signs:
      1.   Sign area shall not be included in the aggregate sign display area
limitations of this chapter.
      2.   Sign shall not exceed a height of six and one-half feet (6.5').
      3.   No more than three (3) signs shall be permitted per business.
      4.   Vending machine signs shall only identify vended products.
   DD.   Village Provided Signs:
      1.   The village board may, at its discretion, provide for signs to be
erected on private property for the purpose of identifying and providing
direction to businesses that are not located on Route 116, but whose access
roads intersect Route 116 in the village. Village provided signs are allowed in
commercial and industrial district per IDOT's requirement and cannot be closer
than every three hundred feet (300') or exceed eight feet by ten feet (8' x
10'). They require a permit from IDOT with written permission from the property
owner.
      2.   The village board may erect sign structures that provide multiple
sign slots that can be filled by the owners of approved businesses. One sign
will be permitted per approved business. The design will be provided by the
village, and the support structure will be maintained by the village. Business
owners/proprietors will be responsible for maintaining individual sign panels,
and panels may be removed by the village board if they fall into disrepair.
      3.   Only businesses located within the village or the one and one-half
(11/2) mile planning area of the village may apply for a sign space. Upon
receipt of an application for sign space of this type, the village board will
make the determination if the business should be provided sign space. The
village board will make this determination taking into consideration the nature
of the business and the importance of the sign to the economic viability of
that business. The owner/proprietor has the right to provide written or oral
testimony to the village board on his own behalf. The village board will decide
by a simple majority vote. The decision of the village board will be final.
      4.   The village board may, at any future time, remove any or all of the
village provided sign structures, without cause, at which time the advertising
panels will be returned to the respective businesses.
   EE.   Pole Banners: Temporary pole banners placed by the village or with the
consent of the village board of trustees celebrating and promoting the
Germantown Hills community, civic organizations or public events subject to the
following conditions:
      1.   A pole banner may be a maximum of eighteen (18) square feet.
      2.   A pole banner may be attached solely to a streetlight or utility
pole approved by the village board of trustees.
      3.   A minimum of sixty five percent (65%) of the area of a pole banner
sign must be dedicated to artwork or text which is consistent with the purposes
for which pole banners may be displayed. The remainder shall be limited to the
business name of the sponsor, the sponsor's logo, the year in which the sponsor
was established and the sponsor's web address.
      4.   No permit or fee shall be required for pole banners displayed by the
village.
      5.   No pole banner may be displayed without the Village Board of
Trustees' prior approval of the design and location of the pole banner.
      6.   The duration for which a pole banner may be displayed shall be
ninety (90) days, except as otherwise determined by the Village Board of
Trustees.
   FF.   Utility Improvement Signs:
      1.   Sign shall be made of plastic, wood or metal and may possess colors,
characters, letters, illustrations or ornamentations.
      2.   Sign is permitted in residential, commercial or industrial zoning
districts.
      3.   One sign not exceeding thirty two (32) square feet and a height not
exceeding six feet (6') shall be permitted at each entrance to the subdivision.
Sign shall be placed at least ten feet (10') off of all property lines.
      4.   Sign shall not be erected prior to sixty (60) days before the
beginning of construction of the utility improvement project. Sign shall be
removed within twelve (12) months of the beginning of construction of the
utility improvement project.
      5.   Written documentation showing the property owner's permission for
the sign to be temporarily placed on the owner's property must accompany the
application for permit described in subsection
8-3-5B of this chapter.
   GG.   Feather Flags:
      1.   Owners And Operators: For purposes of this subsection regarding
feather flags, "owner" signifies the owner of a business property, which
includes the land and any buildings. "Operator" signifies the operator of a
particular business within a building located on a business property.
      2.   Permitted Districts: Feather flags are permitted in commercial and
industrial districts. They may also be used in residential districts on
properties with non-profit operations, such as schools and churches.
      3.   Size Limitations: Each feather flag shall not exceed thirty two (32)
square feet in total area, and shall not exceed fifteen feet (15') tall.
      4.   Placement: Feather flags must be located outside of the public
right-of-way and any clear vision triangle, as determined by the Superintendent
of Public Works.
      5.   Right To Display: The right to display feather flags is extended to
owners. Owners are responsible for securing feather flag permits and for
otherwise assuring compliance with this chapter, not only for themselves and
their businesses, if any, but for all operators and their businesses. Owners
may designate an agent to act on their behalf with respect to feather flag
matters, but the owners remain responsible. If an owner wishes to designate an
agent to deal with feather flag matters, the owner must inform the Zoning
Officer of that designation in writing, providing all contact information for
the agent.
      6.   Responsibilities: If an owner's building contains two (2) or more
operators, it is the owner's responsibility to allocate among the operators
opportunities for them to display feather flags, consistent with the
requirements of this chapter, and to apply for feather flag permits on behalf
of the operators, and to assure the operators' compliance with this chapter,
including abiding by all permit requirements. The Village will not be in the
business of mediating disputes among owners and operators, or among various
operators, concerning any perceived "unfairness" in the allocation of
opportunities to display feather flags. Finally, consistent with the owner's
ultimate responsibility, if an operator violates any part of this chapter, the
owner will be liable for any penalty imposed under this chapter.
      7.   Minimum Distance: All feather flags must be a minimum of fifteen
feet (15') apart.
      8.   Off Premises: Feather flags may not be located off premises.
      9.   Permits:
         a.   No feather flag sign shall be erected or installed except
pursuant to a permit issued by the Zoning Officer.
         b.   Permits for feather flags will be for a period of twenty (20)
days. A twenty (20) day period may be divided among multiple operators so long
as the division among operators is specified in the permit application. A
period of at least one week must elapse between the end of one permit period
and the beginning of the next permit period.
         c.   An owner whose building contains a single business is limited to
four (4) feather flag permits per year per frontage (up to a maximum of 2
frontages).
         d.   An owner whose building contains two (2) or more businesses is
limited to six (6) feather flag permits per year per frontage (up to a maximum
of 2 frontages).
         e.   No feather flag permit may be issued while a B/TS permit is in
effect, or during the one week period after the expiration of a B/TS permit.
         f.   The feather flag permit cost is ten dollars ($10.00) per permit.
      10.   Flag Maintenance: Displayed feather flag signs must be in good
condition and maintained at all times. Failure to comply will be a violation of
this chapter and may result in the flag being removed.
      11.   Illumination: A feather flag may be externally illuminated.
      12.   Signage Allowed Exception: A feather flag shall not count against
the allowable square feet of signage otherwise permitted in this chapter.
   HH.   Billboard Signs:
      1.   A billboard sign shall only be permitted on properties located on
Route 116.
      2.   A billboard sign shall be permitted only for property consisting of
a single lot at least fifteen (15) acres or more in size, is subject to an
annexation agreement with the Village, and is pre-existing prior to the
approval of the annexation agreement.
      3.   No billboard sign may be expanded to a size or height beyond that
which exists as of the date of the annexation agreement approving such
billboard sign.
      4.   A billboard sign shall remain in the same location it occupies as of
the date of the annexation agreement approving such billboard sign.
      5.   No more than two billboard signs shall be permitted per parcel.
      6.   Billboard signs shall comply with all local, state, and federal
ordinances, laws, statutes, and regulations.
   II.   Summary Of Standards: The following summary is provided solely as a
convenience and shall not be construed to modify the specific standards set
forth in this section:

8-3-11: AGGREGATE SIGN DISPLAY AREA LIMITATIONS IN COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL
DISTRICTS:
All permitted signs in commercial and industrial districts shall be governed by
the following standards: (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
   A.   Maximum Display Area:
      1.   Single Walls: Subject to the limitations of an individual sign area
set out in section
8-3-10 of this chapter, the maximum aggregate sign display area (for all types
of signs not otherwise exempt) for a single side of a building shall be limited
to fifteen percent (15%) of the total surface area of the wall (including
windows and doors) of the building occupied by the business as its business
premises. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011; amd. Ord. 743, 2-26-2015)
   B.   Exclusions: The following types of signs shall not be included in the
aggregate square footage limitations contained in this section:
      All signs permitted in agricultural or residential districts.
      Construction signs.
      Directional signs.
      Gasoline service station price signs.
      Grand opening/anniversary signs.
      On site informational signs.
      Pylon signs.
      Real estate signs.
      Special signs.
      Temporary window signs.
      Vending machine signs.
   C.   Multiple Frontages: When a business has more than one display frontage,
the restrictions on the number of signs and sign area shall comply with
subsections A and B of this section, subject to the following additional
restrictions:
      1.   No signs permitted by one frontage may be transferred to another
frontage.
      2.   Double faced signs erected on or near the corner of a building or
parcel so as to be equally visible from each frontage shall be counted as part
of the permitted sign area for each frontage.
   D.   Multiple Occupants: In buildings with multiple business occupants, each
occupant shall be allotted a sign area based upon the display frontage
proportional to the ratio of total floor area in the building. Common areas
shall not be included in this calculation. Every occupant shall be allowed a
minimum sign area of sixteen (16) square feet.
      1.   Subject to the restrictions in subsection A1 of this section, if the
number of business occupants times the minimum sign area per occupant results
in a sum larger than one hundred twenty five (125), then the maximum aggregate
sign display area for a single side of a building shall be the larger sum. In
no case, however, shall the sum exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the wall area
nor shall the area of any single sign exceed one hundred twenty five (125)
square feet.
      2.   Subject to the restrictions in subsection A2 of this section, if two
(2) times the allowable area determined in subsection D1 of this section
results in a sum larger than two hundred fifty (250), then the maximum
aggregate sign display area for all sides of a single building shall be the
larger sum.
      3.   Any sign that identifies one or more businesses and is attached to a
building that contains multiple businesses shall be located in close proximity
to the business(es) that it identifies.
   E.   Signs With Two Faces: For all signs with two (2) faces, the faces shall
be parallel and located no more than two feet (2') apart. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
8-3-12: NONCONFORMING SIGNS:
   A.   Every sign constructed, installed, erected, relocated or altered after
the effective date hereof shall conform to its provisions. A sign that fails to
conform to the requirements of this chapter, or to come into compliance within
the time allotted by this section, is an unlawful sign.
   B.   All nonconforming signs (including subdivision identification signs)
must come into compliance with this chapter if they are replaced, relocated or
subject to a repair or alteration which constitutes at least fifty percent
(50%) of the value of the sign at the time of the repair.
   C.   Every sign in existence on the effective date hereof or the effective
date of any amendment hereto that does not conform to the provisions of this
chapter or such amendment shall be removed, replaced, relocated or altered so
as to conform with the provisions of this chapter and any amendment within one
year. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011)
8-3-13: UNLAWFUL SIGNS:
   A.   Existing Unlawful Signs:
      1.   Every sign in existence on the effective date hereof which was
unlawful under the prior version of this chapter and which continues to be
unlawful under the present version of this chapter shall be removed, replaced,
relocated or altered so as to conform with the provisions of this chapter
within six (6) months after its effective date.
      2.   Upon the effective date hereof, the zoning officer shall identify
all unlawful signs subject to this subsection. The zoning officer shall then
provide notice, in writing, by certified mail to the owner of the unlawful
sign, or the owner of the property on which the unlawful sign is located, or
both. The notice shall describe the sign and state the reasons why it is
unlawful under this subsection. Finally, the notice shall state the compliance
requirements of this subsection. If any unlawful sign is not brought into
compliance as required by this subsection, it shall be deemed a violation of
this chapter, and such owner will be subject to the penalty provisions of this
chapter.
   B.   Violations And Enforcement: As to all situations not covered by
subsection A of this section, it is hereby declared to be a violation of this
chapter for any person to allow the existence of an unlawful sign. The zoning
officer may, after inspection, declare a sign to be unlawful and shall provide
notice, in writing, by personal delivery or certified mail to the owner of the
unlawful sign or the owner of the property on which the unlawful sign is
located, or both. The notice shall describe the sign and state the reasons for
the zoning officer’s declaration and shall order the removal, repair,
relocation or alteration of the unlawful sign.
      1.   In the case of the following signs that are exempt from the permit
requirements, the person to whom the notice is sent or delivered shall bring
the unlawful sign into compliance within twenty-four (24) hours of receiving
the notice:
         a.   Garage and yard sale signs;
         b.   Political signs;
         c.   Real estate signs;
         d.   Temporary window signs;
         e.   Vending machine signs; and
         f.   Village provided signs.
      2.   In all other cases, the person to whom the notice is sent or
delivered shall be given no less than ten (10) and no more than twenty (20)
days in which to comply with the order, except as follows:
         a.   If, in the discretion of the Zoning Officer, compliance will
reasonably take more than 20 days, the person to whom notice is sent may be
given additional time, but no more than 30 days;
         b.   If the person to whom the notice is sent has violated this
section within _____ months prior to the current violation, then the notice
shall require immediate compliance.
      3.   If an unlawful sign is not brought into compliance as directed by
the zoning officer, it shall be deemed a violation of this chapter, and such
owner will be subject to the penalty provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Removal Of Signs Required After Business No Longer Conducted: A sign
shall be removed by the owner or lessee of the premises upon which the sign is
located when the business which the sign advertises no longer is conducted on
the premises. If the owner or lessee fails to remove the sign, the zoning
officer shall notify the owner or lessee in writing, and allow thirty (30) days
for removal of such sign. Upon failure of the owner or lessee to comply with
the notice, the zoning officer may remove the sign at the cost and expense of
the owner or lessee.
   D.   Removal By Village; Costs: Where a sign has not been removed, repaired,
relocated, or altered pursuant to notice requiring the same by the zoning
officer, the zoning officer is hereby authorized to cause removal of said sign,
and any cost or expense incidental thereto shall be paid by the owner and/or
other person in control of the premises on which said sign is located. Such
costs, if not reimbursed, shall constitute a lien against the premises upon
which the sign is located.
   E.   Inspections: The zoning officer is empowered to enter or inspect any
building, structure, or premises in the village for the purpose of inspection
of a sign and its structural and electrical connections to ensure compliance
with all applicable codes and ordinances. Such inspections shall be carried out
during business hours unless an emergency exists. (Ord. 688, 7-21-2011; amd.
Ord. 833, 1-21-2020; Ord. 867, 7-20-2023)
8-3-14: VARIANCES:
   A.   Application For Variance; Fee: A request for a variance of this chapter
shall be submitted to the zoning officer on forms provided by the zoning
officer. The application fee for a variance shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) which shall be in addition to the fee for the sign.
   B.   Hearing: The zoning officer shall forward all information to the zoning
