place, a road, a thoroughfare, or by other appropriate name. Streets are
identified according to type of use, by the major thoroughfare plan as follows:
         Collector: A street generally meant to serve secondary traffic
generators and provide access to private property. Collector streets collect
traffic in residential areas and provide a connection between minor arterial,
other collector, and local streets.
         Local: A street primarily designed to provide access to abutting
property. Local streets provide direct access between private property and
collector streets.
         Minor Arterial: Streets that interconnect or augment traffic flow from
and between principal arterial streets. Such streets accommodate trips of
moderate length and provide access between smaller streets. Sante Fe Trail and
Lourdes Road are examples of minor arterial streets.
         Principal Arterial: Generally refers to Illinois Route 116. The term
represents a street that connects urban cities and rural areas, carries high
volumes of traffic, and provides a continuous route over a long distance. Such
streets provide little, if any, access to private property.
      STRUCTURE: Anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on the
surface of the ground or underground, or affixed to something having a fixed
location on the surface of the ground.
      SUBDIVIDE, SUBDIVISION: Any division or development of any part, lot,
area, or tract of land by the subdivider into lots two (2) or more in number
for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of conveyance, transfer,
improvement, or sale, with the appurtenant streets, alleys and easements,
dedicated or intended to be dedicated to public use or for the use of the
purchasers or owners within the part, lot, area or tract divided. The division
of land into lots two (2) or more in number, each lot with area greater than
five (5) acres, and not involving any new street, alley, easement, or other
means of access, shall not be deemed a subdivision for the purpose of this
title.
      SUBDIVIDER: Any person or entity who subdivides.
      USE: Specific purposes as permitted by the zoning ordinance of the
village of Germantown Hills for which land, a structure or premises is
designed, arranged, or intended, or for which it is or may be occupied or
maintained. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
CHAPTER 3
PROCEDURES
SECTION:
10-3-1: Preliminary Considerations
10-3-2: Preapplication
10-3-3: Preliminary Plat Approval
10-3-4: Final Plat Approval
10-3-5: Boundary Map
10-3-6: Commercial Pad Sites Exempt
10-3-7: Abbreviated Procedure For Small Subdivisions
10-3-8: Commercial Planned Developments And Residential Planned Unit
Developments
10-3-9: Donation Of Land Or Contribution Of Cash For School Purposes
10-3-10: Contribution Of Cash For Park And Recreation Purposes
10-3-1: PRELIMINARY CONSIDERATIONS:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   No land which is located within the village or which is located
entirely or in part within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the village shall,
after the effective date hereof, be subdivided and filed for record, nor any
street laid out, nor any improvements made to the land until the plat or plats
of the subdivision or development plan for a commercial planned development or
for a residential planned unit development shall have been certified to and
approved by action as specified herein.
      2.   No land shall be subdivided or a plan developed for any use unless
access to the land over streets exists or will be provided by the subdivider or
developer.
   B.   Application For Approval:
      1.   Subdivision Plat: A subdivider desiring approval of a plat of any
land lying within the jurisdiction of this title shall submit a written
application therefor to the planning commission. Such application shall be in
accordance with the procedures of section
10-3-3 of this chapter and shall be accompanied by the information set forth in
section
10-6-2 of this title.
      2.   Commercial Planned Development Or Residential Planned Unit
Development: A developer desiring approval of a development plan for land
within the jurisdiction of this title shall submit a written application
therefor to the planning commission. Such application shall be in accordance
with the procedures of subsection
10-3-8A of this chapter and shall be accompanied by the information set forth
in subsection
10-6-4A or 10-6-5A of this title. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-3-2: PREAPPLICATION:
In order to conserve time, effort, and expense, the subdivider or developer
shall consult with the planning commission before submitting an application as
described in subsection
10-3-1B1 or B2 of this chapter. The subdivider or developer shall have
available at this consultation the plans and data specified in section
10-6-1 of this title. The planning commission and the subdivider or developer
shall discuss the application requirements of section
10-6-2 or subsection
10-6-4A or 10-6-5A of this title, as the case may be. The planning commission
and the subdivider or developer shall also discuss requirements for streets;
school and recreational sites; shopping centers; community facilities;
sanitation, water supply and drainage; bike/walkways; and relationship to other
developments, existing and proposed, in the vicinity, as applicable. (Ord. 675,
2-24-2011)
10-3-3: PRELIMINARY PLAT APPROVAL:
   A.   Preparation Of Plat: The subdivider shall, after the preapplication
procedure of section
10-3-2 of this chapter, cause to be prepared a preliminary plat, together with
improvement plans and other supplementary material as specified in section
10-6-2 of this title.
   B.   Submission Of Plat: Nine (9) copies of the preliminary plat and
supplementary material shall be submitted to the planning commission with
written application for the approval of the preliminary plat at least ten (10)
days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. The application
shall be accompanied by a check or money order, payable to the village, in the
amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus six dollars ($6.00) for each lot
over thirty three (33) lots. Such amount shall be paid into the general
corporate fund of the village to offset the cost of professional review of the
plat.
   C.   Planning Commission Action:
      1.   Review Of Preliminary Plat: The planning commission shall review the
preliminary plat and supplementary material for conformity with village
ordinances, including the official map. The planning commission may negotiate
with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable and the kind and extent of
improvements to be made by the subdivider.
      2.   Notification To School Board: Within three (3) business days after a
preliminary plat is submitted for approval, the governing body, through the
planning commission, shall notify the president of the school board of each
school district in which any of the subdivided land is located that the
preliminary plat has been submitted for approval and that it is available for
inspection. The notice shall also give the date, time, and place of the hearing
on approval or disapproval of the preliminary plat. The notice shall be served
by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal delivery. Failure
to notify the school board as required by this subsection C2 does not
invalidate any plat 1 .
      3.   Public Hearing: The planning commission shall conduct a public
hearing on the preliminary plat. Notice of the public hearing shall be
published in a newspaper of general circulation in the village not less than
fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the hearing.
      4.   Planning Commission Approve: The planning commission shall approve
or disapprove the preliminary plat within ninety (90) days from the date of
application or the filing by the applicant of the last item of required
supplementary material, whichever date is later, unless such time is extended
by mutual consent. If the preliminary plat is approved, the planning commission
shall furnish to the applicant a written statement of approval. Because a
preliminary plat approved by the planning commission must still be approved by
the governing body, the planning commission shall forward to the governing body
the preliminary plat and supplementary material submitted by the applicant, and
also a copy of the written statement of approval.
      5.   Planning Commission Disapprove: If the preliminary plat is
disapproved, the planning commission shall furnish to the applicant a written
statement setting forth the reasons for disapproval, specifying with
particularity the aspects in which the proposed preliminary plat fails to
comply with village ordinances, including the official map. Upon disapproval,
the applicant may either appeal the decision to the governing body, or may
submit a revised preliminary plat to the planning commission, attempting to
cure the deficiencies which resulted in disapproval. Submission of a revised
preliminary plat triggers a new ninety (90) day review period as specified in
subsection C4 of this section. If the applicant elects to appeal, written
notice of the appeal shall be directed to the village clerk within thirty (30)
days after the date of the written disapproval of the planning commission, and
the applicant shall attach a copy of the written disapproval to the notice of
appeal. The applicant shall also deliver a copy of the notice of appeal to the
planning commission with a request that the planning commission forward the
governing body the preliminary plat and supplementary material submitted by the
applicant.
   D.   Governing Body Action:
      1.   If the preliminary plat is approved by the planning commission, the
governing body shall approve or disapprove the preliminary plat within thirty
(30) days after its next regular stated meeting following the action of the
planning commission.
      2.   If the preliminary plat is disapproved by the planning commission
and the applicant files a notice of appeal in proper form, the governing body
shall approve or disapprove the preliminary plat within sixty five (65) days
after its next regular stated meeting following the receipt of the notice of
appeal.
      3.   The governing body shall review the preliminary plat and
supplementary material for conformity with village ordinances, including the
official map. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
      4.   If the governing body approves a preliminary plat, it shall direct
the plat officer to sign the preliminary plat and certificate as set forth in
chapter 7 of this title. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
      5.   If the governing body disapproves a preliminary plat, its order or
resolution shall state the reasons for the disapproval, specifying with
particularity the aspects in which the proposed preliminary plat fails to
comply with village ordinances, including the official map.
   E.   Interpretation Of Plat Approval: Approval of the preliminary plat by
the governing body shall not qualify the plat for recording. Approval of the
preliminary plat by the governing body shall be construed to be an expression
of approval of the general layout submitted as a guide to the preparation of
the final plat and to be assurance to the subdivider that the final plat will
be approved if it conforms to the terms of the approved preliminary plat and
all village ordinances. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
 
Notes
1 1. 765 ILCS 205/2.
10-3-4: FINAL PLAT APPROVAL:
   A.   Application For Approval: Application for approval of a final plat
shall be made in writing to the village clerk not later than one year after
approval of the preliminary plat by the governing body. The application must be
supported by such drawings, specifications and bond as may be necessary to
demonstrate compliance with all requirements of Illinois law and village
ordinances, including conformity with the preliminary plat and compliance with
appropriate sections of chapters 5 and 6 of this title.
   B.   Stages Of Approval: The applicant may elect to have final approval of a
geographic part or parts of the approved preliminary plat, and may delay
application for approval of other parts until a later date or dates beyond one
year with the approval of the governing body, provided all facilities required
to serve the part or parts for which final approval is sought have been
provided. In such case, only such part or parts of the preliminary plat as have
received final approval shall be recorded.
   C.   Governing Body Action:
      1.   When an applicant for approval of a final plat has supplied all
drawings, maps and other documents required by this title to be furnished in
support thereof, and if all such material meets all village requirements, the
governing body shall approve the proposed final plat within sixty (60) days
from the date of filing the last required document or other paper or within
sixty (60) days from the date of filing the application for approval of the
final plat, whichever date is later. The applicant and the governing body may
mutually agree to extend the sixty (60) day period.
      2.   If the governing body disapproves the final plat, its order or
resolution shall state the reasons for the disapproval, specifying with
particularity the aspects in which the proposed final plat fails to comply with
village ordinances, including the official map. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
   D.   Plat Officer Signature; Filing Plat: If the governing body approves the
final plat, it shall direct the plat officer to sign the final plat and
certificate as set forth in chapter 7 of this title. Within sixty (60) days
after the plat officer has signed the final plat, the applicant shall file the
plat with the county recorder, and if not so filed, the plat shall have no
validity and shall not be recorded without recertification by the plat officer.
One reproducible copy of the final plat shall be filed with the plat officer.
(Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
10-3-5: BOUNDARY MAP:
   A.   A parcel may be subdivided by use of a boundary map in the following
instances:
      1.   Any parcel of land may be divided into two (2) parts, either of
which part is less than five (5) acres, for the purpose of ownership transfer
or building development. After one such boundary map dividing a tract of land
in one ownership as of June 15, 1978, has been signed by the plat officer, he
shall not sign another boundary map dividing said land. Further division of
said land shall be recorded only by means of a map or plat of subdivision as
provided in this title, which map or plat of subdivision shall include the
parcel previously divided off by a boundary map.
      2.   The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining
and contiguous land that does not create an additional lot.
      3.   The conveyance or dedication of land for highway or other public
purposes or the vacation of land dedicated for a public use.
   B.   A subdivision described herein may be subdivided by recording with the
county recorder an adequate boundary map made thereof by a registered Illinois
land surveyor. Such boundary map shall include all of the following:
      1.   All permanent structures within thirty feet (30') of an existing or
proposed lot line.
      2.   A certification of the county clerk that there are no delinquent or
unpaid general taxes and/or special assessments against the lands described on
this boundary map.
      3.   A signature of the plat officer.
      4.   Shall be drawn with waterproof, nonfading, black ink on tracing
cloth or good quality tracing paper, eighteen inches by twenty four inches (18"
x 24") or larger in six inch (6") multiples.
No such boundary map shall be entitled to be recorded or have validity until it
has been signed by the plat officer. The plat officer shall keep a record and
copy of such boundary maps.
   C.   A parcel subdivided by use of a boundary map shall not be subject to
the platting requirements of this code. However, such subdivision shall be
subject to and comply with all other provisions of this code. The application
for approval of the boundary map shall be accompanied by a check or money
order, payable to the village, in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Such amount shall be paid into the general corporate fund of the village to
offset the cost of professional review of the plat. Should the village deem it
necessary or desirable to engage legal counsel to review the boundary map, the
applicant shall submit an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00) to offset
the cost of such additional review. (Ord. 735, 7-24-2014)
10-3-6: COMMERCIAL PAD SITES EXEMPT:
The following division of land shall not be considered a subdivision for
purposes of this title, so long as all the following requirements are met:
   A.   The division of land relates to a larger parcel of land that is zoned C
commercial under the village zoning ordinance.
   B.   The larger parcel of land that is zoned C commercial:
      1.   Is a shopping center development, or part of a shopping center
development, that qualifies for a pylon sign under subsection
8-3-10V of this code; or
      2.   Is at least one acre in size, prior to the conveyance of any
commercial pads as provided in this section.
   C.   The division of land is for the purpose of a conveyance by the shopping
center developer or commercial property owner of a pad site to a commercial
user, which pad site either:
      1.   Has the same dimensions as the "footprint" of a proposed commercial
building; or
      2.   Has no more than an additional twenty five percent (25%) of the
square footage of a proposed commercial building, and the additional square
footage is planted and maintained in grass or other landscaping materials and
contains no use other than a commercial trash receptacle or HVAC components.
   D.   The proposed commercial building to be constructed on the pad site will
either:
      1.   Directly adjoin, or be located no more than one foot (1') distant
from, an existing commercial building on the larger parcel of land, which
existing commercial building is owned by the shopping center developer,
commercial property owner, or other commercial pad owner. If the proposed
commercial building will not directly adjoin an existing commercial building,
the gap of no more than one foot (1') must be closed off by the proposed owner
of the pad site in a manner that is aesthetically compatible with the facades
of the two (2) buildings so as to restrict access of any description through
the gap; or
      2.   If the proposed commercial building does not directly adjoin an
existing building and is not located within one foot (1') distance from an
existing commercial building, the buildings may be set apart as long as the two
(2) buildings are at least five feet (5') apart and the facades of the two (2)
buildings are aesthetically compatible.
   E.   The shopping center developer or commercial property owner must certify
to the village that he/she/it will continue to be fully responsible for
ensuring compliance with the following requirements as they pertain to the pad
site, as though the developer or owner continued to own the pad site as part of
the development: public and private access, utility easement access, and site
drainage.
   F.   The shopping center developer or commercial property owner must certify
to the village that he/she/it will continue to be fully responsible for
ensuring compliance with the following requirements of the village zoning
ordinance as they pertain to the pad site, as though the developer or owner
continued to own the pad site as part of the development: public and private
access, off street parking space, and off street loading space.
   G.   The proposed owner of the pad site must certify to the village that he/
she/it will comply with all provisions of the village zoning ordinance that are
not rendered inapplicable by virtue of the proposed construction of a building
so as to occupy all or nearly all of the pad site. (Examples of provisions
rendered inapplicable are maximum building coverage, yard requirements, off
street parking space, and off street loading space.) Building setback
requirements from streets or other rights of way continue to apply to the
siting of the proposed commercial building upon the pad site as though the
shopping center developer or commercial property owner continued to own the pad
site as part of the development.
   H.   If the requirements of this section are met, the village board will
authorize the plat officer to give written approval, in an appropriate form, to
a conveyance of the pad site by metes and bounds description from the shopping
center developer or commercial property owner to the commercial user. (Ord.
746, 4-23-2015)
10-3-7: ABBREVIATED PROCEDURE FOR SMALL SUBDIVISIONS:
   A.   The subdivider of any proposed subdivision having four (4) or fewer
lots fronting on an existing street complying with the standards imposed by
this title may, at the discretion of the planning commission, submit a final
plat, together with any construction plans deemed necessary, for direct
consideration and approval by the plat officer without following the steps
which ordinarily precede the submission of a final plat.
   B.   The subdivider of any proposed subdivision having four (4) or fewer
developed lots fronting on an existing street may, at the discretion of the
planning commission, submit a final plat, together with any necessary
construction plans and specifications, for direct consideration and approval by
the governing body without following the steps which ordinarily precede the
submission of a final plat; provided, that the following criteria are met:
      1.   All lots in the proposed subdivision meet at least a minimum lot
dimension as prescribed in section
10-4-7 of this title and as governed by the zoning ordinance.
      2.   All lots in the proposed subdivision will, upon completion of the
subdivision, have access to utilities constructed in accordance with the terms
and conditions of this title. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-3-8: COMMERCIAL PLANNED DEVELOPMENTS AND RESIDENTIAL PLANNED UNIT
DEVELOPMENTS:
   A.   Preliminary Plan Approval:
      1.   Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the procedures and
requirements for approval of preliminary development plans for commercial
planned developments and residential planned unit developments shall be those
procedures and requirements specified in section
10-3-3 of this chapter for approval of preliminary plats. References in section
10-3-3 of this chapter to subdividers and plats shall be construed to be
references to developers and development plans, respectively.
      2.   The required plans, maps and supporting documents are specified in
subsections
10-6-4A and
10-6-5A of this title for commercial planned developments and residential
planned unit developments, respectively. The application fee shall be two
hundred dollars ($200.00), plus, in the case of a residential planned unit
development, six dollars ($6.00) for each dwelling unit over thirty three (33)
units.
   B.   Final Development Plan Approval:
      1.   Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the procedures and
requirements for approval of final development plans for commercial planned
developments and residential planned unit developments shall be those
procedures and requirements specified in section
10-3-4 of this chapter for approval of final plats. References in section
10-3-4 of this chapter to subdividers and plats shall be construed to be
references to developers and development plans, respectively.
      2.   The required maps, data and supporting documents are specified in
subsections
10-6-4B and
10-6-5B of this title for commercial planned developments and residential
planned unit developments, respectively. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-3-9: DONATION OF LAND OR CONTRIBUTION OF CASH FOR SCHOOL PURPOSES:
   A.   As a condition precedent to the approval of any plat or planned
development within the village or within one and one- half (11/2) miles of its
corporate limits, the owner of the property shall, under the following
circumstances, provide for donation of land or a contribution of cash in lieu
thereof to the elementary school district which serves the property:
      1.   Where the plat creates one or more lots intended to be used for
residential purposes; or
      2.   Where the owner seeks approval of a planned development which is
intended to include one or more dwelling units.
   B.   The land donation requirement shall be a function of the number of
dwelling units intended to be created by a subdivision or planned development.
Except as hereafter provided, for each subdivision or planned development
intended to contain one thousand two hundred (1,200) or more dwelling units,
the owner thereof shall provide an elementary school site and a middle school
site. The area of the elementary school site shall be the sum of 0.016 acre for
each single-family dwelling and 0.012 acre for each multi- family dwelling. The
area of the middle school site shall be the sum of 0.018 acre for each single-
family dwelling and 0.014 acre for each multi-family dwelling.
   C.   With respect to subdivisions or planned developments intended to
contain less than one thousand two hundred (1,200) dwelling units and with
respect to all subdivisions or planned developments under circumstances where
the school district having jurisdiction over the property advises the village
that there is no present need for additional school sites, the owner of the
property shall make a contribution of cash in lieu of land. The amount of the
contribution shall be dependent upon the nature of the dwelling unit
contemplated to be constructed and shall be assessed as follows:
      1.   For each single-family dwelling: Three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      2.   For each multi-family dwelling: Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   D.   The owner of the property proposed to be subdivided shall provide to
the planning commission specific information as to the number of single-family
dwellings and multi-family dwellings intended to be located on the property
upon completion of the development.
   E.   Contributions of cash in lieu of school sites shall be held in trust by
the elementary school district whose territory includes the property proposed
to be subdivided for use in the acquisition of land for a new or enlarged
school site to serve the immediate or future needs of children from that
subdivision or the construction of new school buildings or additions to
existing school buildings, or for the improvement of any existing school site
which already serves such needs. The word improvement, under this subsection,
shall be liberally construed and shall include, but shall not be limited to,
the development of parking lots, sidewalks, traffic signals, minor arterial
streets, collector streets, internal roadways, connections with sewer, water
and electrical lines, playgrounds, recreation grounds and athletic fields. The
term improvement shall further include the construction of buildings, additions
to existing school buildings, remodeled or renovated noninstrumental spaces in
classrooms and the purchase of prefabricated classroom units to be used at a
school site. If any portion of a cash contribution in lieu of school site is
not expended for the purposes set forth herein within ten (10) years from the
date of receipt, it shall be refunded to the owners of record of all lots in
the subdivision or planned development for which such contribution was made.
The refund shall be paid to the person who is the owner of record on the day
which is the tenth anniversary of the receipt of such contribution. The amount
of the refund due shall be equal to the amount of the original contribution
remaining unspent divided by the total number of lots in the subdivision.
   F.   In the event that the property proposed to be subdivided is located
partially in one elementary school district and partially in one or more other
elementary school districts, the donation of land or contribution of cash in
lieu thereof shall be apportioned among the school districts. (Ord. 675, 2-24-
2011)
10-3-10: CONTRIBUTION OF CASH FOR PARK AND RECREATION PURPOSES:
   A.   As a condition precedent to the approval of any plat or planned
development within the village or within one and one- half (11/2) miles of its
corporate limits, the owner of the property shall, under the following
circumstances, provide a contribution of cash for park and recreation purposes:
      1.   Where the plat creates one or more lots intended to be used for
residential purposes; or
      2.   Where the owner seeks approval of a planned development which is
intended to include one or more dwelling units.
   B.   The amount of the contribution shall be dependent upon the nature of
the dwelling unit contemplated to be constructed and shall be assessed as
follows:
      1.   For each single-family dwelling: Three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      2.   For each multi-family dwelling: Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   C.   The owner of the property proposed to be subdivided shall provide to
the planning commission specific information as to the number of single-family
dwellings and multi-family dwellings intended to be located on the property
upon completion of the development.
   D.   Contributions of cash pursuant to this section shall be paid to the
village for use in the acquisition of land for new or enlarged park and
recreational facilities and/or the improvement or maintenance of existing
facilities. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
CHAPTER 4
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
10-4-1: Streets
10-4-2: Pavement Design And Construction
10-4-3: Easements
10-4-4: Utilities
10-4-5: Traffic Control Signs And Devices
10-4-6: Blocks
10-4-7: Lots
10-4-8: Street Names
10-4-9: Existing Natural Features
10-4-10: Bike Paths And/Or Walkways
10-4-1: STREETS:
   A.   The course, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to
the comprehensive plan and shall be considered in their relation to existing
and planned streets, to topographic conditions, to public convenience and
safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to
be served by such streets, and shall conform to the following street design
standards and criteria:
      1.   Functional classification based on whether a street is used as a
principal arterial, minor arterial, collector, or local street;
      2.   Geometric design criteria specifying dimensions and arrangements of
a street's visible features;
      3.   Pavement design standards that provide required pavement material
types and street thickness requirements; and
      4.   Construction, inspection, and testing standards which provide the
minimum requirements and procedures for inspection, testing, and documentation
of the street design process from construction to completion.
   B.   Where not shown on the comprehensive plan, the arrangement of streets
in a subdivision shall be reviewed by the planning commission and shall either:
      1.   Provide for the continuation or projection of existing principal
streets in surrounding areas; or
      2.   Conform to the major thoroughfare plan where applicable; or
      3.   Conform to topographic or other conditions where continuance or
projection of existing streets is impractical.
   C.   Local streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic
will be discouraged. Unless otherwise provided in this subsection or by the
planning commission, all new subdivisions shall conform their streets to
qualify as local streets under this subsection and in accord with the standards
laid out in section
10-5-3, table 5-1, "Minimum Requirements For Street Improvements", of this
title.
   D.   Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed minor
arterial or a railroad right of way or rail crossings, access thereto shall be
limited to a minimum number of intersections, and such access intersections
with minor arterials and/or rail crossings shall be determined with due regard
for sight distance between intersections, approach grades and requirements for
future grade separations. No street grade shall be less than one-half of one
percent (0.5%) or more than five percent (5%) on principal arterials, minor
arterials, and collectors and not more than nine percent (9%) on all other
streets.
   E.   1. The geometric design of village streets shall comply with the
American Association Of State Highway And Transportation Officials' (AASHTO's)
"A Policy On Geometric Design Of Highways And Streets".
      2.   The basic street design shall conform to the criteria included in
the following table:
TABLE 4-1
 
Functional Classification      Minor Arterial Collector    Local
Traffic design forecast period 20 years       20 years     20 years
Level of service               C              C            C
Design speed                   35 to 45 mph   30 to 40 mph 20 to 30 mph
Design vehicle                 WB-50          S-BUS-40     S-BUS-40
 
      3.   Horizontal and vertical alignment of streets shall comply with
AASHTO policy for the appropriate design speed.
      4.   Intersection radii shall be large enough to accommodate the design
vehicle so that the path of travel does not encroach upon the opposing lane of
travel or require traveling on the shoulder, gutter, or drainage area of a
street. Radii shall not be larger than necessary.
      5.   Streets that dead end shall not exceed six hundred feet (600') in
length and terminate in a cul-de-sac with a minimum pavement radius of ninety
feet (90') and a minimum right of way radius of not less than one hundred ten
feet (110').
      6.   Selection of rural cross section or urban cross section elements (as
defined in tables 4-2 and 4-3 of this section) shall be approved by the village
during approval of the preliminary plat.

      7.   Street intersections with centerline offsets of less than one
hundred twenty five feet (125') shall be prohibited.
      8.   A tangent at least one hundred feet (100') long shall be introduced
between curves on minor arterial and collector streets where the curve radius
is less than five hundred feet (500').
      9.   Where connecting street lines deflect from each other more than ten
degrees (10°), they shall be connected with a curve with a radius adequate to
assure sight distance.
      10.   Streets shall be laid out to intersect as nearly as possible at
right angles, and no street shall intersect any other street at less than
seventy degrees (70°).
   F.   Alleys shall not be permitted in residential districts.
   G.   Private streets and reserve strips shall be discouraged in platting
subdivisions. Every subdivision shall be served from a publicly dedicated
street. Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be placed under the
control of the village or township and be under such conditions as approved by
the governing body. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
   H.   All new subdivisions along state and county highways shall be arranged
to provide access to such highways at intervals not less than one thousand
three hundred twenty feet (1,320'), except where impractical or impossible due
to existing property divisions or topography or due to undue traffic
concentration at points of access. Also, streets within such subdivision shall
be arranged to permit access to adjacent future subdivisions without
encroachment upon this section. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
10-4-2: PAVEMENT DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Village streets shall be constructed of materials that meet the minimum
standards of the Illinois department of transportation ("IDOT"). Pavement
design for all village streets shall follow the procedure provided in chapter
37 of IDOT's "Bureau Of Local Roads And Streets Manual", 2006. The design
engineer shall specify the relevant criteria and material types to be used in
the construction plans and specifications. IDOT material nomenclature and
quality requirements shall be used for pavement design and construction.
Existing soil properties shall be identified, and a report of the relevant test
results shall be prepared by a qualified geotechnical engineer for use in the
pavement design. Pavement design calculations shall be prepared by a qualified
professional engineer and be submitted to the village along with the final plat
for acceptance before construction. The selection of hot mix asphalt or
portland cement for pavement design shall be approved by the village during
approval of the final plat.
   B.   Subgrade soils shall develop an immediate bearing value ("IBV") in
excess of 6.0. If the in situ soils do not attain this value, remedial
procedures shall be taken to increase the IBV value to 6.0. The in situ IBV,
prior to modification, shall be used for pavement design calculations. The
following minimum values shall be used for pavement materials in the pavement
design:
      1.   Subbase granular material: Six inches (6").
      2.   Aggregate base: Six inches (6").
      3.   Asphalt pavement: Six inches (6").
      4.   Asphalt surface course: 1.25 inches.
      5.   Portland cement concrete: Five inches (5").
   C.   The design engineer shall document that acceptable material types and
thickness are used and achieved during the construction process. The design
engineer shall also perform density testing on all subgrades, aggregate
materials, and asphalt materials. Testing of portland cement concrete shall
include air content, slump, and compression strength. Tests shall be performed
by or under the supervision of the design engineer. A proof roll of the
subgrade shall be completed using a loaded tandem axle dump truck before
pavement materials are placed. The proof roll shall be performed in the
presence of a village representative. Copies of the design engineer's test
results and construction observation records shall be submitted to the village.
(Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-4-3: EASEMENTS:
Easements across lots, centered on rear or side lot lines, or where necessary
for utilities, watercourse, drainageway channel or stream shall not be less
than ten feet (10') wide and shall be centered on lot lines, or adjacent to lot
lines, where practicable. All easements shall be shown on the plat. (Ord. 675,
2-24-2011)
10-4-4: UTILITIES:
   A.   All utilities shall be located in a dedicated easement adjacent to the
public right of way or with a dedicated easement providing access to the
utility.
   B.   All crossings under proposed pavement shall be constructed prior to any
street construction. Flowable backfill (CLSM), as specified in the "Illinois
Department Of Transportation Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction" (latest edition) will be utilized under and within two feet (2')
of any proposed roadway.
   C.   Any utility crossing under an existing roadway shall be directional
drilled unless permission for open trench construction is granted by the
village.
   D.   All utility stubs to future lots shall be clearly marked above the
ground surface. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-4-5: TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS AND DEVICES:
All traffic control signs and devices shall be in accordance with the laws of
the state of Illinois, the "Manual Of Uniform Traffic Control Devices"
("MUTCD"), and IDOT's published supplement to the MUTCD. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-4-6: BLOCKS:
The length, width and shape of blocks shall be determined with due regard to:
   A.   Provision of adequate building sites for the special type of use
contemplated.
   B.   Requirements as to lot size and dimensions.
   C.   Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street
traffic.
   D.   Limitations and opportunities of topography.
   E.   Block lengths shall not exceed one thousand three hundred twenty feet
(1,320').
   F.   In cases where the block length exceeds six hundred feet (600') and
where deemed essential by the planning commission to provide pedestrian
circulation to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers and other community
facilities, an easement not less than ten feet (10') wide, dedicated to the
village or township for a crosswalk, shall be provided.
   G.   Block width shall be wide enough to allow two (2) tiers of lots of a
minimum depth of one hundred feet (100'). (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-4-7: LOTS:
   A.   All provisions of the zoning ordinance regulations concerning lots
shall apply including lot area, width, and depth. The standards of the specific
zoning district of the area at the time of submission of the final plat shall
be followed in determining minimum lot requirements.
   B.   Zoning ordinance regulations for minimum lot size (see table 4-4 of
this section), except lots fronting on a cul-de- sac, shall have a minimum
frontage of thirty feet (30') at the right of way. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, for any proposed subdivision having five (5) or fewer lots, the
minimum lot frontage shall be no less than thirty feet (30'); provided, that
the average lot frontage for all lots in the subdivision shall meet the
requirements set forth in table 4-4 of this section.

   C.   The lot shapes and orientation shall be appropriate for the location of
the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated.
   D.   The minimum lot frontage shall be no less than one hundred feet (100'),
except lots fronting on a cul-de-sac shall have a minimum frontage of thirty
feet (30') at the right of way. Notwithstanding the foregoing, for any proposed
subdivision having five (5) or fewer lots, the minimum lot frontage shall be no
less than thirty feet (30'); provided, that the average lot frontage for all
lots in the subdivision shall meet the requirements set forth in table 4-4 of
this section.
   E.   Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be avoided except where
essential to provide separation of residential development from minor arterial
streets or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation.
   F.   Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to
street lines.
   G.   No parcel, remainder, gore, outlot or remnant of land which is part of
the tract being subdivided shall be created which, by reason of lot width,
depth, area, frontage, topography or lack of access thereto, cannot be used as
a zoning lot, or be subject to further subdivision in accordance with the terms
of this title. Any remaining parcel or outlot which cannot be made to comply
with the foregoing shall be eliminated by combining the area thereof with one
or more adjoining lots which do comply, or by conveying the same for
appropriate public use to a public body, subject to its acceptance of same.
(Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-4-8: STREET NAMES:
A proposed street which is in alignment with or joins an existing and named
street shall bear the name of the existing street. In no case shall the
proposed name of the street duplicate the name of an existing street within the
area. The use of the suffix "street", "avenue", "boulevard", "driveway",
"place" or "court", or similar description, shall not be distinction sufficient
to constitute compliance with this section. Names that sound similar to
existing names or that could be confused or difficult to understand in
emergency situations are not to be used. House numbers shall be assigned in
accordance with the provisions of the county or the village, depending upon the
location of the subdivision. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-4-9: EXISTING NATURAL FEATURES:
To the extent possible, the subdivider is encouraged to retain existing trees
and other interesting natural features in the development of the subdivision.
(Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-4-10: BIKE PATHS AND/OR WALKWAYS:
The planning commission shall make recommendations to the governing body
concerning new or replacement bike paths and/or walkways. The governing body,
after consideration of the recommendation, may provide for the building of the
same by ordinance. A bike path and/or walkway ordinance shall:
   A.   Define the location of the proposed new or replacement bike path and/or
walkway;
   B.   Prescribe its width, which shall be no less than ten feet (10') unless
special circumstances preventing such width are enumerated in the ordinance;
   C.   Describe the materials to be used to construct the bike path and/or
walkway, which shall generally be asphalt or concrete;
   D.   Describe the manner of constructing the bike path and/or walkway; and
   E.   Describe the officer(s) who shall inspect, approve, and accept the bike
path and/or walkway upon its completion. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
CHAPTER 5
REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
10-5-1: General Requirements
10-5-2: Monuments
10-5-3: Streets
10-5-4: Sewer System
10-5-5: Water System
10-5-6: Stormwater Drainage And Detention
10-5-7: Sump Pumps
10-5-8: Curb And Gutter
10-5-9: Sidewalks
10-5-10: Street Lighting
10-5-11: House Services
10-5-12: Inspection And As Built Plans
10-5-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   It is recommended that no grading, tree removal, site work or
installation of any required improvements be commenced until the preliminary
plat has been approved.
   B.   All grading, site work or installation of any required improvements
shall be done in such manner as to prevent flooding, washing, erosion, silting,
or other impairment of adjacent properties, storm drainage channels, bodies of
water or adjoining streets.
   C.   No trees, tree stumps, brush or similar material shall be buried or
used as fill in any area of a subdivision to be traversed by a road, or which
is likely to be in or adjacent to an individual sewage disposal system or
similar use. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-5-2: MONUMENTS:
Monuments shall be placed by an Illinois registered land surveyor at all block
corners, angle points, points of tangency of curves in streets, and at such
intermediate points as shall be required by the plat officer. The monuments
shall be of such material, size and length as may be approved by the plat
officer. Such monuments, as near as possible, shall be placed so as to be flush
with the established finished grade. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-5-3: STREETS:
   A.   Streets (and alleys where provided) shall be completed to grades shown
on plats, profiles and cross sections as needed and approved by the planning
commission.
   B.   Streets and alleys shall be graded, surfaced and improved to the
dimensions and standards of table 5-1 of this section.
   C.   Prior to placing the street surface, adequate subsurface drainage for
the streets and all utilities under the streets shall be provided or installed
by the subdivider. Upon the completion of the street and alley improvements,
plats and profiles as built shall be filed with the planning commission.
   D.   Streets shall have such right of way widths as are indicated on the
major thoroughfare plan, or as specified in chapter 4 of this title. When
existing streets are located within the subdivision or adjacent to the
subdivision, the subdivider shall provide for additional right of way width to
equal the minimum required by chapter 4 of this title; provided, however, that
when such existing streets abut the subdivision on one side only, only one-half
(1/2) of the difference between the existing right of way width and the width
indicated on the major thoroughfare plan or as specified in chapter 4 of this
title shall be provided by the subdivider.
   E.   The commission shall make such requirements as to type of pavement and
as to curbs, gutters, and sidewalks as it deems to be necessary for such
street, provided such requirements are consistent with this title and the
Illinois division of highways "Manual Of Street And Highway Improvements
Standards And Typical Cross-Sections". However, the subdivider shall be
required to improve the street only to the width required by the current and
immediate needs of his subdivision consistent with standards specified herein.
   F.   The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with street signs, the
type, height and design as approved by the planning commission, at the
intersections of all streets.
   G.   The construction materials and procedures shall meet the current
minimum standards and specifications as set by the Illinois department of
transportation unless specified otherwise in this title.
   H.   When all of the streets and other facilities required in this section
are completed within the platted area in accordance with the provisions of this
section and approved by the authorities having jurisdiction, they shall be
submitted for acceptance for maintenance by either the governing body or the
township highway commissioner; this acceptance to be evidenced by a stipulation
and certification of completion of work executed by the governing body or the
township highway commission which shall be recorded in the office of the county
recorder of deeds by the subdivider of the platted area.
   I.   The following table sets out minimum requirements for street
improvements:
