10-5-4: SEWER SYSTEM:
   A.   All sanitary sewers will be constructed in accordance with the most
current edition of "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois". The design of the sanitary sewer system shall be in
accordance with the Illinois administrative code, title 35: environmental
protection, subtitle C: water pollution, chapter II: environmental protection
agency, part 370: Illinois recommended standards for sewage works.
   B.   When the subdivision is reasonably accessible, as determined by the
planning commission prior to approval of the subdivision plat, to an existing
sanitary sewer system, the subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a
complete sanitary sewer system to be connected to such sanitary sewer system.
   C.   1. The trunk sewer main shall be located within the public right of way
but outside of the roadway pavement whenever possible. All crossings under
proposed pavement shall be constructed prior to any street construction.
Flowable backfill (CLSM), as specified in the most current edition of the
"Illinois Department Of Transportation Standard Specifications For Road And
Bridge Construction" will be utilized under and within two feet (2') of any
proposed roadway.
      2.   Sanitary sewer pipe shall have a minimum diameter of eight inches
(8") for main line sewers and four inches (4") for lateral sewers, and shall be
of material, joints and fittings as approved by the village.
      3.   Sewer mains shall have tracer wire attached to the pipe. Tracer wire
will be connected to a ground rod with a clamp with brass screws next to each
manhole.
      4.   A tee and lateral shall be constructed for each individual lot or
parcel in the subdivision and shall be a minimum of four inches (4") in
diameter.
      5.   All service lateral connections shall have a tracer wire coming from
the sewer main. At service laterals, a two inch by four inch by eight foot (2"
x 4" x 8') wood stud, painted green, shall be placed at all service
connections. Four feet (4') of the two inches by four inches (2" x 4") shall be
above the ground surface. Next to the two inches by four inches (2" x 4"), a
steel rod (2 feet x 2 feet x 1/2 inch) shall be placed with a tracer wire
connected. Four inches (4") of the rod shall be above the ground surface.
      6.   Sewer mains will be tested with low pressure air method and mandrel
tested, as specified in the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer
Construction In Illinois". The village or designated agent will be present
during the test.
      7.   Prior to final acceptance of the sewer by the village, all sewer
mains shall be internally inspected with a color inspection camera. The camera
lens shall not have less than a sixty five degree (65°) viewing lens and auto
focus. Accurate and continuous footage and date readings shall be superimposed
on a DVD. The DVD will be labeled showing lines recorded and name of the
contractor who constructed the sewer mains. Copies of the DVD will be provided
to the village.
      8.   Manholes shall be built where sewers change in size, slope, or
direction, and at a maximum spacing of four hundred feet (400'). Manholes shall
be precast concrete and have a minimum drop of 0.1 foot across the flow line.
Where manholes are constructed in areas susceptible to surface runoff
infiltration, the frame and lid of such manholes will be of the bolt down and
watertight type. Manhole lids for sanitary sewers shall be completely closed
and self-sealing. All manholes shall be tested for watertightness as specified
in the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Construction In Illinois".
      9.   When the topography of the subdivision does not allow for connection
to the municipal sanitary sewer system with gravity sewer, the subdivider shall
provide the subdivision with a pumping station that pumps the sewage to the
nearest available gravity municipal sanitary sewer. The pumping station shall
be designed to accommodate the loading produced by the proposed subdivision.
The pumping station shall be designed in accordance with the Illinois
environmental protection agency regulations. Specific equipment, materials and
location of the pump station shall be approved by the village. The subdivider
shall provide a backup generator as a part of the pump station. The connection
of the proposed pump station to the existing supervisory control and data
acquisition ("SCADA") system shall be required by the village.
   D.   When no existing sanitary sewer system is available or is not
reasonably accessible to the subdivision, as determined by the planning
commission prior to approval of the subdivision plat, the subdivider shall
provide the subdivision with a complete sanitary sewer system which shall
connect with a sanitary sewer outlet approved by the Illinois environmental
protection agency or other appropriate regulatory agency; except, that when
such approved outlet is not available, one of the following methods of sewage
disposal shall be used:
      1.   A complete sanitary sewer system to convey the sewage to a treatment
plant to be provided by the subdivider in accordance with minimum requirements
of the Illinois environmental protection agency or other appropriate regulatory
agency, with adequate provision for the maintenance of such plant. To avoid
errors in building elevations, the sanitary sewer system shall be in place and
able to function as intended before a building permit will be issued for any
structure that will connect to the system.
      2.   Where lot size permits, private sewage disposal systems on
individual lots consisting of septic tanks and tile absorption fields or other
approved sewage disposal systems where laid out in accordance with minimum
standards approved by the Illinois environmental protection agency or other
appropriate regulatory agency.
   E.   Upon completion of the sanitary sewer system installation, a registered
professional engineer shall certify that the sanitary sewer system complies
with all the standards required by the village and the Illinois environmental
protection agency or other appropriate regulatory agency. One certified copy of
the plans for such sanitary sewer system as built shall be filed with the
planning commission, village and Illinois environmental protection agency or
other appropriate regulatory agency.
   F.   Storm sewers, footing drains and downspouts shall not be connected to
sanitary sewers. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
   G.   The phrase "the subdivider shall provide", as used in this section,
shall be interpreted to mean that the subdivider shall install the facility
referred to, or whenever a private sewage disposal system is to be provided,
that the subdivider shall require, as a condition of the sale of each lot in
the subdivision, that the facilities referred to in this section shall be
installed by the owner of the lot in accordance with this title. (Ord. 675, 2-
24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
10-5-5: WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   All water main construction shall be in accordance with the most
current edition of the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois".
   B.   The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete water main
supply system which shall be connected to an existing public water system;
except, where lot size permits and such existing public water system is not
available, the subdivider shall provide an individual water supply on each lot
in the subdivision in accordance with minimum standards approved by the
Illinois environmental protection agency or other appropriate regulatory
agency.
   C.   Water mains shall be located in a dedicated easement adjacent to the
public right of way.
   D.   All crossings under proposed pavement shall be constructed prior to any
street construction. Flowable backfill (CLSM), as specified in the most current
edition of the "Illinois Department Of Transportation Standard Specifications
For Road And Bridge Construction", will be utilized under and within two feet
(2') of any proposed roadway.
   E.   All water mains, including water services, shall include tracer wire.
   F.   The plans for the installation of a water main supply system shall be
prepared by the subdivider with the cooperation of the applicable water utility
company. Upon the completion of the water supply installation, one copy of the
plans for such system as built shall be filed with the planning commission, the
village, and Illinois environmental protection agency or other appropriate
regulatory agency.
   G.   Fire hydrants shall be located in such a manner that no structure
within the setback lines on a lot would be more than three hundred feet (300')
from a fire hydrant. There shall be ready access between the fire hydrant and
the lot that does not require crossing of other private property. The minimum
distance shall be measured along the route of ready access.
   H.   The water system shall be under pressure and able to provide fire flow
before a building permit will be issued for any structure to be served by the
system. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
   I.   The phrase "the subdivider shall provide", as used in this section,
shall be interpreted to mean that the subdivider shall install the facility
referred to, or whenever an individual water supply is to be provided, that the
subdivider shall require, as a condition of the sale of each lot in the
subdivision, that the facilities referred to in this section shall be installed
by the owner of the lot in accordance with this title. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011;
amd. 2012 Code)
10-5-6: STORMWATER DRAINAGE AND DETENTION:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   The subdivider, through the subdivision's engineer, shall submit
drainage calculations supporting the storm drainage and detention system signed
and sealed by a licensed professional engineer in the state of Illinois.
Drainage calculations shall include a narrative and summary of the existing and
proposed drainage patterns, surface cover types, times of concentration, flow
rates, rainfall intensities, pipe sizing calculations, and storage capacities.
The subdivider is strongly encouraged to utilize recognized best management
practices (BMPs), such as conserving open space, reducing imperviousness,
utilizing bioswales, etc., for reducing the quantity of stormwater runoff and
improving the quality of stormwater runoff to mimic the natural watershed
hydrology.
      2.   All drainage calculations shall conform to the methods outlined in
the village ordinance pertaining to sediment control, runoff control, and soil
stabilization during certain construction projects commenced after April 24,
2008, and the most current edition of the "Illinois Department Of
Transportation Drainage Manual".
      3.   All drainage improvements shall be constructed in accordance with
the most current edition of the "Illinois Department Of Transportation Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" and supplemental and recurring
special provisions. As built plans shall be submitted to the village at the
acceptance of any public improvements.
      4.   The storm drainage system shall be adequate to properly drain the
subdivision and all other upstream areas that are tributary to the subdivision.
   B.   Storm Sewer System:
      1.   The storm sewer system shall be designed for the 10-year frequency
storm event.
      2.   The minimum storm sewer size shall be twelve inches (12").
      3.   The minimum velocity allowed in storm sewers shall be three feet
(3') per second. The maximum velocity allowed in a storm sewer shall be ten
feet (10') per second. All velocities shall be based on the pipe flowing full.
      4.   The type of material permitted for storm sewers shall be as
specified in the "Illinois Department Of Transportation Standard Specifications
For Road And Bridge Construction".
      5.   All stormwater drainage structures shall conform to IDOT standards
as detailed in the "Illinois Department Of Transportation Standard Drawings
Section 600 - Drainage". All castings for stormwater drainage structures shall
be stenciled with "Dump No Waste! Drains To Waterways".
      6.   The location and spacing of inlets shall be designed to allow a
maximum stormwater encroachment of one-half (1/2) of the traffic lane on the
outside lane for the 10-year frequency storm event. A minimum of two (2) inlets
shall be provided in all roadway sag locations.
      7.   A flared end section or head wall is required at the outlet of all
storm sewer systems. Riprap or other preapproved energy dissipation measures
shall be utilized at the outlet of all storm sewer systems to control erosion
and scour to prevent damage to downstream properties. All flared end sections
shall include grating meeting IDOT standard 542311.
      8.   All field tiles encountered during construction shall be repaired as
directed by the village, with the size, pipe material, location, and depth
indicated on the record drawings. Where field tiles are damaged and it is
determined by the village that they cannot be repaired, provisions shall be
made to reroute the field tiles to the nearest available storm sewer.
   C.   Permanent Stormwater Control Measures:
      1.   Permanent detention ponds shall be designed so that the peak
discharge rate from the permitted area resulting from the 2-year, 10-year, 25-
year, 50-year and 100-year critical duration storm events for the postproject
condition do not exceed the corresponding storm event peak discharges for the
preproject condition as described in the village ordinance pertaining to
sediment control, runoff control, and soil stabilization during certain
construction projects commenced after April 24, 2008.
      2.   Stormwater control calculations shall be performed per section
8-2-14-1, attachment A of this code pertaining to sediment control, runoff
control, and soil stabilization during certain construction projects commenced
after April 24, 2008.
      3.   Wet bottom detention pond design standards:
         a.   Maximum side slopes of four to one (4:1).
         b.   A minimum permanent pool depth of eight feet (8') to discourage
the growth of weeds.
         c.   A safety ledge ten feet (10') wide and approximately one and one-
half feet (1.5') under the normal water surface elevation shall be provided
around the perimeter of the detention pond.
         d.   Riprap or other approved energy dissipation methods shall be
utilized at the water surface elevation around the perimeter of the detention
pond to limit wave action erosion.
      4.   Dry bottom detention pond design standards:
         a.   Maximum side slopes of four to one (4:1).
         b.   The minimum longitudinal slope in the bottom of the detention
pond shall be one percent (1.0%).
      5.   A flared end section or head wall is required at the outlet of all
stormwater controls. Riprap or other preapproved energy dissipation measures
shall be utilized at the outlet of all stormwater controls to limit erosion and
scour to prevent damage to downstream properties. All flared end sections shall
include grating meeting IDOT standard 542311.
   D.   Roadway Ditches: Roadway ditches shall be designed to accommodate 25-
year frequency storm events and have:
      1.   Maximum side slopes of three to one (3:1).
      2.   Minimum depth of two feet (2').
      3.   Minimum bottom width of two feet (2').
      4.   Minimum longitudinal slope of one percent (1%).
      5.   Maximum design velocity of five feet (5') per second. Design
velocities that cannot be reduced to at least five feet (5') per second should
be minimized as much as possible and require ditch lining to protect against
erosion.
   E.   Crossroad Culverts:
      1.   All crossroad culverts shall be designed for the 25-year frequency
storm event with a minimum of one foot (1') of freeboard to the edge of
pavement elevation.
      2.   Minimum crossroad culvert size shall be eighteen inches (18").
Larger diameter culverts shall be used if necessary to pass the 25-year storm
event. Crossroad culverts shall be reinforced concrete material of the
appropriate class based on the installation conditions.
      3.   Driveway culverts shall be not less than fifteen inches (15").
Larger diameter culverts shall be used if necessary to pass the 25-year storm
event. Driveway culverts shall be reinforced concrete material.
      4.   A flared end section or head wall is required at the outlet and
inlet of all crossroad culverts. Riprap or other approved energy dissipation
measures shall be utilized at the outlet and inlet of all crossroad culverts to
limit erosion and scour. All flared end sections shall include grating meeting
IDOT standard 542311.
   F.   100-Year Frequency Storm Events:
      1.   The subdivider shall preserve an overland flood route capable of
conveying the 100-year frequency storm event through the subdivision without
causing property damage. Drainage calculations shall be submitted to the
village which demonstrate the capacity of the overland flood route. (Ord. 675,
2-24-2011; amd. Ord. 841, 6-17-2021)
10-5-7: SUMP PUMPS:
Sump pumps will not be connected to the sanitary sewer system. A separate line
shall be constructed for sump pumps to discharge into the storm sewer. This
pipe will be identified with tracer wire and identified as sump pumps only.
Each lot will have an individual connection provided. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-5-8: CURB AND GUTTER:
Curb and gutter shall be constructed along the frontage of all lots. The curb
and gutter shall be constructed of portland cement concrete and shall meet
current Illinois department of transportation design standards. (Ord. 675, 2-
24-2011)
10-5-9: SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Sidewalks shall be constructed along the frontage of all lots. The
planning commission may recommend that sidewalks be provided along any road or
street as necessary for schoolchildren or other pedestrian movements.
   B.   Sidewalks shall be at least four feet (4') in width. Sidewalks shall be
located within the dedicated right of way and at least five feet (5') from the
curb line unless the planning commission recommends that another location is
warranted due to topography or other considerations. Sidewalk alignment on lots
abutting other subdivisions or lots having existing sidewalks shall be so
constructed to provide continuous and contiguous pavement. Sidewalks shall be
constructed of portland cement concrete having a minimum thickness of four
inches (4"). (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-5-10: STREET LIGHTING:
   A.   In residential subdivisions, the subdivider shall either:
      1.   Install streetlights at each intersection and along straightaways at
a maximum spacing of one every five hundred feet (500'). Streetlights must be
mounted on aluminum poles, and both poles and luminaries must be of a type
acceptable to both the electricity provider and the public works department; or
      2.   Impose and enforce a restrictive covenant requiring a yard light on
each lot switched only by a photocell which will cause the light to operate
from sunset to sunrise. Such restrictive covenant shall require all yard lights
to be located in the yard ten feet (10') from the front lot line and within
three feet (3') of the driveway.
   B.   All lighting referenced in this section must be approved by the
planning commission during the preliminary plat approval. See subsections
10-6-2B and
10-6-4A of this title. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-5-11: HOUSE SERVICES:
   A.   House services shall be constructed to connect with the utility service
mains constructed within any public street or easement to serve each adjoining
lot, tract or building site. Such house services shall extend from the main to
not less than two feet (2') inside the curb line or easement line.
   B.   All such house services connected with utility mains constructed within
any street or easement shall be located at the approximate centerline of each
lot, and no deviation shall be made from this requirement, except upon prior
approval of the planning commission.
   C.   Upon completion of the construction in place of all such house service
connections, an accurate map or maps showing the exact location of all such
mains, together with manholes, shutoff valves, house service connections and
other similar facilities being a part thereof, shall be filed by the subdivider
with the planning commission. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-5-12: INSPECTION AND AS BUILT PLANS:
   A.   It shall be the responsibility of the developer to retain the services
of a professional engineer, registered in the state of Illinois or approved
testing laboratory, or combination thereof, to supervise the construction of
the public improvements which are required under this chapter.
   B.   The plat officer shall be advised two (2) working days in advance of
any connection to the existing sewer or water system and also prior to the
commencement of testing of new improvements. A certified copy of the final test
results for the water and sanitary sewer shall be filed with the plat officer
before commencement of any street improvements.
   C.   The plat officer shall be notified two (2) working days in advance of
the commencement of construction of curb and gutter and asphalt surfacing. Upon
completion of the subgrade, the plat officer or his representative shall
witness the test rolling of the subgrade with a fully loaded gravel truck
furnished by the contractor or developer, and the areas that fail the test
rolling shall be repaired in an approved manner.
   D.   If the developer, contractor, and/or developer's engineer disagree with
any decision or recommendation of the governing body officials, the developer
and his engineer may file a certificate guaranteeing work for an additional one
year period and proceed with construction unless the governing body
recommendation is in accordance with the EPA standards or the Illinois
department of transportation specifications, in which case, no variance shall
be allowed without the approval of the village board.
   E.   Upon completion of the construction of sanitary sewer, storm sewer,
water mains, streets, curbs, gutters, street lighting, sidewalks or any other
public improvements, the developer's engineer shall certify to the governing
body that the installed improvements have been completed in accordance with the
approved plans and specifications and recommends acceptance of the development.
An accurate map or maps showing the exact as built locations of all water and
sewer mains, together with manhole locations, shutoff valves, house service
connections and other similar facilities being a part thereof, shall be filed
by the developer with the plat officer. Maps and/or drawings showing all other
public improvements shall also be filed with the plat officer. (Ord. 675, 2-24-
2011)
CHAPTER 6
PLATS AND DATA
SECTION:
10-6-1: Preapplication Plans And Data
10-6-2: Plats And Data For Conditional Approval Of Preliminary Plat
10-6-3: Plats And Data For Approval Of Final Plat
10-6-4: Maps And Data For Approval Of Commercial Planned Developments
10-6-5: Maps And Data For Approval Of Residential Planned Unit Developments
10-6-6: Recording Final Plat
10-6-7: Public Improvements
10-6-1: PREAPPLICATION PLANS AND DATA:
Previous to the filing of an application for conditional approval of the
preliminary plat, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission the
following plans and data:
   A.   General information data and location map which shall describe or
outline existing covenants, zoning, land characteristics, community facilities
and utilities, streets, schools, parks, playgrounds, and commercial and
industrial developments.
   B.   A sketch plan showing in simple sketch form the proposed layout of
streets, lots and other features in relation to existing conditions and may be
freehand or a print of a topographic map. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-6-2: PLATS AND DATA FOR CONDITIONAL APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT:
A preliminary plat of the subdivision shall be accurately drawn to a scale of
one hundred feet to one inch (1" = 100'). The preliminary plat shall be
eighteen inches by twenty four inches (18" x 24") in size or in six inch (6")
multiples thereof. The following information shall be shown on the preliminary
plat. The lack of any information shall be cause for disapproval of a
preliminary plat.
   A.   Required Existing Data:
      1.   Public land survey: The preliminary plat shall be tied to at least
one point of the public land survey system.
      2.   Boundary lines and lot lines: By bearings and distances.
      3.   Existing easements: Location, width and purpose.
      4.   Existing streets: On and adjacent to the tract by name, right of way
width, location, type, width and elevation of surfacing; curbs, gutters,
culverts, and sidewalks.
      5.   Existing utilities: On and adjacent to the tract; location, size and
invert elevation of sanitary sewers, storm sewers, and, where existing,
location and size of water mains; location of gas lines; fire hydrants,
electric and telephone poles, and streetlights. If any of the items listed in
this subsection A5 is not available at the site, indicate the direction and
distance to the nearest ones and furnish statements of availability.
      6.   Other existing conditions: Watercourses, marshes, rock outcrops,
wooded areas, dwellings, buildings, and other significant features.
      7.   Proposed public improvements: Streets or other major improvements
planned by public authorities for future construction on or near the tract.
      8.   Ground elevations: On mean sea level datum plane, show contours at
vertical intervals as follows:
         a.   Slope of six percent (6%) or less: Two foot (2') intervals.
         b.   Slope of over six percent (6%): Five foot (5') intervals.
      9.   Title and certificates: Present tract designation; title under which
the subdivision is to be recorded, names and addresses of owners, acreage,
scale, north point, datum, bench marks, certification of a registered
professional engineer or surveyor and date of survey.
   B.   Required Proposed Data: The preliminary plat shall show all existing
conditions required in subsection A of this section in topographic data and
show all proposals, including, but not necessarily limited to, the following:
      1.   Streets: Names, right of way and street widths, approximate grades
and gradients.
      2.   Street lighting: Location and type.
      3.   Easements: Location, width and purpose.
      4.   Utilities: Location, type and approximate size. This information may
be shown on a separate exhibit.
      5.   Lots: Lot lines, numbers and block numbers.
      6.   Sites (nonpublic): If any, for shopping centers, churches, industry,
multi-family dwellings or any other nonpublic use exclusive of single-family
dwellings.
      7.   Sites (public): If any, to be dedicated or reserved for parks,
playgrounds or other public uses. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
      8.   Bike paths and/or walkways: If required by the village board,
planning commission, or ordinance. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
      9.   Setback lines: Give dimensions of minimum setback lines.
      10.   Side data: Including number of residential lots, typical lot size,
and acres in other public and nonpublic land uses.
      11.   Title, scale, north arrow and plat date.
      12.   Other preliminary plans: When required by the planning commission,
the preliminary plat shall be accompanied by profiles showing existing ground
surface and proposed street grades; typical cross sections of the streets and
sidewalks; a preliminary plan of proposed sanitary and stormwater sewers, and
water mains with grades and size indicated, if available.
      13.   Draft of protective covenants: Whereby the subdivider proposes to
regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed
development.
      14.   Zoning: Show zoning classification of the subdivision and adjacent
area. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-6-3: PLATS AND DATA FOR APPROVAL OF FINAL PLAT:
The final plat shall meet the following specifications:
   A.   The final plat may include all or only a part of the area of the
preliminary plat as proposed in the application.
   B.   The original drawing of the final plat of the subdivision shall be
eighteen inches by twenty four inches (18" x 24") or in six inch (6") multiples
thereof. It shall be drawn at a scale of one hundred feet to the inch (1" =
100'). Four (4) black or blue line prints and one reproducible print shall be
submitted with the original final plat.
   C.   The following information shall be shown:
      1.   Primary control points or descriptions and "ties" to such control
points to the public land survey system, to which all dimensions, angles,
bearings, and similar data on the final plat shall be referred.
      2.   Tract boundary lines, right of way lines of streets, easements and
other rights of way, and property lines of residential lots and other sites,
with accurate dimensions, bearings or deflection angles, and radii, arcs, and
central angle of all curves.
      3.   Name and right of way width of each street or other rights of way.
      4.   Location and right of way widths of existing and/or platted streets
adjacent to the tract.
      5.   Location, dimensions and purpose of all easements.
      6.   Consecutive numbers for each lot or site within all subdivisions
having the same name.
      7.   Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated
or reserved.
      8.   Minimum setback on all lots and other sites.
      9.   Location and description of monuments.
      10.   Names of record owners of adjoining unplatted land.
      11.   Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land
by book and page.
      12.   Certification by an Illinois registered land surveyor as to
accuracy of the survey and plat.
      13.   Statement of the owner certifying that he has title to the land
being subdivided.
      14.   Statement by the owner dedicating streets, rights of way,
easements, and any sites for public use.
      15.   Title, scale, north arrow, and date.
      16.   Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements, or dedications
as may be required by applicable codes, ordinances and/or statutes pertaining
to zoning, dedicated streets, and drainage facilities. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
   D.   A certificate by the plat officer, as set forth in chapter 7 of this
title, certifying that the subdivider has complied with one of the following
alternatives: (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
      1.   A good and sufficient bond has been posted with the village clerk in
a penal sum sufficient to cover the amount of one hundred ten percent (110%) of
the estimate by a qualified engineer of the probable expenditures necessary to
enable the subdivider to conform with the standards of construction established
pursuant to the provision of this title. The bond shall be conditioned upon
faithful adherence to the rules and regulations contained in this title; or
      2.   All public improvements have been installed in accordance with the
requirements of this title.
      3.   The governing body will allow the deposit of cash or the filing of
an irrevocable letter of credit in a form acceptable to the governing body in
lieu of the bond described in subsection D1 of this section.
   E.   Protective covenants in the form of recording.
   F.   Street and utility improvements plans shall be submitted and approved
before the final plat is approved.
   G.   Upon submission of the final plat, the subdivider shall deliver to the
planning commission three (3) copies of construction plans and specifications,
prepared, signed and sealed by a professional engineer registered in the state
of Illinois, which shall include or be accompanied by at least the following:
      1.   Street profile plans for each new street in the proposed
subdivision. In cases where the grades of the streets involved are already
established, or in cases of small subdivisions or resubdivisions, the
submission of such street profile plans may be excused by the planning
commission. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
      2.   All public improvements including, without limitation, public
sidewalks, bike paths and/or walkways, sanitary sewers, water mains, storm
sewers, streets, curbs and gutters, street lighting facilities and
appurtenances thereto. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
      3.   Structures for the control of drainage, stormwater and erosion as
required by this title and by other provisions of this code.
      4.   An estimate of the cost of constructing all public improvements and
all drainage, stormwater and erosion control structures, which estimate shall
include the cost of engineering services and which shall be prepared and signed
by the registered professional engineer who prepared the construction plans and
specifications.
      5.   An acknowledgment signed by both the subdivider and the engineer who
prepared the construction plans and specifications that the subdivider and
engineer have entered into a contract for engineering services, which
acknowledgment shall be in a form prescribed by the planning commission.
      6.   Restrictive covenants (if any) in a form acceptable for recording,
and other data, such as other certificates, affidavits, etc., as may be
required in order to comply with this title. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-6-4: MAPS AND DATA FOR APPROVAL OF COMMERCIAL PLANNED DEVELOPMENTS:
   A.   Conditional Approval Of Preliminary Plan:
      1.   The written application for conditional approval of the preliminary
development plan for a commercial planned development shall be accompanied by a
general development plan, including maps at a scale of one inch equals one
hundred feet (1" = 100') and at a size of eighteen inches by twenty four inches
(18" x 24"), or larger in six inch (6") multiples, sketches, elevations, and
supporting documents to fully describe the following elements:
         a.   The general nature, location, and objectives of the proposed
development.
         b.   The areas of the project to be used for commercial, office or
other activities, indicating the total square footage of each use.
         c.   The boundaries of the project, including a legal description of
the metes and bounds of the parcel and the acreage therein.
         d.   An area map showing the adjacent property owners and existing
land uses within two hundred feet (200') of the parcel.
         e.   Existing contours at two foot (2') intervals for slopes of six
percent (6%) or less and at five foot (5') intervals for slopes greater than
six percent (6%), accompanied by an outline of grading plans.
         f.   The proposed street system for the project, designating collector
and local streets and describing their configuration in conformance with the
plans and standards of the village.
         g.   Descriptive data concerning the existing and proposed sewer,
water and storm drainage facilities within the project, indicating their size
and location.
         h.   Location of all main and accessory structures, indicating
intended heights, coverage and orientation.
         i.   Location, size, capacity, drainage and landscaping of the
proposed parking lots within the project, if any. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
         j.   Pedestrian circulation features, walks, paved areas, and bike
paths and/or walkways within the project. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
         k.   Location and type of street lighting.
         l.   Landscaping and forestry features, including planned buffer areas
between uses, if any.
         m.   Community facilities, including recreational and other
nonbuilding areas designated within the project, indicating areas to be in
common ownership.
         n.   Location of fire hydrants such that no point on the perimeter of
the building is farther than one hundred fifty feet (150') from a fire hydrant.
         o.   Market and feasibility studies for principal uses, indicating
proposed rental rates and expected service areas.
         p.   A document describing the proposed phasing program for the
project for all commercial or office structures, recreational and other common
facilities, landscaping and other open space improvements.
      2.   The material will be reviewed with the understanding that the
purpose of a commercial planned development is to create an area that can be
developed with maximum flexibility in design and to promote arrangement of
buildings, circulation systems, land use and utilities while preserving the
existing landscape to the greatest extent possible.
   B.   Final Approval Of Plan:
      1.   No building permit shall be issued until the planning commission has
approved the final plans and reports for the development as a whole or in
stages or portions thereof deemed satisfactory in relation to total
development.
      2.   The following information shall be shown on the final development
plan:
         a.   Primary control points to the descriptions and "ties" to such
control points to the public land survey system, to which all dimensions,
angles, bearings, and similar data on the final development plan shall be
referred.
         b.   Tract boundary lines, right of way lines of streets, easements
and other rights of way, with accurate dimensions, bearings or deflection
angles, and radii, arcs and central angle of all curves.
         c.   Name and right of way width of each street or other right of way.
         d.   Location and right of way widths of existing and/or platted
streets adjacent to the tract.
         e.   Location, dimensions and purpose of all easements.
         f.   Location of all main and accessory structures, indicating
heights, coverage and orientation.
         g.   Location, size, capacity, drainage and landscaping of the
proposed parking lots within the project.
         h.   Pedestrian circulation features, walks and paved areas within the
project.
         i.   Landscaping and forestry features, including planned buffer areas
between uses.
         j.   Community facilities, including recreational and other
nonbuilding areas designed within the project, indicating areas to be in common
ownership, if any.
         k.   Location and description of monuments.
         l.   Names of record owners of adjoining unplatted land.
         m.   Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land
by book and page.
         n.   Certification by an Illinois registered land surveyor as to the
accuracy of the survey.
         o.   Statement of the owner certifying that he has title to the land
of the planned development.
         p.   Statement of the owner dedicating streets, rights of way,
easements, and any sites for public use.
         q.   Title, scale, north arrow, and date.
         r.   Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements, or dedications
as may be required by applicable codes, ordinances and/or statutes pertaining
to zoning, dedicated streets, and drainage facilities. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
      3.   A certificate, as set forth in chapter 7 of this title, shall be
provided by the plat officer certifying that the owner has complied with one of
the following alternatives: (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
         a.   A good and sufficient bond has been posted with the village clerk
in a penal sum sufficient to cover the amount of one hundred ten percent (110%)
of the estimate by a qualified engineer of the probable expenditures necessary
to enable the planned development to conform with the standards of construction
established pursuant to the provision of this title. The bond shall be
conditioned upon faithful adherence to the rules and regulations contained in
this title; or
         b.   All public improvements have been installed in accordance with
the requirements of this title.
         c.   The governing body will allow the deposit of cash or the filing
of an irrevocable letter of credit in a form acceptable to the governing body
in lieu of the bond described in subsection B3a of this section.
      4.   Financial requirements before release of the final plat are as
follows:
         a.   After approval of the final plat by the governing body, but
before execution and delivery of the final plat to the subdivider, the
subdivider shall pay or make arrangements for payment of, if any, fees or
charges due the village with respect to the property and shall also provide
security for the completion of all required improvements to the planning
commission in accordance with the following conditions:
            (1)   Total estimated construction costs and engineering fees for
all required improvements. The estimated cost of such construction shall first
be reviewed and approved by the planning commission; or
            (2)   Total contracted construction costs and engineering fees for
all required improvements. Under this circumstance, all construction contracts
shall first be reviewed and approved by the planning commission.
         b.   Options for providing security for completion of improvements are
as follows:
            (1)   Cash Escrow: A cash deposit or certified check placed with
the village clerk and administered in accordance with the provisions of a
mutually acceptable escrow agreement.
            (2)   Letter Of Credit: An irrevocable, straight, commercial letter
of credit in the form prescribed by the village attorney with a commercial bank
or other financial institution authorized to do business in the state of
Illinois which is acceptable to the village. Deviations from the standard
letter of credit shall not be permitted except with the consent of the
governing body upon the written advice of the village attorney.
            (3)   Surety Bond: A surety bond to insure the construction of the
improvements in accordance with the approved construction plans and
specifications. Said surety bond shall be written by a competent surety company
licensed to do business in the state of Illinois. If a bond is filed, it shall
be in the form and with surety and conditions approved by the governing body
upon the written advice of the village attorney.
         c.   Such security, in whatever form, shall, by its terms, provide
that it shall not expire until released in writing by the village. The
subdivider shall complete the public improvements in accordance with the
approved plans and specifications and shall meet all other conditions precedent
to the acceptance of those public improvements within a two (2) year period
following the approval of the final plat by the village board of trustees. If
the subdivider fails to complete all required improvements in accordance with
the approved plans and specifications within two (2) years following the
approval of the final plat by the governing body, the village may, at its
option, complete or contract for the completion of the public improvements in
accordance with such plans and specifications and pay the cost with the
security provided by the subdivider.
         d.   After the subdivider has paid or made arrangements for payment of
all water or wastewater facilities assessments or other fees and after the
subdivider has provided security for the completion of required improvements as
provided in this subsection B4, the subdivider is authorized to commence
construction of the improvements.
      5.   Street and utility improvement plans shall be submitted and approved
before the final development plan is approved.
      6.   Minor changes in the location, siting, or character of buildings and
structures may be authorized by the plat officer if required by engineering or
other circumstances not foreseen at the time the final development plan was
approved. No change authorized by the plat officer under this subsection B6 may
increase the size of any building or structure nor change the location of any
building or structure by more than ten feet (10') in any direction; provided,
the plat officer may not permit changes beyond the minimum or maximum
requirements set forth in this title. All other changes in the development
plan, including changes in the site plan and the development schedule, must be
made under the procedures that are applicable to the conditional approval of a
preliminary development plan. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-6-5: MAPS AND DATA FOR APPROVAL OF RESIDENTIAL PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS:
   A.   Conditional Approval Of Preliminary Plan:
      1.   The written application for conditional approval of the preliminary
development plan for a residential planned unit development shall be
accompanied by a general development plan, including maps at a scale of one
inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100') and at a size of eighteen inches by
twenty four inches (18" x 24"), or larger in six inch (6") multiples, sketches,
elevations, and supporting documents to fully describe the following elements:
         a.   The general nature, location, and objectives of the proposed
development.
         b.   The location of residential buildings and the number of dwelling
units in each building.
         c.   The boundaries of the project, including a legal description of
the metes and bounds of the parcel and the acreage therein.
         d.   An area map showing the adjacent property owners and existing
land uses within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the parcel.
         e.   Existing contours at two foot (2') intervals for slopes of six
percent (6%) or less and at five foot (5') intervals for slopes greater than
six percent (6%), accompanied by an outline of grading plans.
         f.   The proposed street system for the project, designating collector
and local streets and describing their configuration in conformance with the
plans and standards of the village.
         g.   Descriptive data concerning the existing and proposed sewer,
water and storm drainage facilities within the project, indicating their size
and location.
         h.   Location of all main and accessory structures, indicating
intended heights, coverage and orientation.
         i.   Location, size, capacity, drainage and landscaping of proposed
parking lots within the project, if any. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
         j.   Pedestrian circulation features, walks, paved areas, and bike
paths and/or walkways within the project. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
         k.   Landscaping and forestry features, including planned buffer areas
within the project.
         l.   Community facilities, including recreational and other
nonbuilding areas designated within the project, indicating areas to be in
common ownership.
         m.   Location of fire hydrants such that no dwelling is farther than
three hundred feet (300') from a fire hydrant.
         n.   A document describing the proposed phasing program for the
project for all recreational and other common facilities, landscaping and other
open space improvements.
      2.   The material will be reviewed with the understanding that the
purpose of a residential planned unit development is to create an area that can
be developed with maximum flexibility in design and to promote the efficient
use of land and facilitate an economic arrangement of buildings, circulation
systems, land use and utilities while preserving the existing landscape to the
greatest extent possible.
      3.   Yard, setback, lot size, height, and frontage requirements may be
waived for the residential planned unit development; provided, that there is
compliance with the spirit and intent of this subsection in the total
development plan, as determined by the planning commission. The planning
commission may determine that certain setbacks be required within all or a
portion of the perimeter of the site and shall exercise ultimate discretion as
to whether the total development plan does comply with the spirit and intent of
this subsection.
   B.   Final Approval Of Plan:
      1.   No building permit shall be issued until the planning commission has
approved the final plans and reports for the development as the whole or in
stages or portions thereof deemed satisfactory in relation to total
development.
      2.   The following information shall be shown on the final development
plan:
         a.   Primary control points or descriptions and "ties" to such control
points to the public land survey system, to which all dimensions, angles,
bearings, and similar data on the final development plan shall be referred.
         b.   Tract boundary lines, right of way lines of streets, easements
and other rights of way with accurate dimensions, bearings or deflection
angles, and radii, arcs and central angle of all curves.
         c.   Name and right of way width of each street or other right of way.
         d.   Location and right of way widths of existing and/or platted
streets adjacent to the tract.
         e.   Location, dimensions and purpose of all easements.
         f.   Location of all main and accessory structures, indicating
heights, coverage and orientation.
         g.   Location, size, capacity, drainage and landscaping of the
proposed parking lots within the project.
         h.   Pedestrian circulation features, walks and paved areas within the
project.
         i.   Landscaping and forestry features, including planned buffer areas
between uses.
         j.   Community facilities, including recreational and other
nonbuilding areas designed within the project, indicating areas to be in common
ownership, if any.
         k.   Location and description of monuments.
         l.   Names of record owners of adjoining unplatted land.
         m.   Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land
by book and page.
         n.   Certification by an Illinois registered land surveyor as to the
accuracy of the survey.
         o.   Statement of the owner certifying that he has title to the land
of the planned development.
         p.   Statement of the owner dedicating streets, rights of way,
easements, and any sites for public use.
         q.   Title, scale, north arrow, and date.
         r.   Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements, or dedications
as may be required by applicable codes, ordinances and/or statutes pertaining
to zoning, dedicated streets, and drainage facilities. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
      3.   A certificate, as set forth in chapter 7 of this title, shall be
provided by the plat officer certifying that the owner has complied with one of
the following alternatives: (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
         a.   A good and sufficient bond has been posted with the village clerk
in a penal sum sufficient to cover the amount of one hundred ten percent (110%)
of the estimate by a qualified engineer of the probable expenditures necessary
to enable the planned development to conform with the standards of construction
established pursuant to the provisions of this title. The bond shall be
conditioned upon faithful adherence to the rules and regulations contained in
this title; or
         b.   All public improvements have been installed in accordance with
the requirements of this title.
         c.   The governing body will allow the deposit of cash or the filing
of an irrevocable letter of credit in a form acceptable to the governing body
in lieu of the bond described in subsection B3a of this section.
      4.   Street and utility improvement plans shall be submitted and approved
before the final development plan is approved.
      5.   Minor changes in the location, siting, or character of buildings and
structures may be authorized by the plat officer, if required by engineering or
other circumstances not foreseen at the time the final development plan was
approved. No change authorized by the plat officer under this subsection B5 may
increase the size of any building or structure, nor change the location of any
building or structure by more than ten feet (10') in any direction; provided,
the plat officer may not permit changes beyond the minimum or maximum
requirements set forth in this title. All other changes in the development
plan, including changes in the site plan and the development schedule, must be
made under the procedures that are applicable to the conditional approval of
the preliminary development plan. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-6-6: RECORDING FINAL PLAT:
Within ninety (90) days after delivery of an approved final plat to the
subdivider by the planning commission, the subdivider shall record the final
plat with the county recorder of deeds. If the plat is not so recorded, it
shall have no validity and shall not be recorded without subsequent approval of
the governing body. The governing body may extend the filing date an additional
ninety (90) days if the subdivider demonstrates unique circumstances or
conditions whereby the recording of the final plat could not be accomplished as
herein required. (Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
10-6-7: PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Preliminary Approval Of Certain Components Of Public Improvements: Upon
the completion of satisfactory testing, the department of public works may give
preliminary approval to water mains, sanitary sewers and streets after
installation of curbs and base but before installation of pavement. Upon
receipt of such preliminary approval from the public works department, the
planning commission may issue building permits for the construction of
improvements to the lots within the subdivision. In any event, however, no
occupancy permit shall be issued until public improvements which serve the lots
in the subdivision have been accepted by the village as provided in this title.
Notwithstanding the receipt of preliminary approval, the village shall not
provide village services within the subdivision including, without limitation,
maintenance, snowplowing or garbage pick up until final acceptance of all
improvements.
   B.   Inspection Of, Acceptance Of And Warranty For Public Improvements:
      1.   If any plat of a subdivision dedicates public streets, easements or
other improvements to the public use, the approval of the final plat by the
governing body shall not constitute acceptance by the village of any such
public improvements, irrespective of any act or acts by any officer, agent or
employee of the village with respect to such public improvements.
      2.   Upon completion of the public improvements, the subdivider and the
subdivider's engineer shall submit to the village a signed certificate of
compliance which indicates that all public improvements constructed in
connection with the subdivision comply with all applicable requirements of this
title, and that such public improvements were installed substantially in
accordance with the approved construction plans and specifications. The
certification shall be in a form developed and approved by the planning
commission and the public works department and shall, in general, address each
requirement imposed by this title. The public works department shall review the
certificate of compliance and shall conduct such investigation and inspections
as it deems appropriate and recommend to the governing body such action as the
public works department deems appropriate based upon its review and inspection.
(Ord. 675, 2-24-2011)
      3.   Upon completion of the public improvements, the subdivider shall
submit as built plans for all such public improvements which accurately reflect
the location of the public improvements as constructed. Such plans shall be
marked by the engineer as "as built" construction plans. The subdivider or the
subdivider's engineer shall submit to the village a copy of the as built
construction plans on a CD in a format acceptable to the public works
department. If the governing body concludes that the representations made in
the certificate of compliance are accurate, then the governing body shall
accept the dedication of the public improvements on behalf of the village.
However, such acceptance shall not become effective until the subdivider
provides security against structural failure of the public improvements in the
form of a surety bond, cash bond or irrevocable letter of credit in an amount
equal to fifteen percent (15%) of the cost of constructing the improvements.
Such security shall have the same characteristics as the security for the
completion of the public improvements and shall allow the village to draw upon
the security to pay costs incurred by the village to repair any structural
failure of the public improvements which occurs after the effective date of
acceptance of the public improvements by the village. The security, less any
amount used to repair defective public improvements, shall be released to the
subdivider after the second anniversary of the effective date of acceptance of
the public improvements by the governing body. Security for the completion of
the public improvements provided at the time of final plat approval shall not
be released until such time as the security against structural failure of the
public improvements, as herein provided, has been submitted by the subdivider.
(Ord. 675, 2-24-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
CHAPTER 7
FORM OF CERTIFICATES OF PLAT OFFICER
SECTION:
10-7-1: Form Of Certificate For Preliminary Plat
10-7-2: Form Of Certificate Of Approval Of A Final Plat With Public
Improvements
10-7-3: Form Of Certificate Of Approval Of A Final Plat Without Public
Improvements
10-7-4: Form Of Certificate Of Plat Officer Where The Plat Or Survey Is Exempt
10-7-5: Form Of Certificate For Boundary Map
10-7-1: FORM OF CERTIFICATE FOR PRELIMINARY PLAT:
The form of certificate of plat officer for approval of a preliminary plat, as
set forth in subsection
10-3-3D4 of this title, shall be as follows:
I,                     , Plat Approving Officer for the Village of Germantown
Hills, In the County of Woodford and State of Illinois, Do Hereby Certify that
the above Preliminary Subdivision Plat conforms to the Requirements of the
Subdivision Regulations for Germantown Hills, as amended.
(Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
10-7-2: FORM OF CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL OF A FINAL PLAT WITH PUBLIC
IMPROVEMENTS:
The form of certificate of plat officer for approval of a final plat where
public improvements are to be installed pursuant to subsection
10-6-3D, 10-6-4B3 or 10-6-5B3 of this title shall be as follows:
I,                     , Plat Approving Officer for the Village of Germantown
Hills, In the County of Woodford and State of Illinois, Do Hereby Certify that
the above Final Subdivision Plat conforms to the Requirements of the
Subdivision Regulations for Germantown Hills, as amended, and that the above
owners and proprietor have posted good and sufficient bond, letter of credit or
escrow with the Village Clerk of said Germantown Hills, in a penal sum
sufficient to cover the estimate by a qualified engineer of the probable
expenditure necessary to enable the subdivider to conform with the standards of
the construction established pursuant to the provisions of this ordinance.
(Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
10-7-3: FORM OF CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL OF A FINAL PLAT WITHOUT PUBLIC
IMPROVEMENTS:
The form of certificate of plat officer for approval of a final plat where no
public improvements are to be installed or have been installed and accepted
pursuant to subsection
10-6-3D, 10-6-4B3 or 10-6-5B3 of this title shall be as follows:
I,                     , Plat Approving Officer for the Village of Germantown
Hills, In the County of Woodford and State of Illinois, Do Hereby Certify that
the above Final Subdivision Plat conforms to the Requirements of the
Subdivision Regulations for Germantown Hills, as amended.
(Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
10-7-4: FORM OF CERTIFICATE OF PLAT OFFICER WHERE THE PLAT OR SURVEY IS EXEMPT:
The form of certificate of plat officer where the plat or survey is exempt
under these regulations shall be as follows:
I,                     , Plat Approving Officer for the Village of Germantown
Hills, In the County of Woodford and State of Illinois, Do Hereby Accept the
Above Survey as Exempt from the Requirements of the Subdivision Regulations for
Germantown Hills.
(Ord. 711, 10-25-2012)
10-7-5: FORM OF CERTIFICATE FOR BOUNDARY MAP:
The form of certificate of plat officer for approval of a boundary map, as set
forth in section
10-3-5 of this title, shall be as follows:
I,                     , Plat Approving Officer for the Village of Germantown
Hills, In the County of Woodford and State of Illinois, Do Hereby Certify that
the above Boundary Map conforms to the Boundary Map Requirements of the
Subdivision Regulations for Germantown Hills.
(Ord. 735, 7-24-2014)
